description:
Had dinner with my husband on a date night and had such an amazing experience!
We did not plan on coming here specifically and surprisingly found an availability through OpenTable right away!
The service was really good, the food was AMAZING and the atmosphere was so cozy and nice.
I have lived in SF for the last 3.5 years now and have been to the Castro many times. I didn't notice this place before but so glad my husband took me here!
Definitely will come back and definitely will recommend it to friends!
A real gem!
author: Hai C.

description:
Service was decent once they realized we were there but we sat for about 15 minutes before a waiter came over to us. The soup was incredibly delicious. My friend tried a bite of my soup and then instantly ordered one for herself. Entrees were ok but not memorable. The sea bass is a full fish so be ready for that. The orecchiette had large raw greens that overshadowed the yummy pasta. Seemed like the greens were used to fill the bowl but they detracted from the pasta itself. Ambiance is cute and the vibe is lively but quiet enough for an easy conversation 

High marks for the soup and ambiance
Average marks for service and entrees
author: Janelle M.

description:
Poesia is a homey Italian restaurant.  My favorite pastas at the moment are Fileji di Renato (spiral shaped pasta with pork ribs sugo and roasted garlic tomato sauce) and Pasta Nera con Gamberoni, Calamari e 'Nduja (squid ink pasta with calamari, prawns, and 'nduja sausage).

1 star off: I did not enjoy the Orecchiette con Purea di Fave e Pomodorini (orecchiette pasta with fava bean puree, green chard, tomatoes confit, and smoked ricotta).  The pasta was overcooked and did not seem seasoned.

Although Yelp photos show a dark, intimate restaurant, I would not say it is.  The restaurant can get quite loud from the street noises in the Castro.  Staff is friendly and with cool Italian accents though, and they are not as loud as the Castro.
author: Ally W.

description: Had a wonderful dinner here last night with my husband. Excellent service, delicious food, romantic ambiance. This place feels old school Castro, which is nice in neighborhood beset with revolving door, overpriced, "trendy" eateries. And hey, this place is even good enough for Oprah who I recall eating here a few years back!
author: Alexander C.

description: Such a good place to have a meal. Quaint upstairs restaurant in the middle of the Castro district. The food is really good and moderately priced (3 cocktails, 2 starters, 4 mains, 1 dessert = $145 more than enough for 4 ppl -- could have gotten 3 mains). Good for sharing. Pastas are homemade. Service is authentic Italian.
author: E U.

description: A group of us decided to celebrate our racing season with a great dinner and One of the crew recommended Poesia. So we made a reservation for a party of 10 and proceeded to meet there. We were greeted by the owner an promptly seated at a corner table. Our orders were all over the map. From steak to pasta to seafood.  My wife chose the squid ink pasta and I ordered a steak.  When our dishes arrived, her pasta looked amazing and tasted even better.  My steak was excellent but I had a taste of the ink pasta and it was out of this world.
author: Robert H.

description: Worth the drive to the Castro area of San Francisco! Wonderful experience from the waitstaff to the desert. Nice wines. Will definitely return!
author: Joy I.

description: This is one of our favorite stops in the Castro for dinner.  Wonderful food, great service,  friendly staff.
author: George R.

description:
I love that they have happy hour but the oysters though really fresh get served with a very oily mignonette. The waiter didn't even know what a mignonette is. It should be.light acidic like lemon & vinegar-' not this. And the eggplant caponata is so sweet. 2 olives cut in half,
yet no tomatoes I could find, all sweet no tart. Note to self: only order the tomato bread soup or the Branzino. These 2 items are consistently good.
author: Scott F.

description:
Each time I would drop in and say hello to this Italian place. Unique and cozy!
The new bartender is so efficient and we are always feeling so warmly welcomed.
author: Brodie Z.

description:
The place is cute and small so reservations are definitely needed.  7:30pm and later, the noise level reaches a fever pitch so conversation is difficult.  The Staff are all friendly and charming, if not in a rush, but understandable since there are 4 of them to cover a packed restaurant.

Their bread is generic and cold, but the citrus-herb-olive oil dipping sauce is fresh and vibrant, so it makes up for the plain bread, (Helpful Tip: Spoon some of this dipping sauce over the many mounds of arugula you're about to get with your appetizers/meal).  Below is what I recommend:

Definitely Get:
-A small Salami & Cheese plate, (Tagliere Salumi e Formaggi).  4 people can share easily or 2 really hungry people.  A good variety of fresh, thinly sliced meats and cheeses.

-Pasta with Pork Tomato Sauce, (Fileji di Renato).  SO Good, and a good portion.  The pasta are these twisted cut ropes that you can tell is homemade and wonderfully chewy.  The pork tomato sauce has a good amount of tender pork pieces and the sauce tasted like it was cooked for a long time, so hearty and comforting.

-Pasta with Lamb Tomato Sauce, (Fettucine al Ragu di Agnello): I don't eat lamb, but I'm sure it must be as good as the pork version.

-Tiramisu:  The Yelp pictures show this in a dainty, shallow glass serving boat, but when we, a party of 4, ordered it, it came out as a larger short brick.  The lady fingers were still distinguishable, (not soggy), the cream was light with a dusting of cocoa/coffee powder & a taste of rum in every spoonful that wasn't overpowering.  I can see why another Yelper said this was the best he ever tasted.

-Wine: For a party of 4, a bottle of red wine, (for less than 4 people, it makes more sense to order by the glass).  For those of us who aren't wine experts, faced with pages of white/red wines can be like playing wine roulette hoping you'd get a light, drinkable wine that won't distract from the food, (meaning not oaky/tanniny).  We lucked out, the waiter recommended a red wine from Sicily and it was perfect.  

Maybe Get-Depends on you're craving/taste:
-Steak salad, (Tagliata di Filetto di Manzo).  6-8, half inch by 2 1/2 inches of perfectly cooked and seasoned medium-but more rare, steak pieces surrounding a mountain of arugula sprinkled with faro.

-Grilled Squid Salad, (Calamari alla Griglia).  I don't eat squidlies, but if you like just grilled squid, this is for you.  6-8 baby squid grilled surrounding a mountain of arugula.  I could smell the fresh grilled smokiness of my friend who ordered it beside me & it smelled good.

-Whole fish in parchment paper, (Brazino al Cartoccio).  It was the whole fish, (without the head or tail as shown in some Yelp pictures).  Perfectly cooked with amazing cubes of potatoes that were crisp on the outside and creamy on the inside.  Only thing is all of it was bland, (another use of that citrus/herb bread dipping sauce!).

Don't Get:
-Toasted Bread slices topped with Artichoke hearts, (Crostini di Carciofi).  For $10 its 2 slices of plain, toasted bread with not enough moisture or artichoke hearts to stay on top of the bread.

-Anything with homemade Ravioli, (usually a special).  Although the fact the ravioli is homemade is impressive, they didn't brown the butter sauce enough and there were only 2 small sage leaves buried in the dish somewhere.  They said the ravioli was filled with dark kale and 2 different kinds of cheeses, but you couldn't see or taste the cheeses because the kale conquered all.

-Side of Vegetables, (Verdure al forno).  It was bland, over cooked and was late to our table, (to their credit it was taken off of the bill).

I'll definitely come back, but it's good to know what to order & what to avoid.
author: Johnnie N.

description: The staff were so friendly! I had a really amazing time and enjoyed all of my food. It was so delicious! I especially enjoyed the squid ink pasta. Also, all of the servers were incredibly handsome and friendly! The wine selection was outstanding.
author: Joni W.

description: Really good Italian restaurant in the Castro. Came here after happy hour with friends and we had a great time.  Ordered the burrata, crostini and branzino and everything was great.  Service and ambiance were also excellent.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Had an amazing experience at Poesia last night.
Made the reservation through Open Table the night before for a small birthday celebration. They not only flawlessly accommodated a vegan member of the party and an infant, but Sara took the time to call me a few hours before to see if I wanted to write a special message on their birthday tiramisu. They sat us at the round table tucked away next to one end of the bar (the best table IMO). We loved our food but the favorites were the burrata artichoke crostini, the insalata el cavolo (kale never tasted so good), and of course their go-to Fileji. With the intimate setting, heart-warming stomach filling food, and wonderful service it took us back to the Italian countryside. Thank you Poesia for another great evening.
author: Seira M.

description: If you are alone in home and dont know what food you want, you must call and in few minutes you will receive best italian food.
author: Giorgi K.

description: Food is awesome as always... however... the kitchen was a disaster at getting things out in a timely manner... had to cancel our appetizer Bc the main courses were coming out beforehand. We'd ordered the appetizer 25 min before the main course so we could have it with our wine. I'll be back.. not my first time here...  cheers
author: Adrien T.

description:
Poesia has a lot of potential to be a great restaurant. The fresh pasta was great, the complimentary pesto served with bread was great, and the marinated olives were pretty good. However, the ambiance was a little lackluster and they served warm wine. 

Drinks:
Unfortunately my Cabernet was served unusually warm. This was probably due to it being a warm day, but that's no excuse to serve warm wine. My boyfriend got a negroni that was one of the better negronis I've had.

Ambiance:
It was very dark, and I couldn't help but wonder if this was to hide the dinginess of the place. I would like to see Poesia throw the curtains open and have a clean and better lit space. If you can get a seat on their balcony, ignore this section.

Olive Marinate:
These were pretty good for the small price paid. You can taste the citrus and they have fresh herbs sprinkled on them. 

Orecchiette con Purea di Fave e Pomodorini:
This dish was very interesting and has a lot of potential. Orecchiette is served over a good amount of puréed fava beans, which gives this vegetarian dish some substance. This is paired with Swiss chard and smoked ricotta - both giving the dish a very unique and earthy taste that was delicious. I think more salt may have been needed when cooking to make the chard pop a little bit more, but overall this was a good dish.

Fettuccine al Ragú di Agnello:
This was a great dish. The lamb shank was perfectly seasoned and cooked, and the pasta was tender.
author: Eric R.

description:
Datteri Ripieni was from the gods! Definitely a side you cannot pass up. Would be a great appetizer.
Overall service was wonderful and attentive to our needs. Quaint atmosphere enjoyed by a group of 8. They were willing to split the bill too!
author: Dallas L.

description:
A hidden gem in the Castro. If you're looking for a great place to enjoy authentic Italian food--search no longer! It was the perfect place to eat after a movie at the Castro Theatre. It was a busy Friday night, but we only waited for 5 min for a table--very acceptable for an unplanned visit. 

I recommend the calamari--it's charcoal grilled, not fried! This was a huge selling point for us beings that we try to stay away from fried foods. The eggplant parmigiana was an excellent second course. I highly recommend the limoncello for an after dinner liquor. 

All in all--highly recommend this place to anyone looking for a great Italian meal in a lively atmosphere!
author: Joey T.

description:
Thanks to my handy-dandy Yelp app, I found this lovely restaurant. The inside is charming, the customer service was welcoming and polite, the menu is vegetarian friendly, and the food is fantastic! All four of the dishes we ordered  (see pictures) were extremely fresh and delicious! The Happy Hour menu is awesome and the pricing is very reasonable for the quality of food and service received. If you're in the area, definitely check out Poesia! 

4 plates and 1 well drink = $50.03, excluding tip.
author: Jennae H.

description: This restaurant was particularly good tonight. The salmon was seasoned and tender, with incredible flavor and freshness. It was the best salmon I ever tasted. My partner, Mike, particularly enjoyed his eggplant parmigiana, which also had incredible taste and flavor, the best eggplant parmigiana ever. I highly recommend this restaurant. It's a tribute to Italian cooking and Francesco is a wonderful host.
author: Steven H.

description:
Service on point. 
Almost to a fault. 
I don't need a server at the table every five minutes. 
Let me read the menu and make some choices. I recommend to the manager that you have your servers pump the proverbial breaks. 

Projection in the main dinning room is a complete and total distraction. And on top of that. It's not even centered on the wall. Speaking off walls, I couldn't keep my eyes off all the bird decals. Someone thought that was a good design idea. I'm assuming they're straight? Because no good gay would have allowed that. 

The food was good. 
But you can't really fuck up pasta, can you?
author: Jade D.

description:
The Miracle on 18th Street. Poesia is in the heart of the Castro. Unbelievably, among the traffic congestion and double parked cars, we found a legal parking space - directly in front of Poesia. Truly a miracle of Christmas!

The restaurant is upstairs. I did not see a lift anywhere, yet the single toilet is ADA compliant. This was once a residence. Interior is comfortable, though seating can be cramped. They chose to play a movie (sound off) on one wall. I had my back to it, others in our party did not seem distracted. 

Service was better than most restaurants. Attire is casual. At 7pm on a Friday night, the place was packed. Wisely, we had a reservation and were seated immediately.

The ladies loved the Branzino bass. The Dattei dates added to the enjoyment of the meal. The Polenta e Funghi (mushrooms) was average. My Pasta Nera (calamari and shrimp noodles) was tasty, but overly spicy hot for my New England taste buds. The Tiramisu was gigantic while the chocolate mousse leaned towards smallish - both were delightful. Prices are to be expected. With wine and side dishes the three use ran up a tab over $200 (before tip).

Bottom line: we whole heartedly recommend Poesia. Get reservations and expect parking from Hell in a city that doesn't like autos.
author: Wayne J.

description:
One star is a gift!!!
Hands down the WORST SF restaurant ever!!  Cold soup. Fish speciality was all bones. Bad service.$130 and we were still hungry.
author: Suzanne M.

description:
Yes, the place is sort of hiding, but the pasta is bomb. I had the squid ink one and from start to finish the food didn't disappoint. Had dinner here and they had an oldie movie playing on a projected wall. The decorations are "interesting" since the frames are not straight. 

Highlight of the food was definitely the pasta, can't emphasize that enough.
author: Kevin L.

description:
We have been meaning to go to this restaurant for years and decided to celebrate our anniversary there. Even early in the evening the acoustics were too loud, family at bar with crying baby, decor was depressing with old portraits of strangers hanging all over the place. Although there was a cool black and white movie being shown on the back wall, no sound.

We ordered the arugula salad, pine nuts, fennel and olive oil dressing. That was delicious as well as the spread for the fresh bread.
We both orderd the turmeric chicken which comes with broccolini and some type of carb(white mushy texture with some cheese in it?). The chicken was boring, flat and mushy. It should have had apricots, toasted almonds, raisins to add some interest and texture. It was very disappointing. The broccolini was slightly over cooked. It should have been a bit crisper. The service was okay, The house red which was a pinot noir was much better then the cab that was on the menu. And that baby that was crying...

Will not be back to Poesia. The chef is not that talented and the food is not inexpensive. We're happy we can take this place off our bucket list.
Too bad there aren't any really fine dining restaurants in the Castro. We really could use one.
author: Craig A.

description:
Food: Tagliolini all Pesto and the Caprese was tasty. The polenta lacked that umami kick to it
Service: pretty good, friendly waitresses and bartender
Atmosphere: quite loud, night club bass can be heard from the next door over. Cute black and white movie projected onto the rear wall
author: Ken K.

description:
One of my ABSOLUTE FAVORITE places. The Italian food is incredible. Very authentic. 
There are several regulars (like myself) who are there every Sunday for the lasagna special. They have specials every single day and they frequently try new recipes. The manager/head chef Rosella does an absolutely amazing lasagna. She makes the noodles, sauces, and cheeses by hand. It is absolutely AMAZING. I highly recommend. 

If you've never been, it can be hard to find. It is up a flight of stairs on the second level directly across the street from Midnight Sun. 
The ambiance is very comfortable and casual. It is a place to go for fine Italian food. The waiters are all very friendly. 
The service is always great. They can easily fill the entire restaurant on any given day. They have a full bar, clean facilities, great food. What else could you possibly need?
author: Chris S.

description: One of my favorite places in the city for a cozy, high-quality, reasonably priced dinner. Teddy, the bartender, is a gem.
author: Jax R.

description: Great food, cool place and wonderful wine. The location is pretty cool in the Castro. Definitely will go back.
author: Wade W.

description: Made a reservation here for my husband's birthday. Where to begin? Talk about the best old fashioned I've ever had - get them on happy hour when they're half off. Squid ink pasta was delicious - a MUST when you come here. Really authentic. Staff is even from Italy - can't ask for much more authentic Italian than that. Great service and excellent wine menu.
author: Shareen S.

description: Great neighborhood spot for family style dining. Back in the 70's North Beach was home to an abundance of family style Italian restaurants which sadly are relics of the past. Having just experienced a group meal with 12 friends I am pleased to announce that Italian family style dining is alive and well at Poesia. The menu suggested by owner Francesco was bountiful and tasty. All that was missing was the bowl of pig's knuckles. I will let the pictures speak for themselves. Especially enjoyed the pastas and the burrata. Looking forward to a repeat visit to further explore the menu. Mangia Bene!
author: Jim B.

description: Been to Poesia several times last few years. Never disappointed. I like the atmosphere, the fancy drinks, and the top-notch authentic Italian menu. Friendly staff and owner complete the picture. But after last week's Friday night dinner, I'm inspired to yelp. Started with a perfect Negroni, artichoke crostini, and a Caesar salad. All good. Then the wine--a fabulous Calabrese red. Not sure the name... first 4 letters are "Pella...". It was recommended by the owner as a Barbera alternative. Then the mains: a spectacular osso buco with risotto Milanese and succulent medallions of filet mignon with arugula salad. No pasta this time. Maybe next. Poesia continues to impress!
author: David A.

description:
Two girl friends and I decided to have a girl's dinner date and Poesia seemed like a pretty promising Italian restaurant. This restaurant is quite small but surely popular because almost all the tables were filled up by 6:30pm. 

Complementary bread is served (it was average) with olive oil and vinegar--standard. A happy hour menu is available until 6:30pm with discounted tapas and drinks, so I recommend making a reservation for 6:15pm to make the happy hour. 

We got the Squid Ink Pasta, Lamb Shank Fettuccini, and Fileji Di Renato (pork). The server said that the pasta will be slightly undercooked because the texture will be better tasting that way--she was right. The pasta was delicious because it was very chewy. I personally am a fan of white sauce more than red sauce but I really enjoyed the pasta here regardless. The red sauce in my Squid Ink Pasta was slightly spicy and it was perfect. The bites of octopus added great texture to the already chewy pasta dish. 

We also wanted to try the Burrata appetizer and the Cauliflower side dish but we're glad we didn't order it because we were super full after the pasta. Next time!
author: Christy W.

description:
meravigliosa! The ambiente is tasteful, Italian inspired but still true to its home in the Castro. The food was outstanding, the waitstaff was knowledgeable and attentive, and I didn't have to wait for a table at all despite not having a reservation. It was worth every penny! I have lived all over the world and this is the closest to true Italian food and sentiment I have ever found outside of Italy and its immediate surrounding countries. As a solo female traveler, I found the space delightful and comfortable. Francesco, the owner, was wonderful with all the customers and we had a great little chat. 

I highly recommend this spot if you want to treat yourself! I hope to return some time in the near future.
author: Alia G.

description: If I had not been part of a group, I would not have eaten here.  The entry and dining room smelled of spoiled shellfish. I had the special, a mushroom fettuccini in a white wine sauce. The mushrooms were soggy, the sauce was too heavy, and the dish completely lacked seasoning.  Do yourself a favor, find another restaurant.
author: Food E.

description: So pleased to find good food in the Castro. Comfortable location off the street. Hearty, delicious food. Aria cocktail recommended by bartender was flavorful. Beets in beet salad were sliced a bit thin for my preference, but salad was delicious. Tomato based pasta sauce with shredded pork ribs was comforting and delicious. Staff seemed heavy on Italians and they're universally beautiful, which no doubt sells in the Castro!!  Wonderful experience.
author: Steven F.

description:
This review will prove only that you can please some of the people some of the time and not please some of the people some of the time.  This place must be among the most inconsistent experiences in SF, or so it seems from other reviews.
The good: the grilled calamari was excellent
The bad: the highly touted "homemade pasta" was so so - no better than anywhere including out of a box
The ugly: service was inconsistent - appetizers came when they should have, but then a long wait for the rest of the meal - some food arrived lukewarm suggesting it was left sitting out awaiting the server's attention to bring it - but worst of all was the deafening noise - do not go if you want to talk to anyone - it was so bad that the management apologized three times - and why add a background drum machine noise  to the mix?
author: S K.

description:
A wonderful date deserves a wonderful place. Being able to reserve a table here just made it all the better. We arrived just near the tail end of Happy Hour, and our waiter was very happy to honor the lower cocktail prices during our time. Which is good, cause boy did we drink ( and remain extremely classy ). We shared an appetizer, and thus began that dance of emotions, while stuffing our mouths full of delicious food. I quality of the pasta was wonderful, and while the portion sizes are smaller than I am used to, I left feeling very full. And with a dessert menu like that, we just couldn't say no ( and you know you have "met the one" when you both realize that even though your full, there is still room for dessert ). 

The waiter keep our waters filled, and our drinks coming, while leaving us be to enjoy a romantic dinner conversation.
author: Bryan M.

description: Happy hour here: THE BOMB! Get the basil mojito, probably one of the bests I've ever had! Also, as authentic Italian I'm telling you they have AUTHENTIC Italian food, TRUE STORY! You totally have to try the dates with cheese, super yum as snack with happy hour! I can't wait to go there and have a dinner and give you some more reviews, wait for it, it's gonna be epic! Also owner super nice guy, make sure you meet him!
author: Irina P.

description: Good food but really slow service and bad attitude. Sorry not coming back. I hope they can improve their attitude and service
author: Mete T.

description: Went here for the first time recently, and I fell in love. Super quaint space with good lighting (excellent date spot), friendly attentive service, and the food was incredible. Everything was so flavorful and seemed very authentic. The executive chef came out to our table to explain the dishes and share her insights. She was super friendly, informative and charming. Overall, I loved the experience, and now consider Poesia my go-to Italian restaurant in SF.
author: Steven A.

description:
4 stars for food, 2 stars for service.  Poesia's food was quite good, but the service was a huge disappointment.  The decor is traditional and the prices not cheap.

The service at Poesia was disappointing from beginning to end.  We were seated at 7:30pm, but no one came to greet us and take our drink orders until 20 minutes later!  They didn't bring us the menu for wine by the bottle until we asked.  Throughout the meal, no one came to bring us more water after ours ran out.  Later, we had to ask for the dessert menu ourselves.  Our party of three did not wrap up until 10:15pm, and this was not by choice - our dinner took nearly three hours because of the consistently slow service.  

The food at Poesia was its saving grace.  The gnocchi starter was good, and I quite liked my pasta with pork.  My friend really enjoyed her eggplant Parmesan, and my husband really liked his squid ink pasta with seafood.  The broccoli side was decent.  Finally, the chocolate spuma dessert with salt and spice was tasty (though quite small and not sharing friendly).

The decor was traditional and old fashioned - my dining companions liked it, though I would have preferred a simpler, more modern look.

The food and drinks were not cheap.  Consider getting a bottle of wine instead of wines by the glass.  We made the mistake of getting multiple glasses of the $14/glass Alicante (quite good) instead of the $45 bottle.

Overall, despite the good food and drinks, I can't get over the slow, disappointing service.  Ugh - what a shame.
author: Barnali D.

description: I love going here. The staff is always attentive and the food exceptional. It's a smaller space so it's great for smaller groups or with just one friend. I've been here several times to catch-up over dinner and wine and will definitely return.
author: Scott K.

description:
We enjoyed the food at Poesia.  It's a cute and cozy neighborhood restaurant.  But we had the unfortunate experience of being served by this waitress who was trying to rush us to order our food.  We wanted to take our time in checking out the full menu.  She asked us if we'd like to order drinks, which we did.  At that point, we also ordered our appetizers.  She insisted that we also order our entrees, which we were not quite ready to do.  But she did not have a smile on her face, and she seemed rushed.  Typically, a good wait staff person would let you order drinks and starters, and can come back to take your order for entrees.  But not this one.  She just wanted the whole order taken at the same time.

We had a $100 gift certificate.  Upon being seated, we asked her if there is to be remaining balance after our meal, would we be able to come back to finish the balance next time.  She told us yes.  But when we were all done, the manager came up and advised us that we did indeed have some balance remaining, and wanted to know if we would like to order more food or desserts - since we would NOT be able to use the remaining balanace at next meal.  Very disappointing.  If she had given us the correct information, we could have ordered accordingly and used up the entire $100.

My star rating is as follows:  4 star for the food; 2 star for service; so it averages out to a 3 star.
author: nardo m.

description:
Terrible experience.  Daughter made a reservation for 7:30 for our party of three.  I heard the phone call.  We arrived at 7:25 and were informed (rather rudely) that our reservation was for 6:30.  Server said it wasn't a problem since they had an available table, but that we had been expected earlier.  

Not off to a great start. . . . We ordered an appetizer and three entrees.  Appetizer never came.  Entrees FINALLY arrived, after an exceptionally long wait.  I had the ravioli--ample portion and quite tasty.  Daughter had the gnocchi, and it was a very small portion.  I shared some of my ravioli with her.  Hubby got pork--and it had a bone in it!  Mind you, our appetizer never arrived, but we were charged for it. 

When we FINALLY received our bill, again after an exceptionally long wait, my husband pointed out the fact that we had never received our appetizer, and it was removed from our bill.  

There are too many great places to eat in San Francisco to spend so much time and so much $$$$ here.
author: Ruth C.

description:
Poesia is such a lovely hidden secret right in the middle of the Castro scene - a quaint juxtaposition of the thumpa thumpa from the bars around. 

It's like dining at a friend's place. The space is intimate, warm, and welcoming. To boot, the food hits the right marks too. Totally love the grilled calamari salad. Nice char on the squid with a salad that hits the right balance of acid. Also had a zucchini blossom gnocchi that was quite lovely. Top all of this off with lovely service and Poesia is quite a winner. 

If anything, starting a night of drinking here prevents an immediate kamakazi dive into drunken lunacy with the plethora of two-for-one drink specials around. At the very least, you get some good food to start the night.
author: Jon L.

description:
Mixed experience.
Great value happy hour. 
Cozy and homey ambiance.
Really great service. Loved our waiter!
Food was hit or miss.
Sweet potato gnocchi was the highlight.
Oh and not deep fried eggplant parm.
Raining and marble stairs are treacherous. I wiped out and am in a lot of pain!
author: Andrew K.

description: Had a delicious Italian meal at this place! Ordered eggplant Parmesan to start and it was delicious with the basket of bread! Great location and atmosphere
author: Robin P.

description: Poesia is one of my favorite places for a special occasion dinner. The food is fantastic, really good and the service and ambiance matches! Excellent all around.
author: Andrea A.

description: I have had good meals at Poesia in the past but this last visit was a total bust. Soon after we were seated, bread and olive oil were brought to the table. The bread was good but the olive oil was so harsh and bitter that it was completely inedible. Really horrible. We ordered arugula and fennel salad which came way over dressed and covered in what must have been the same olive oil. The salad was also inedible. The staff didn't even say anything or ask any questions when they took the plate away even though we hardly touched the salad. I ordered osso bucco which was served on top of risotto. My first bite was the risotto which was, without question, the saltiest thing I have ever been served in a restaurant. Completely inedible (unless, of course, I wanted to have a stroke right there in the restaurant). The veal tasted off, it had the taste it develops if it sits in the refrigerator too long. I was really looking forward to the bone marrow, but that too tasted off, the way it gets if it turns grey in the refrigerator.  One other gripe while we are at it. I really wish they would ditch that film they project onto one wall, it is really distracting if you are seated near it, which we were.
author: Lee D.

description: Great little restaurant in an excellent location. It's small and intimate serving probably the BEST lasagna I've had anywhere EVER!!!  The pasta is fresh and cooked to perfection.  Also, the fresh warm bread and arugula pesto when you first arrive are winners as well!
author: Stephanie W.

description: This is definitely a hidden gem!  And I am not an easy person to please.  :-) I love the home made pasta and atmosphere here!  I used to dine here all the time until I moved to the east bay.  However your name is always mentioned among anyone whom I carry a conversation about pasta. :-). Service and food are always consistent here which is the reason I kept coming back!  Come open one in the east bay so I don't have to miss you so much! :-)
author: Kelly L.

description: Wow! This place is fantastic! The mac n cheese was sooooo good. We didn't expect that. The entrees were very good as well. If you're in the Castro and craving some authentic Italian then this is it! It is a bit pricey though. Also, their mojitos are INCREDIBLE!
author: Alyssa L.

description:
Poor service,  really BAD service. The waiter never came over and let us know that our meal would be out soon or that it was taking a while... something would have been nice. 

We waited a while for our apitisers, and then another 20ish minutes before I had to flag down the waiter and ask him what was taking so long with our main course. He went into the kitchen and returned with, your meal will be here in 3 minutes. So I watch the clock, almost 7 minutes later... here came our main course. Sea Bass and Goncci... that's it, nothing special. And that took over 30 minutes. Meanwhile, I had to ask the waiter to refill my iced tea (that should have been a giving, without asking).

The food tasted good, no issues until we where ready to leave. Nobody ever brought my take home box back to the table. When I asked, it could not be found. 

Oh well, this was our 6th time eating here and usually not a bad experience, but last night was a complete failure.
author: D L.

description:
Stu S. already hit all of the right descriptors in his review a few months back. Charming. Tiny. Upscale. Italian.

Delicious tapas. Reasonable happy hour. Delicious, like REALLY delicious cocktails. Definitely a cute place for a grownup to grab a cocktail with a co-worker at 5:30pm.

I'd recommend sitting at the bar. It seemed to be the only place that wasn't a bit cramped for space. And as a 6'6 dude, that means something to me.
author: Sean B.

description:
Wanted 4-5 nucies ( I have no idea how to spell that) the manager said no. I wanted to talk to him and find myself under attack, he kept on talking and tried to shut me up. couldn't speak or reply. Will never come again to this place. 
This is not a way to treat customers.
author: Avi J.

description: Horribly slow service. I will not return. 10 minutes my wine glass sat empty and nobody asked about it.
author: V M.

description:
Owner Francesco personally seated us by the front window...great restaurant! Best veal osso buco I have ever had. It should be on the menu always, not just for a special! The only other time it was this good was when I was in Italy! 
The video on the website is very compelling. So glad we went!
http://poesiasf.com/about/
author: Callie C.

description: Very good Italian restaurant, with a very good wine list.  Both the appetizer plates of tagliere salumi e formagggi and crostini di carciofi were excellent and of a decent size.  If one arrives very early , there is a "happy hour," with very low priced cocktails.  They had an interesting beef ragu lasagna, which was very filling.  Did not have desert, as all that was availble had chocolate in it. Suggest eating early, as at normal dinner times, the crowd is *very* noisy.
author: robert l.

description:
We did not get dinner here, so I can't give it 5 stars, but we went in for dessert and wished we'd come for dinner. 

We got salted truffle something or other, and it rocked. Followed by one impressive cappuccino. 

Best thing this place has going for it is the atmosphere. They place old Italian movies on the wall, and it's in the top story of an old house, so it is ADORABLE, cozy, and romantic. Our server was incredibly friendly and helpful and down right entertaining, the food that was coming out around us to other tables looked incredible. I'll definitely go for dinner next time I'm in SF.
author: Adrienne S.

description: Love this restaurant. The food is scrumptious, the atmosphere is darling romantic, and the service is really friendly. Try the carpaccio. I've been craving it since I had it. It's a perfect date night but it's nice with a small group of friends, too! I can't wait to go back!
author: Kat R.

description:
Food is 4 stars, service is 2.

We had a 7:30 reservation. Seated at 8 and order taken at 8:30. Had to ask for bread, which was stale.

Some dishes came over salted (squid ink pasta and special holiday entree), but tomato pasta dishes were delicious.
author: Rita C.

description:
This is a lovely 2nd floor restaurant in the heart of the Castro. Full of charm esp with the Italian waitstaff who were very friendly. I've been here twice and have to say they do some things great and some things that need improvement. I hope the management reads this as constructive criticism to help them improve, because I think they have potential for being a great restaurant and want them to stay in the neighborhood.

Pros
Caprese Con Burrata - the Burrata was soft and delicious. The whole dish came together with the good quality olive oil, kalamata olives and the heirloom tomatoes. It helps that the heirlooms are in season. 

Fettuccine al Regu Di Agnello - Delicious, well balanced sauce with fresh pasta.

Branzino Alla Cartoccio - Only Italians and Chinese can appreciate eating a whole fish. Ha. My dining partner didn't like having eyes staring back at him. I thought the presentation was nice and the fish tasty and tender

The complimentary bread was tasty and warm. Served with olive oil and balsamic.

Cons:
Pollo Arrosto - Half roasted chicken served with lemon and thyme sauce and a side of soft polenta. The polenta was creamy and tasty, but the chicken was awful. After reading the description, I was expecting a chicken with crispy skin infused with thyme flavor; instead, I got a ugly dark green chicken that was dry and tough. Seems like they coated the chicken with a wet herbal coating and roasted it... way too long.

Wine - The pour here is stingy. A few sips and it was gone. Not cool to charge full price for a little bit of wine. We decided to order a bottle instead of more glasses.
author: Robert C.

description:
Whenever I get house / home made pasta that's deliciously prepared, I yelp it out!  

We were a party of 12, so we got to try many items on the menu.  All of it was good.  Servicing sizes are not American style pile-on but Italian style for smaller palates. 

One of the hallmarks of truly Italian food:  Not super rich American style desserts.  

This restaurant reminded me of an Italian trattoria rather than a ristorante.

The difference for those interested:
http://www.fourbrotherscucina.com/italian-eateries-ristorante-trattoria-and-the-osteria/

In short, this place is a little bit of Italy in the heart of the Castro, which is not known for fine dining.  So, we are so glad this restaurant exists.  It's fresh pasta is comparable to any we've had at neighboring Farina, Delfina, Locanda, SPQR, A16, etc.  Truly a gem to cherish!
author: W G.

description:
Poesia is a hidden gem in the Castro. The ambiance is lovely--intimate and romantic. The lighting is great and I love the old school films they play on the wall. Their happy hour offers 2 cocktails for $10--and they're fancy-ass cocktails. 

The food is absolutely wonderful--rich and perfectly portioned. Every server I've ever had has been warm and welcoming as well as attentive.

Tip: If you're worried about getting a table, book on OpenTable to guarantee a spot.

Wheelchair accessibility notes: Sadly, this is very wheelchair unfriendly since you have to get up a steep flight of maybe 10 stairs just to get to get to the front door. Tables are also rather close together inside. Single person bathroom. Street parking only.
author: Tricia R.

description:
Fantastic service, great location and delicious food! My friends and I enjoyed the special sea bass baked in parchment paper, the vegetarian home made beet & ricotta ravioli's and the pork pasta. I didn't try the pork myself, but the other two dishes were the best I've had in a while. My friends said the meat dish was also delicious. 

There was a large party of about 30 people seated before us, but the service did not suffer, and the noise was moderate.

We ended the the meal with the tiramisu & the coconut Panama cotta with blue berry compot. The tiramisu was good, but I'd make a special trip back just to enjoy the pans cotta. Wow!! That was delicious!

Before we left I spoke with the bartender who informed me that they have a daily happy hour menu. The menu looked great.

I've found another gem in the Castro!
author: Danusia F.

description:
We spent a lovely evening out to dinner at this restaurant. The service was very good. The cocktails were delicious and clearly carefully crafted and well-balanced.

The ambience is as described in other reviews. It has the feeling of what it is: a floor of a converted Victorian home. It has a lovely neighborhood vibe.

The food was good with some delicious standouts. In particular the chocolate mousse dessert was great, with olive oil and cayenne pepper.
author: Ghengis G.

description:
Three times in the past month or so. Damn, so hard to try new places in the Castro when there's just a great place you can always go to. 

Came here the first time with a friend and her bf. Got to try the tomato bread soup ( Pappa Al Pomodoro) - wasn't bad, but not great either. Kind of tasted like tomato bisque, but maybe not for everyone. I ended up ordering the pasta with pork ribs sugo (Fileji di Renato). Definitely really delicious. Small plate though so made me a bit sad that I couldn't try any the next day. Most of the time pasta sauce is better after you let it sit for a while. 

We also ordered 2 desserts - they had only heard one of them, so we only got that dessert until we asked about it. No apologies for the mistake - only a little bit of blame on us. Regardless, we got the dark chocolate mousse (spuma di cioccolato) which was good except the sea salt grains were definitely a bit too large for the flavor they were trying to go for. Some of the bites were definitely too salty for a dessert. The other dessert - tiramisu - was delicious though. 

Came again on a Friday for happy hour. Happy hour ends at 6:30 rather than at 7 which is what my friend thought it was. They still gave us happy hour pricing - thanks! - since we were like a minute late. I ordered the Seduced and Abandoned - which was yummy! We also ordered the buratta with prosciutto and asparagus (burrata con prosciutto staginato e asparagi). Delicious. I'm glad that they also give us bread because the three together on some bread is so delicious. 

Third time here, on a date, Friday night. The dining table was packed We started with the ricotta gnocchi (gnocchi di ricotta con pomodorini). It was light and fluffy with a delicious sauce. Definitely one of those things you should get as an appetizer - super delicious. We ended up ordering the ravioli special and the fettuccine with lamb ragu (fettuccine al ragu' di agnello). Both of which are delicious. The special was definitely good, but I definitely enjoyed the lamb ragu more. 

Overall, this location has really good Italian food. Service is pretty decent, but not the best. So come here knowing that. 

Protip: get the gnocchi and the tiramisu. Both really good dishes. Service can be spotty when it's busy, but it isn't horrible.
author: Nina Y.

description: Nice service and a cute atmosphere, but it took over an hour for our entrees to come, bread was mushy and not very good, the vegetarian pasta was very bland with plain boiled potatoes and beans (not worth $20), and everything needed salt. It was a fairly underwhelming experience and not what we had hoped for.
author: Anissa I.

description: Came here from out of town on a strong recommendation and it definitely lived up to the hype. Service was amazing, although the wait time was not. The food explained the wait - incredible! I had the most amazing lasagna ever. My boyfriend had a dish with mussels or something. He loved it too. I was especially appreciative of the amazing wine selection. I'll be back.
author: Joshua N.

description:
Have i not reviewed this yet?
I true neighborhood gem.  Authentic.  Homey.  Friendly.  Great Negronis.
Don't miss Sunday lasagna night.
author: Troy B.

description:
Just like walking into Grandma's house. Everything, and I say everything, is home made. From the linguini to the mousse to the chocolate liqueur at the end...you can truly taste the love and quality in each bite. 

We ordered the carpaccio served on a bed of arugula and olives as appetizers. For our entrees we got the lamb linguini and ravioli. and as dessert we got their famous chocolate mousse as the bartender served their chocolate liqueur (might I say..aphrodisiac galore). Their mousse takes 4 hours to make. sprinkled with sea salt on top of olive oil..truly a work of art. BUENISMO!
author: Jocelyn C.

description:
Don't buy the hype.

The burrata was horrible. Italy would've been ashamed. It took an hour and a half, after we arrived for dinner, to get our entrees. My pasta was a disappointing heap of dry and flavorless pasta with Romanesco broccoli and olives. Inedible. We left our entrees untouched, paid, and ran across the street to grab a slice of pizza. 

Btw, when we asked for the check, our waitress looked offended, notified the manager, and he soon made his way to our table to ask what was wrong with our entrees. We politely explained. He mumbled out a half-ass apology and walked away briskly. Gross food, slow service, rude manager. To top things off, I got an email shortly after leaving, from Open Table, notifying me that our reservation had been canceled. What a passive aggressive and pathetic move by the manager. Who does that?

Save your cash.

Go to Locanda, Delfina, or Lupa Trattoria instead. You'll get good service, and leave with a happy tummy.
author: Gabriela W.

description:
The service was good, the food was "hit and miss" with precious few dishes hitting the Yum zone and the others the BICKY ( bad - icky ) zone. 18th & Castro once again proving itself a better intersection for the cruising crowd than the educated palate. Sitting in a window table with an uninterrupted view of the Midnight Sun, providing free entertainment of the comings and goings of the Castro bar dwellers. Mr. Server (with his multitude of bangle bracelets) was good, The food @ Poesia: 

Bread and olive oil & balsamic vinegar - GOOD freshish Italianesque bread, ok/average olive oil & vinegar

Carpaccio - GREAT: 3 Mini towers of carpaccio wrapped around greens with erect enoki mushrooms spouting out of the top, a culinary construction in deference to the locale ? 

Dandelion greens - BICKY (see above): overcooked - mushy with less flavor than a boiled stick. Shoulda sent it back but didn't want an Italian retribution appearing in subsequent dishes 

Fried Calamari: OK: mostly a salad mound with a few (maybe 6) smallish pieces of calamari. This was a surprise since many pic's of this dish show a mound of Calamari.

Filet Mignon - GOOD: Tasty & properly cooked medium rare, sliced with plenty of the omnipresent small greens

Lamb shank pasta - OK: Pasta properly cooked, meat was shredded on top. Wondered where the other 80% of the shank was. Tasty but skimpy. Maybe this lamb shank was from a very, very skinny lamb

Fish (Branzino?) cooked in parchment - BICKY: Overcooked - mushy, it was obvious that the parchment was more a gimmick than integral to how the fish was cooked. It was deboned which helped with picking the mushy meat. 

Desert: GOOD - : Ice cream w/ a shot of espresso, with the serving embellishment of having the espresso poured on the ice cream at our table. 

TL;DR:

The environment is a Victorian or Edwardian house converted to its present restaurant scheme. Its vibe is (as many have) described is homey. While "homey", the only resemblance to its architectural heritage is the peaked ceiling. Any other recognizable interior que of the buildings heritage was erased with sheet rock decades ago. Its kind of like the guy who fills in his lawn area with cement and paints it green. A "chandelier" near our table, appearing to be a hand moulded creation that looked as if it was made out of reddish playdough by someone with too much contact with lead. Maybe the dough part is meant to carry forward the Poetic culinary theme? It takes more than Italian names for dishes to make them delicious. The cocktail attraction & promotion & deals certainly contribute to the Positive Poesia experience for many of LOCAL Castro fawning fans. Bartenders are a natural FAV in this neighborhood. I would guess this joint in its current incarnation won't draw many folks that would seek out a solid Italian food joints beyond the intersection of "18th & Castro" such as: 

Bacco: http://www.yelp.com/biz/bacco-san-francisco

Manzoni (name has that Castro appeal) http://www.yelp.com/biz/manzoni-san-francisco-2

Zero Zero: (farther afield a solid and vibrant joint) http://www.yelp.com/biz/zero-zero-san-francisco
author: Matsuo U.

description:
Given the amazing Yelp reviews and the strong Trip Advisor rating, I expected a really great meal.  While I can see why the ambience is romantic, and the black and white film projected on the wall along with some cute picture frames are a nice homey touch, the food was really not that great.   I would give it 3 stars for OK.  

We got there in time for the happy hour, and my friend ordered the Juliet  of the Spirits and I ordered the Swept Away.   We also got the tomato bread soup.  It was okay, but not quite what I expected (I'm pretty sure there's cheese in it as well). 

For our entrees, we ordered the branzino in parchment paper with lemon, which tasted quite fishy, somewhat bland despite the lemon slices, and a bit too mushy.   I couldn't finish more than 1/3 of it.  We also ordered a half order of the fettucine with shredded lamb shank ragu and a full order of the tagliolini with black olives, broccoli romanesco and sweet tomatoes.  In both cases, the pasta itself was tasteless and slightly overcooked, while the additional ingredients were decent and tasty.  We thought the meal was okay but definitely not particularly good, and generally somewhat surprising given the fantastic reviews.  

Service was excellent and again the ambience is cozy and intimate.
author: Vivian W.

description: Sweet restaurant upstairs from the street. The food was delicious -- the cauliflower is comforting and cheesy, like mac and cheese, only with cauliflower. Kale caesar was perfect, including anchovies! Mushroom polenta had a great taste. My friends raved about their pasta with pieces of steak. We had a very enjoyable meal at the bar where the bartender was super friendly.
author: Peggy S.

description: This is the most charming little restaurant in the Castro. The food is fantastic.  The staff are wonderful and the atmosphere is of the best!
author: Gary M.

description:
Intimate, warm space with silent movies projected on the wall. 

Long haired Italian speaking waiters. 

Tasty cocktails with even more tastier Italian food. 

Welcome to Poesia.

Start off your evening with a Negroni sbagliato while you whet your appetite with their creamy burrata.  Several pastas are available gluten free and as any true self-respecting Italian would have it, they're all hand-made. Try the half moon shaped squid ink ravioli stuffed with dungeness crab. This is paired with a bright lemony-olive oil based sauce that was so simple and yet flavorful! how do they do that?! DIVINE. 
The bf's tagliata di filetto were perfectly medium rare accompanied by sweet potato puree and broccoli rabe. 

Highly recommended for an authentic Italian dinner in the Castro.  Buon appetito!
author: Janice C.

description: Lovely find in the Castro. We had the artichoke crostini, pork ragu and the special of the day (risotto with Calabrese sausage and chanterelles). Dessert was coconut pana cotta, espresso and Americano. The service was just perfect, the drinks were great, and the food was amazing. The ambiance is intimate and romantic; not too loud even when full. I will definitely be back.
author: Claudia G.

description: Eggplant wrap with ricotta was sublime. The service was very attentive and the food was good.
author: George S.

description:
This is such a cute upscale restaurant next to one of my favorite coffee shops. The waiters are very professional and attentive. I love the whole classy atmosphere. Aside from the fact that I could not understand the majority of the words of the menu, my friend and I ordered a few items to satisfy our Italian craving.

----------------------

* The salad with sardines, romaine lettuce, and parmesan cheese was delicious... the perfect combination of different flavors between the sardines and dressing.

* Fregola Sarda Con Frutti Di Mare E 'Nduja ($17) - Semolina pasta with 'nduja sausage, calamari, prawns, and white wine sauce. Just the right level of spiciness. The calamari was excellently cooked but the prawns were a little overcooked and dry. Nevertheless I enjoyed this dish very much.

* Fileji Di Renato ($16) - Calabrese spiral pasta with pork ribs sugo in roasted garlic tomato sauce. Also very delicious  the perfect mix of textures between the pasta and pork.

----------------------

I really have nothing else to say other than this place has excellent service, excellent cuisine, and very "interesting" videos projected onto the wall. Okay, free entertainment.
author: Stefanie C.

description: Love this place!   Have been there twice in one week and LOVED my meal, and especially loved the service from Chris and the crew.   Every bite is wonderful, each sip of wine is great.   Had this short rib pasta dish which was killer.  This is a neighborhood gem and i can't wait until the next time I go back.
author: Scott H.

description:
My roommate had this bookmarked on her Yelp page for a long time.  We were in the area, and decided to check out the menu.  We had eaten earlier, and weren't hungry.  We just wanted to see what Poesia had to offer.  Little did we know we barely made it for happy hour.  The host was so welcoming, so we decided to stay.

We ordered the "rustico" and the "pappa al pomodoro."  The rustico is a puff pastry filled with tomato sauce, mozzarella, and parmesan cheese.  The pappa al pomodoro is tomato bread soup.  The puff pastry was a bit burnt, but so delicious! It was especially good with the soup.  I would order the soup again because the tomatoes were bursting with flavor and the bread went well with the overall texture of the soup.

We also ordered drinks.  I got the Juliet of the Spirits that had vodka, St. Germain, lavender syrup, and tiny pieces of lavender on top.  My roommate ordered La Dolce Vita which had bourbon (her favorite), Di Saronno, and citrus juice.  Mine was so aromatic and sweet.  I can't say much about hers.  I did try it, but I'm not a bourbon fan.  I will say that she really enjoyed hers.

The bartender who served us was really friendly.  And the host checked in on us, and again, so welcoming.

The decor is really romantic, especially with the black and white movies playing against the back wall.  I felt like I was back in Italy again with the good food, friendly staff, and energetic atmosphere.
author: Vira P.

description: Nicer quality food for the Castro.  Small cute restaurant in a great location.  Waitress was friendly and overall a pleasant experience.
author: Jack T.

description:
We came here for dinner based on a unanimously strong review on check please Bay Area. It was a good restaurant but not worth going out of your way for and didn't didn't live up to the raving reviews. 

Appetizer: 
we had a crostini with mozzarella cheese, olives and salami. This was a tasty dish (super fresh and best olives I have ever had) but better suited for an afternoon snack than a starter for dinner.

Mains:
1. Salted cod ravioli - 2 stars. Too strong on the spice and salt. Didn't seem like a balanced dish in term so of floors. 

2 Seabass: wow, super light, fresh and tasty leveraging natural flavors rather than through additives. However, felt like a dish that is better suited for an afternoon day at the beach lunch. Can't go wrong ordering none the less - 5 stars for a lunch dish. 

Dessert:
1. Tiramisu: 3 stars. Good solid tiramisu but nothing special 

Drinks:
Got 2 cocktails - nothing special. Can't recommend it
Tawny Port - 4 stars. Highly recommend.
author: Kem K.

description: Absolutely amazing little spot! The food was superb, the drinks were amazing. Most of all, Pietro was the best server. We will absolutely be back!
author: Tyler K.

description:
The ragu was pretty damn good. The sauce especially would compare favorably vs.  most good pastas you could get in a city with a better Italian food reputation.

The Pasta Nera was awful. Shame on me for ordering squid ink delivery pasta, but for the price you'd expect better than a foil ball filled with doughy, hyper-salty pasta and rubbery seafood. I eat too much seafood. Fishier-smelling, slightly past seafood normally doesn't bother me, but this dish was impossibly stinky.
author: Jeremy S.

description: Loved this place! Please do yourselves a favor and walk up the stairs to this gem. Unfortunately, we only had drinks and an appetizer (delish). We couldn't get a reservation. We sat at the bar and had Teddy make our drinks and chat us up. Good guy. We will return.
author: Robin A.

description: Super cute Italian restaurant in the Castro! Great service and the food is phenomenal.
author: Katarina D.

description:
I was not impressed by this restaurant at all.

The ambiance is just not right, the food is very simple and seriously I can do better at home. If I'm going out for Italian, I'm expecting more than just a simple plain tomato sauce.

Service was also OK, but again nothing special.
author: Maggie J.

description:
Che romantico.  Of course my young amante added to the seductive ambiance of a lovely Christmas Eve late dinner at this smart and sophisticated osteria Italiano. Ha!  

A lot of charm here. The no fuss man in charge found us a table (no reservation) and the food is really good.  Burrata with charcuterie: heaven; lamb shank fettucine: yum; filet mignon and arugula salad: so nice.  Service attentive.  Ambiance very comfortable.  

When in the Castro with your main squeeze ...
author: Tim F.

description:
Sitting here now after waiting a half hour after our reservation time. Another half hour and they haven't taken our order. The words pretentious and affected come to mind. Limited menu and beverages. Noise level is outrageous and after two repeatings of the special, we have no idea what it is.

Calamari Alla Griglia is a wonderful surprise. Warm and grilled over arugula 

Appetizers done and they still haven't taken our order. Now over an our past our reservations. And now we wait...

The heat in this small dining room is akin to a sauna. Making the long wait for food all the more unbearable.  I went outside for air for about five minutes. Still no food. It's now 1.5 hours after our reservation.

Almost two hours. We're ready to start eating the olives at the bar. NO ONE has apologized or are even acting like this is unusual. I'm calling this one star before the meals even come.  IF they ever come.

Oh goody. Almost two hours and an eggplant parmigiana with grease separating on the sides. One layer of paper thin, greasy eggplant with a slight burnt taste. VERY disappointing.

We are done in 5 minutes as we're all starved. No way we're waiting another hour for dessert. Nope, we all voted on leaving this sweat box and grabbing dessert down the street. Good riddance.
author: Les T.

description: I hated the food. very dry and not a good taste. The waiter charged us 3 drinks from another group. he messed up on the bill twice....and i still think he charged us one more item wrong. i have tried better and cheaper Italian food. To expensive and not good.
author: Walter A.

description:
I dined at Poesia for the first time on Saturday night with a small group of friends. We were celebrating my friend Jon's birthday.

The food was very delicious. For antipasti, we shared the bruschetta and the grilled calamari. For my secondo I had the ravioli di carne magra con funghi--ravioli stuffed with diced filet mignon and fresh mozzarella; served with portobello mushrooms and a garlic, white wine and Italian parsley sauce. I also tried a couple bites of my friend's squid ink pasta with fresh Dungeness crab. Yum!

The Swept Away cocktail (Prosecco and Campari) was refreshing. And since the next item on the birthday agenda was bar hopping in the Castro, a couple of my friends and I decided to skip dessert and concluded our meal with some grappa instead. I had never tried grappa before then. It was pretty intense.

Overall, my friends and I really enjoyed our dinner at Poesia. The restaurant is fairly small and had a cozy ambiance. The service was excellent. I highly recommend this restaurant to anyone who loves Italian cuisine. It's perfect for a romantic date or celebrating a special occasion.
author: Dustin F.

description:
Very good beet salad.  I could hardly eat my entree fettucine  w/leg of lamb.  Very slow service.  It took 45 minutes to get our salads.
Had eaten there before and found it to be fine.  It had been years and they have really gone downhill.
Expensive for what you get!!
author: Robert K.

description:
The food and drinks were solid. They were very busy and it didn't appear they had enough servers to deal with their capacity. It was Friday prime time, though. Nice atmosphere, it felt like home inside. 

Overall, a good experience. I might come back on another night of the week to check it out.
author: Andrew J.

description: We had gone here a few years back for our anniversary and it was perfect very cozy warm and friendly place. The food was divine and the service was amazing i have such an awesome memory of a lovely evening spent here absolutely lovely...
author: Dwiti V.

description:
We were really looking forward to trying this place. The staff is friendly and the service very attentive. However, the food was okay. We ordered the mussels with chorizo and really didn't taste the chorizo. The grilled calamari a little too overcooked and oily.

Overall the place was good but perhaps not enough for us to trek across town for.
author: Mimi T.

description:
Servers here are all really nice and take great care of you while dining. They seated us nearby the window and we enjoyed dinner with a glass of wine. The Victorian home turned restaurant is very cozy and had a very homey feel. Especially when our table was lit up by the Christmas tree right outside of our window. 

I had the pappardelle special with Parmesan, tomatoes with speck. I'd rate it about a 4 - perhaps even a 3.5. It wasn't too heavy and portions were just right. Flavors were good enough but nothing extraordinary. 

For dessert we had the much raved about chocolate mousse with sea salt, cayenne peppers and Olive oil. It was fine for me but I immediately wished we went with the servers suggestion of ordering the profiteroles made fresh in-house. I wish the menu had explained it was just two balls of the mousse. Had I known, I probably wouldn't have ordered it. 

I'd probably rate them a 3 star but had to up one due to the friendly service we received. Service certainly can make/break your overall dining experience.
author: Esther A.

description:
Was a group of 4 business dinner and an opportunity to celebrate one of our partners birthday.  Alex was our server and was most accommodating and served up an after dinner dessert equipped with a birthday candle.  The pork and lamb dishes over pasta (with GF options available) were all well received by the group.  Wine prices were very fair.

Videos of old B&W films projected on the back wall was fun.
author: JP S.

description: Average Italian food. The basil on the flatbread tasted outright bitter. The ravioli looked good on the menu; the sauce had no flavor except olive oil. Lots of it.
author: V S.

description:
Really a wonderful dining experience. It's a small place, but well worth any wait. The staff was fantastic and I thought the overall service was friendly and attentive. 
I had the calamari appetizer, which is completely different than any I'd ever had - fantastic! I had the Tagliata di Filetto di Manzo as my main course, and it was simply the best filet I have EVER had. Enough said - except the views out their windows are also entertaining and keep the conversation lively!
author: Dan P.

description:
I just had one of the best trout dishes I have EVER eaten.  It was almond crusted.  Crispy and perfectly seasoned on the outside.  Moist and tender inside.  Phenomenal!

The side of rainbow chard with white onions was a brilliant accompaniment.

Another six star meal at Poesia...
author: Kenneth T.

description: This place is so cute and the food is great! Came here for my birthday with some girlfriends few years ago. Bartender was very nice and gave us some great drink recommendations. It also would be a great date spot. It's on the small and cozy side.
author: Nawal W.

description:
We saw this on Check Please! and wanted to try it out. We were expecting for the owner to say hello to us as we entered (as they indicated on the show).. no such luck. 

It was also a warm evening in San Francisco and so it was warm in the restaurant (no AC in most SF places). So evening started out disappointing. 

But once we cooled down and looked around we started enjoying our surrounding. Loved the movie projected onto the screen (a Fellini!) Our server was super nice and efficient. We started the Ellis Island, their version of a martini.. so so yum! For appetizer ordered the Pappa al Pomodoro (tomato soup) which was very good. And the Sardine alla Graticola. WOWZER I really really really really loved the sardine!! For main dish I had the Orecchiette alla Calabrese pasta with sausage, which I really liked and had a spicy kick to it. My partner had the pink ravioli Tortelli di Barbabietolla.. he liked it fine. Dessert was Tiramisu (OK) and Spuma di Ciccolato (interesting but just ok). 

We really enjoyed Poesia. We'll definitely be taking friends or out of town visitors there.. it has a special atmosphere.
author: Vol T.

description:
What a find. Sat at the one table on the balcony. Four delicious appetizers: dandelion greens, mussels, dates wrapped in bacon and pomodoro salad.

Other than the tomatoes that aren't quite there yet it was a perfect meal. The service was excellent as were the drinks. We will be back for the made in house pasta.
author: Victor P.

description:
3.4 stars

Service:  5 stars

Ambience:  4 stars 

Food:  3 stars

The highlights for us were the very friendly and attentive staff, the creative menu, and the warm, intimate setting.  As a nicely added touch, old Italian movies were projected on the wall.  

The food didn't quite live up to our expectations.  From so many positive reviews about the salad with grilled calamari.  The salad lacked dressing and the calamari was under flavored.  We also had the beet salad and it was quite good (the beets were sweet and the goat cheese was very flavorful).

For entrees, I had the squid ink pappardelle with crab.  The pasta was cooked nicely (al dente) but the flavor of the dish was too mild for my liking.  The tiny crab flakes that were sprinkled on the pasta added some flavor but were so sparse that I felt like I was eating pasta on its own.

My wife had the rack of lamb.  She said it was dry and lacking in flavor.

The great service makes me want to rate this place higher, but the weak delivery on the food makes it hard to justify 4 stars.
author: Lee K.

description: I love this place. I would probably come here every day if they served a fresh pasta with a simple puttanesca sauce or arrabiatta I would come here every day. Too much pork sugo or lamb sugo & not knowing how much--I ordered the special: Linguini with crab,cherry tomatoes & garlic. Yeah it was yesterday's crab, but the linguine was sooo good. After I mentioned that I wish the chef would offer simple pasta with a simple but tasty tomato base, she told next time just ask! The lovely people, delicious food & cocktails, and the 1950s/60s  movies projected all the wall makes Poesia an affordable trip to Italia. Grazie Mille!
author: Connie C.

description:
Overall a nice place, cozily seated on the 2nd floor of what probably used to be a house. With the black & white Italian movie playing in the background, a fantastically friendly waiter (from reading previous Yelp reviews, seems like they are trying to make up for past experiences), and a $60 three course dinner + wine deal for two from LivingSocial, we had a really nice little date. Not outstanding enough to necessarily come back considering the endless restaurants in SF we haven't tried yet, but nice enough to recommend it for a decently romantic spot.

MUST-HAVE: Fettuccine al Ragu

~~ANTIPASTI~~
* Gnocchi Silani - 3.5 stars
(Ricotta Cheese Gnocchi, Citrus Sauce, Pachino Tomatoes. $10)
Very chew, soft, well made gnocchi. The citrus sauce was a tiny bit strong, and that in combination withe tangy juice from the tomatoes made the dish less savory and more sour. The slices of tomatoes themselves were fantastic, perfectly ripe, almost sweet.

* Tortino di Baccala di Nonna MariaRosa - 3.5 stars
(Salted Cod cake baked in the oven with potato puree. $11)
Nicely done. The cod had great texture, as did the potato puree. A little bland flavor-wise though.

~~PASTA~~
* Fettuccine al Ragu d'Agnello - 4 stars
(Lamb Shank  Ragu', Tomato Sauce. $16)
The house made fettuccine was really great. FYI it is thicker (though also variable, so you can tell it's made in house) and on the al dente side. The sauce had a nice tangy flavor that balanced well with the gamey flavor of the lamb. Speaking of the lamb, it was tender and tasty. 

* Pollo alla Griglia con Salsa Piccante - 4 stars
(Free Range Half Chicken, Lemon & Peperoncino Calabrese Sauce, Broccoli di Ciccio, Roasted Potatoes. $19)
While the chicken was a tiny bit on the dry side, it was flavored so well with many spices and herbs that made it smell (and taste) delicious. It had a great crispy skin as well. The potato was really good, also with a nice crisp and well flavored, and the greens were slightly bitter which balanced everything else out really well.

~~DOLCI~~ 
* Zabaione al Marsala con Sbrisolona e Gelato - 2 stars
(Light Marsala wine custard with Almond short dough and Chocolate Gelato. $8)
Very disappointing (we should've listened to our waiter who was kind of pushing for the other dessert). The custard had too strong of a coffee flavor, even for my boyfriend the coffee lover. The almond dough were incredibly hard and not fun to chew or try to break apart.

* Spuma di Cioccolata - 3.5 stars
(Dark Chocolate mousse, Sea Salt, Extra Virgin Olive Oil, Chile Powder. $8)
The dark chocolate was really nice. You have to balance out each bite to get the right amount of salt, olive oil, and chile to get the flavor right. It's just missing some variation in texture - you really only get the soft texture of the chocolate.
author: Ziyan C.

description: Please, do not give these people your money. Between being insulted for not having a reservation  (they sat us immediately) and the waitresses rude attitude, one of the worst SF experiences I've ever had. I watched my friend tell the waitress he was Vegan *she said, yes I get this alot* and then brought his dish out with cheese. Not a big deal, but then she proceeded to lecture him about how the dish had cheese after I witnessed her PROMISE him there would be NO CHEESE. It was really embarrassing for him and we specifically asked them if they could accommodate him. It was like she was trying to shame him in front of all of the other patrons. Not cool. We made his dietary restrictions clear to her from the get go. If they couldn't handle it we would have gone somewhere else!
author: Kayla C.

description:
Food is fine but nothing special, service was OK (though they only apparently had 1 waiter working at dinner time, which made things slow).

My main reason for giving three stars is the environment -- the floor shakes every time someone walks by briskly, which happens frequently since there is only one waiter rushing around the place. The movie being projected on the wall seems more tacky than classy, and it's VERY distracting as there are suddenly bright flashes when the scenes change or the movie ends. The chairs are also very uncomfortable for anyone with broad shoulders.

Perhaps I just had a bad seat, but I found myself very distracted and constantly trying to get the waiter's attention.

I can see this place being popular for those in the neighborhood, but there's no reason to come here for Italian food if you're visiting the city or live elsewhere in SF.
author: Scott H.

description: Service was terrible, food was worse, and not much more to say than that.  It was so bad, we left the entrees after two bites and grabbed a slice at the pizza place across the street.  Save your money and go almost anywhere else, like Lupa Trattoria, Locanda, or even fuckin' Olive Garden.  What a bust.
author: Saminda W.

description:
Just what kind of Italian restaurant screws up a bruschetta? An Italian restaurant in the Castro, I guess. It sounded good when the waitress described it, and it looked good when it arrived (see photo). But when I put one in my mouth, it was like a wedge of balsa wood. I really thought I would break a tooth because I kept gnawing at it like a hamster on meth. The mushroom and parmesan topping was fine, but what a disastrous start to a dinner I was having with Jamie W. and my friend Carlos and his partner whose name coincidentally was also Jamie W. 

The rest of the meal went without a hitch, though I didn't find anything I had that extraordinary. I think Carlos made the best choice, the $15 Orecchiette al Forno, which came mixed in provolone, walnuts and warmed radicchio, but the portion was on the stingy side. My Jamie W. ordered the $17 Fettuccine al Ragu', which sounded tempting since it came in a tomato sauce with slow-braised lamb shank (see photo). It was tasty enough but not terribly tantalizing. Mine was better, the $18 Ravioli al Granchio, about five reasonably-sized rounds stuffed with an unlikely mix of crab meat and smoked Pancetta and covered in a brandy sauce (see photo). 

Our starter was a simple $9 Insalata di Barbabietol, which combined diced golden and red beets with radish and goat cheese (see photo). Good, sweet and rather predictable. I was worried the place would be cramped since it is in what looks to be the parlor of a converted Victorian. But it wasn't that bad. Relatively low-key considering all the tables were full up. The service was attentive, but I have to admit that inedible baguette at the beginning really haunted my whole meal. After all, I could have gotten a fresher bun for my burger at Slider's for half the price. 

FOOD - 3 stars...reasonable though not stand-out, need to ding them for the stale baguette used for the bruschetta 
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...busy but cozy enough...and such a huge restroom that I wanted to eat in there 
SERVICE - 4 stars...no complaints on this front 
TOTAL - 3 stars...that damn bruschetta!
author: Ed U.

description:
Really cute place. 
My partner and I went here for date night a few weeks back. The place was recommended by a friend. The service was really good and we were greeted when we walked in. We ordered a few glasses of wine, which were really good. Both of our starter plates were perfect! However the main courses were just okay and very small portions. I had ravioli which only had 5 on the plate and they were not super big. And the dessert selection was very mediocre. In fact we ended up order nothing for dessert because nothing sounded that appetizing. All in all it was a good experience. Probably not a place I would goto again.
author: Charles B.

description: Ridiculously loud restaurant, the volume coming from drunk diners at tables nearby was unbearable.  High prices for very mediocre food, my fish was very poorly prepared.  Staff uninterested in hearing the complaint, they just brought the bill.  There are far better places nearby to try with great food and attentive service.
author: John R.

description:
GREAT meal - baratta, veal shank pasta, filet, beet pasta and chicken.  Desserts were tiramisu and canolli.  Nice wine by the glass options and well
made cocktails - cannot wait to go back! Service was equally wonderful - thanks for a wonderful night out!
author: Marie C.

description:
FYI - For those who have yet to try Poesia, now's your chance with this Bloomspot deal!! :) http://bit.ly/16iNu1H - You're welcome. 

Came here again recently for my dad's birthday and I had yet another great experience. Made my reservations through savored.com for 30% off the total bill made the meal that much more delicious! However, since the restaurant was packed on a Friday night, the service was kind of slow. Should've kept this little gem to myself! 

For our appetizers, we ordered the calamari and mussels again cause they were just so amazing last time. (See old review for my comments on those dishes). 

For mains - 
1. Shrimp Risotto cooked with fish broth and pistachio
OMG - THIS WAS SO AMAZING! At first look, I thought the risotto only came with two prawns, but little did I know that there were pieces hidden within the risotto. Poesia definitely doesn't skimp out on you! The risotto (though still a bit harder than I usually like my risotto) was full of flavor, and I loved the crunchiness of the pistachios. This was definitely a creative take on your ordinary shrimp risotto. Who knew putting pistachios in there would complement the dish so well?

2. Short Rib Ragu
The consistency of the pasta was so tender and chewy - probably the best pasta I've ever had. The ragu was also really flavorful. 

3. Filet Mignon
It was absolutely delicious. It was cooked to perfection at medium rare, so tender and juicy. It almost just melted in your mouth!

4. Rack of lamb
