Bf said that this was the best rack of lamb he has ever had in SF. Again, it was cooked to perfection at medium rare. He devoured that like no other btw. 

Would definitely recommend everyone to try Poesia! The service is always top notch (though it may be slow at times) and the restaurant is really homey as well :)
author: Michelle L.

description: Took my friend here that were visiting. I was absolute unimpressed with them. The wait staff was friendly and kind from the start. When it came down to my order though I had expressed that I was vegan and tried to edit an item to just not have cheese. I thought it simple enough. When it came out of course it had cheese and I was told "I told you that from the start". Hence why I had requested no cheese and was told I get that all the time. I will say the plates that came out looked very delicious but after being told that I was wrong and I didn't order it correctly upset me. Next time I will just take my friend to the sausage factory as they have always been kind and catered to my request without and issues.
author: Sonny L.

description:
Came here for new years. The food here is quite good. I had the beet carpaccio salad as my appetizer and it was very tasty. For my main entree I had the cioppino which was good too. The only complain that i have is that the portions are a little on the small side and I was a little hungry after dinner still. My partner ordered the seafood fettucine but it looked like my cioppino but instead of have the broth, they had pasta.

Service here was excellent. All the waitstaff is very friendly.
author: Kenson K.

description:
Came here with my bf the night before Valentine's Day. It has good reviews, so we were excited to get a reservation on Opentable. Overall, the experience was "okay."  We had:
- Grilled calamari w/arugula salad: The greens were oily and the calamari was still a little too chewy, but it had a nice flavor so we still enjoyed it.
- Lamb ragu: It was okay. I mean, I'd never order it again and I'm not salivating thinking about it, but it wasn't bad.
- Eggplant parm: Personally, I liked this dish - but anything made with sauce and a lot of cheese is good. It wasn't the best parm cheese ever, and it wasn't the worst. 
- Dandelion side dish: Honestly, the worst then we were served. It was supposed to have a garlicky bread crumb topping, but instead it was just a pile of bitter greens and no other flavor.

All this said, it was a cute restaurant and we had a nice time. It happened to be a warm-ish SF night and it was way too hot in the restaurant.  No cross air ventilation.
author: B B.

description:
How often do I Yelp? Not often. But when I do, it's because it's that phenomenal! Everyone already left good recommendations so just a few more besides the obvious great tender calamari and pasta dishes, the wines are perfectly hand selected, straight forward, reasonable parameter from wine regions of Italy and most importantly conscientious on their price point to leaving room for perhaps getting bottle or two if you're celebrating with friends. Francesco and team had made an establishment so exquisitely genuine, one will be reminded of being with family. (however far they may be.)
It's always been a transcendent experience for my friends and I whenever we dine at Poesia. So with that said, I suppose dining here is truly way more than, one might say, 'just having a meal'.
author: Paulina L.

description:
There are a few restaurants where I leave the place smiling. This place definitely amazing. The homemade pasta was one of the best. 

We ended up showing up early for our 6.30 dinner reservations. Happy hour was awesome. Good prices on cocktails (2 for $10) and appetizers.

Had the mussels and the tomato/bread soup. DELICOUS. 

Went on with the rolled pasta and pork. FRESH PASTA. OMG. 

Girlfriend had the Frutti di Mare. Clean, clean flavors. The sauce and pasta was not overpowering the seafood and vice versa. 

Delicious. One of my favorite spots in the city.
author: A L.

description:
This place used to be a house I think.  I love what they did to it. 

I'm so lucky to have gotten a reservation Sunday night!

Their peach tiramisu was most memorable! YUM!!
author: David W.

description:
Lovely quaint Italian restaurant in the Castro, with a stairway leading up to the restaurant. They have limited table seating on a slim balcony, which is cute with the potential for romantic, provided of course that it isn't a cold and windy evening. 

We were in a rush, and not particularly hungry, so my friend and I split some appetizers, all vegetarian, all delicious, especially the roasted cauliflower! 

Service was casual but efficient even though it was already after 8pm on a Saturday - we were in, seated, ordered, served, ate and paid up in 40 minutes. Very accommodating, since we mentioned we wanted to get to our movie at 9.

Will make it back here with my husband some day soon!
author: Heta D.

description:
I loved this place.  Three of us went for my birthday and had a delightful meal.  I'm a vegetarian, and there were plenty of options.  One thing I loved about was that the server directed me with confidence.  When I narrowed down my choices, he did not hesitate to steer me in one direction over another.

I started with the Parmigiana di Melanzane (eggplant parmasean).  This wasn't ordinary eggplant parm, smoothered in cheese and riddled with sauce.  Rather, it was subtle.  There was sauce, and there was cheese but not a lot.  It was incredible.  The sauce was thick and tart, and the crispiness of the eggplant complimented the sauce perfectly.  Outstanding.

For my entree, I had the Mezzelune di Zaffferano con Taleggio e Funghi, which was a ravioli stuffed with walnuts and Taleggio cheese.  Delicate and delicious.  The saffron sauce was perfectly balanced -- not too heavy or too creamy.  I believe there were only five raviolis with the entree, with which at first, I was disappointed.  That said, I was satisfied by the end of the meal, and with the appetizer and the bread and the glass of Proseco, it was sufficient.  

My friends ordered meat and seafood dishes.  I'm a strict vegetarian; I don't eat fish or fish stocks (and wouldn't share a gnocchi dish with mussels, for instance).  I'm embarrassed to say that I can't remember what my friends had because I was too busy enraptured with the poetry of my own plates.

The food was wonderful.  They do accommodate vegans as well and Poesia seemed to strive to make everyone feel comfortable.  A great place to splurge.  A great place to celebrate.  

Cozy interior.  It's not big.  Reservations recommended.  Conveniently located near Castro on 18th Street.

Couldn't have been better.
author: SalsaBoy S.

description:
Went in alone with with a book and a pasta craving and was greeted by Marnie, who took wonderful care of me. She recognized my reading material and after we had a sweet little chat about that, she catered to my desire to go a little off menu by subbing a pasta for the salad that usually comes with the awesome filet I found myself ordering. Because who can resist a nice filet?

The pasta was absolutely delicious, featuring a scrumptious array of seafood and a sausage sauce that harmonized beautifully. Want a great southern Italian meal without driving to North Beach? Pull up a chair right here. The bartender was awesome too. Perfect marks for food, service, atmosphere and value.
author: Jesse D.

description: Small and personal style restaurant. If you want first class food and service you must give this place a try.
author: Tom K.

description:
Service was good, cocktails were good.  I was not crazy about the taste of what I ordered (squid ink ravioli).  I would have given it another star because it overall it was not that bad, but it was pretty expensive so I did not feel it was my money's worth.  :(. 
May try it again some other day.
author: Lucia M.

description: Dined here tonight with friends and enjoyed a delicious meal.  The owner personally greeted us and assured us a table would be ready soon.  He got us comfortable at the bar while we waited and true to his word, the table was soon ready for us.  We were immediately served water, bread, and olive oil.  The waitstaff was extremely attentive.  I ordered the carapaccio for an app and it arrived as three tender pieces of filet mignon wrapped around arugula, with tiny mushrooms sticking out as if blooming from the dish.  The pork ragu with homemade pasta was simple yet fabulous.  For desert we shared the chocolate mousse, sprinkled with a few grains of sea salt and a drizzle of olive oil.  The ambience is cozy and inviting.  One interesting addition are the continual Italian TV commercials from the 60's being projected on one wall.
author: Scooter B.

description:
Comfy and cozy with delicious food, tasty wines, and a very friendly and knowledgeable staff. 

Nice to have this little escape in the heart of the Castro.
author: Dirk W.

description:
I'm from Italy and I have to say: Amazing food! Authentic, original Italian recipes and high quality ingredients. The service was impeccable and really enjoyed the experience. 

Also very good for vegetarians! 

We'll definitely go back very soon!
author: Virginia Margherita F.

description: FABULOUS! Loved every moment at Poesia. It's so intimate as it was a home...
author: Marisa A.

description:
We came with good expectations, but we got a very poor service, rude even. waiting over 40 minute to get our dishes without offering any water in the meantime or getting some kind attention from the waiter and in the end the food was horrible.  

We complain once to the manager and we didn't even get "i'm sorry". 
We paid and left. We'll never come back again.
author: Shay B.

description:
Poesia is an excellent option in the Castro district.  I love the ambiance of the house/restaurant and how it's an intimate space.  Being a small space, you definitely want to make a reservation.  Noise also became more of an issue as the restaurant became busier.  

Service - we interacted with both servers.  Both were very friendly and paced service to our requests (eating several courses, we stretched the meal out for about 2 hours). 

Food - Loved everything!  Tenderloin carpaccio was excellent and a very good size portion.  I highly recommend the tomato bread soup. The gnocchi is housemade and was a tad heavy;not the "pillows of heaven" that we gnocchi lovers eternally hunt for.  I'd never had gnocchi with branziino, which presented an interesting blend of flavors.  The menu offers unique dishes that you don't commonly see.  

Poesia is also very reasonably priced and portion sizes were plenty.  I highly recommend this restaurant.
author: Ashley W.

description:
Yet another full-bodied delightful experience. We walked in without reservations(!) on Labor Day weekend and were wowed, again. 
Risotto in squid ink
Bruschetta like none other
Beef steak par excellence
Ver-ry, ver-ry happy that this pleasure resource is here in the neighborhood!
author: lance l.

description:
Use Savored for 30% off!

5 stars for their burrata holy moly it was good. I was a bit disappointed with the famous squid ink risotto (undercooked in my opinion), and the fried fish. I would definitely return though to try the other dishes. The service was awesome, and their top tier wines are AMAZING.
author: Jess C.

description: Super slow service... And not in a good way.  Waitstaff helpful and pleasant, but it took forever to get our entrees.  Cocktail list is interesting.  Wines we ordered with dinner were so-so.
author: B. Thomas A.

description:
Wow, this place is fantastic!

We're over in East Bay and had tickets for "1776" the musical playing at A.C.T.  We heard about Peosia on KQED's "Check Please Bay Area," and decided to try it before the show.  Traffic across the Bay Bridge was faster than we thought so we arrived 15 minutes before our reservation time of 5:30.  We were warmy greeted by Francesco and invited to sit on the 'porch' for a few minutes.  A few minutes later, he reappeared with a nice glass of Persecco for the four of us!  What a great way to start the evening off!  We had a really nice time chatting with him before and during the dinner.

I had the soup of the day - an organic tomato bread soup (thickened with bread).  It was really good - very bright and fresh flavors.  My wife and I split a Beet Salad.  She had the Filet Mignon Ravioli w/ Lobster Mushroom Sauce.  She loved it!  I had the Oreccheitte Alla Calabrese, coin shaped pasta basked in the oven with 'Nduja Sausage, Porcini Mushrooms and Provolone.  It was superb.  The pasta was perfect.y al dente and perfectly seasoned.  It was also fresh and bright in flavor and well balanced.  The other couple also had the same soup and split a different salad.  I forget what entrees they had but they were also extremely well satisfied with their choices, as well.

We finished the meal with one order of Spuma Cioccolato, dark chocolate mousse, sea salt flakes, extra virgin olive oil and chili powder.  It was so very rich that it was just right for the four of us!  What a way to cap a fantastic meal!

Bottom line - this is a great place because the food is terrific and the prices are reasonable with excellent service and ambiance.  Francesco makes you feel so very welcome - it's like going to a friend's house for dinner!  The price for that quality level of food makes this place an outstanding value.  I can't say enough about this place.  We would go 3 to 4 times a month if they were closer to our home!!!!

Well done and thank you, Francesco!!!

Jim

12/14/13 UPDATE:

Went back for dinner tonight with another couple and had another wonderful dinner!  We felt really comfortable and welcome in this very busy establishment.  But, even with the holiday crowds and high-energy, the service was impeccably smooth and polished.  We started with Calamari and Polenta for appetizers.  Both were great and the squid was perfectly grilled - nice and tender.  The Polenta was with mushroom and Calabrese Sausage that gave it just the right degree of kick. I had the Lasagna, my wife had the Special Ravioli, our guests had the Squid Ink Pasta and the Linguine w/Lamb Ragout.  All were exquisite!  

I was curious to see if the first visit was a fluke but since they were able to replicate the excellent experience, I have to conclude that Francesco and his crew are able to deliver this kind of fine food and service on a consistent basis!

We'll be back even though it is over an hour drive for us!!!!

Jim
author: James Q.

description:
This is my new favorite San Francisco restaurant. The owner, Francesco, and staff, especially Marney and Alex, are friendly and attentive, and the food is amazing. Ask them what to order, and they will deliver you one of the best dining experiences you have ever had. 

I recommend starting with the Swept Away cocktail and getting the Calamari Alla Griglia as an appetizer. Until I came to Poesia, I did not care for calamari, but this is the best I have ever had (My mouth is watering just thinking about it!). It is delicious; you can taste the smokiness of the grilled preparation, along with the tenderness of the calamari. From there, I leave it in the hands of Francesco; whatever he suggests I am ordering. 

My friends and I first dined here on Christmas Eve, and I got the lobster and pasta, and when I was there last month, I got the crab and squid ink fettucine. Both were amazing. I also tried, at Francesco's suggestion, the Spuma di Cioccolato, a chocolate mousse with sea salt flakes so decadent, that I wanted the serving dish to be bottomless. 

What impresses me most about this restaurant is that no detail goes unnoticed. You do not have to ask for more water, another drink, or for your plates to be cleared. In a small space, a magical orchestra unfolds with each staff member playing their part to perfection. It is impressive, and each time I eat here, I feel like I have been invited to a friend's house. Italian movies play in the background, and the staff makes you feel so comfortable. 

This is my "go to" spot for celebrations and special occasions. I can hardly wait for the next one, so I can eat here again!
author: Sarah O.

description:
This place is a great neighborhood gem! The food is sooooo good; it's really fantastic! We had the 
Apps
--Bruschetta ( with burrata, duck and fig jam). I have never had this combination before but it's perfect! More substantial and interesting than just with tomatoes and the fig jam gives it a slightly sweet touch that compliments perfectly.
-- Gnocchi ( In a sauce of orange juice and cherry tomatoes) again, the combo was so great we were using slices of the table bread to lap up the remaining sauce 

Main
-- FILEJI DI RENATO ( tube pasta with pork ragu) really great. If you want comfort food in the form of warm pasta with thick tomatoe sauce topped with Parmesan cheese, this is the dish for you.
-- TAGLIATA DI FILETTO DI MANZO CON INSALATINA DI RUCOLA E FARRO ( filet mignon with arugula and farro salad) this dish was pleasantly light. If you are looking for a leaner/ paleo- option that will not weigh you down, this is your dish.

Sides
-- CAVOLFIORI AL FORNO (cauliflower ) do yourself a favor and order this dish... Even if you don't like cauliflower!! Best I have ever tasted

Dessert
--  TIRAMISU ( of course!) You will not be disappointed
--CANNOLO, I am not a huge fan of cannolis but this I liked. I am also not particularly fond of citrus in desserts and it did have an orange flavoring in the filling which I could have done without, but my bf loved it and I found myself going back for more bites than I anticipated
-- Cappuccino (perfectly balanced and a nice end to the meal). I am a coffee drinker and I enjoyed it

Only cons: time to receive food and noise level

Summary 
This is a quaint restaurant in an old Victorian and it can be a really romantic spot especially if you get a table close to the window. The noise level can also get a bit high if there any large groups dining ( on my night there were three). The only real downside to the experience was that the service time was SO SLOW! Our waitress was pleasant and water was refilled timely and dishes removed, but the time it took to get each course was double the time you would expect and the restaurant was not full. Unsure if they were short staffed in the kitchen, but we went through 2 baskets of bread because our food was taking so long and we were starving. That being said the food that ( eventually) came out was great. I would definitely go back again and would highly recommend this.... Just be sure to buffer in  2 hours at a minimum.
author: Rebecca B.

description:
I go here for all my special dinners. I highly recommend this small romantic restaurant.

The menu changes ever few month, and keeps things very exciting.
 
The food is on point and great, the service is warm and very welcoming (except for once where the waiter was slow) but other than the one slow service , service is  great

Drinks are good if you enjoy fine ports, wine or Brandy. Not a huge fan of mixed drinks.

Prices are what you would expect from a place of this quality. I think for what it is, prices are fair.


The chef is very friendly and welcoming and his food is always a pleasure to have .

Best desert would have to be the chocolate mouse, (sea salt olive oil and cayenne), and I highly recommend it.

One of my favorites has to be the Bronzino or the squid ink risotto (though it may stain the mouth for a few hours lol)
Best app I've had there are the variations of sardine,they tend to change a bit over time, but are very good (unless you don't like sardines) 


 All in all, I always recommend  this place to anyone who enjoys fine food , intimate atmosphere , good service and good drink.
author: Chef B.

description:
Owner Francesco is as warm and inviting as the food he serves. 

When most people review restaurants, they include the ambiance, service and just the overall tone of the experience along with how the food tasted. It is important for people to feel comfortable while enjoying their food. 

If I'm describing you, then you need to try Poesia. 

To my advantage, I grew up with a Sicilian mother who genuinely loved to cook for people. This is what this restaurant felt like to me. I recognized everything on the menu but zeroed in on two of my all time favorite foods-carciofi and melenzane. (artichokes and eggplant) 

The artichoke dish was my antipasto choice. It was moist inside (like mashed potatoes) and crunchy fried on the outside. The ultimate comfort food. 

I had the eggplant parmigiana as my entree. It was wonderful. My partner had the caprese salad which I tasted as well. The mozzarella melts in your mouth. His main dish was the Fileji di Renato. (pork ribs, roasted garlic, smoked ricotta served over homemade penne pasta) Wow! 

We finished things off with the hazelnut gelato and the orange infused tiramisu.

Francesco was our server.  He along with everyone else there took very good care of us and managed a packed restaurant with ease. 
It's apparent that they all love what they do.
author: Thomas D.

description: This is a very cute Italian restaurant in the Castro. The food was awesome everything tastes so fresh and homemade. We started off with a puff pastry Rustica which was a special. It tastes so good like a mini stuffed warm croissant. We ordered the Tagliolini Integrali con Fagiolini Patate E Pesto and the Fettuccine al Ragu di Agnello with gluten free pasta. Both pastas were excellent the pasta is homemade which really adds to the taste.
author: Paul D.

description: This place is pretty unique and delicious! Fresh homemade pasta tasted amazing. My friend and I really wanted pasta so we asked for certain sauces from other dishes and asked for pasta with it. I got a seafood sausage based sauce with mine and she got a pork ragu with hers, they tasted so good. Everything was good, even the free bread! Service was great from beginning to end. Only small flaw a bit too much sea salt on the chocolate dessert and not enough mascrapone in the tiramisu dessert.
author: Karen T.

description:
This place was fantastic!

Nice hole in the wall place off of the Castro. The overall ambiance in the restaurant was quaint and well reserved. As everyone has proceeding in saying that the staff is friendly and attentive. 

Any of their signature cocktails are phenomenal, and a must try. 

The food was something of a treat, every entree that was served was a new delight of   extravagant flavors.
author: Dennys G.

description:
That was my first experience and I was kinda disappointed.
The food was good but nothing exceptional. According to me, it's a way expensive compared to the quality and the quantity. The wine wasn't so good either. 
The service was decent nothing more nothing less. 
I won't recommend this place ...
author: Ornella G.

description:
I never met a pasta I didn't like - until I ate at Poesia. Despite occasional highs, the lows are too frequent and too low to give this overpriced neighborhood joint your hard-earned dining dollars.

The inconsistent service and cuisine at this restaurant do not support its aggressive pricing, which is amplified by an irritating, European-style cover charge for bread - "and the tablecloth," as the owner subsequently explained - that is not disclosed until you get the final bill. 

While the so-called "covert" fee is only $1 per guest, it is superfluous for a so-so restaurant charging the better part of $20 for tiny servings of nearly inedible pasta (as discussed more fully below) and the better part of $30 for its protein-based secondi.   
 
Things started off on a high note with the grilled calamari appetizer and a shared plate of beet ravioli that tasted better, and more subtle, than you would think. But things then started to fall apart. 

There was a l-o-n-g, l-o-n-g, uncomfortably l-o-n-g wait for the main courses. When they arrived, they were not up to expectations.  

While the baked branzino was workmanlike, the fish was not nearly as moist and flavorful as preparations experienced in numerous other restaurants or even our humble home kitchen. The pal who rapidly gobbled down the creamy crab pasta special reported it to be delicious. 

In our foursome, I drew the losing hand by ordering the squid-ink gnocchi with shrimp. Presented with exactly two (2) shrimp, my first bite of the waterlogged gnocchi was absolutely icy. When I looked around for someone to take the dish back to the kitchen for further attention, no server could be found. Sampling another bite, I found the balance of the pasta warm enough to consume, though it tasted musky and dull. When I finally flagged down a busboy to fetch some salt and pepper to try to fix it up, even additional seasoning could not mask the unpleasant taste.

If it hadn't taken so long to get dinner and if I had been able to find a server on the floor on a timely basis, I would have sent the dish back as a FAIL. Absent these alternatives, I took one for the team and ate as much of the glop as I could. When I finally had an opportunity to courteously bring these issues to the attention of the owner, he seemed neither interested nor apologetic.   

So, here's my advice, Mr. Owner: If you are going to be as pretentious and greedy as to impose a cover charge on top of your aggressively priced menu, then the consistency and the quality of the food and service ought to back up your conceit.

My advice to everyone else is: You can do better than this place.
author: Alan M.

description:
I took my friend here for a birthday dinner and the service was exceptional from the beginning til the end.  One hiccup was that she forgot one of our side dishes but we were so full it didn't matter.

Fresh pastas, and they weren't strict about switching out sauce for other sauces.  When plated it didn't look like much but once you start eating you get full fast.  We both each got a dessert and I really liked the chocolate mousse with salt dessert but some bites had a little too much sea salt.  I was too thrilled about their tiramisu too.
author: Rosalind S.

description: I've lived in the Castro for decades, and can remember some pretty awful restaurants in this location. Finally, we have a winner! Excellent food, superb service, not cheap, but worth every penny. Everything we ordered was delicious, but the mussels (appetizer) and squid ink pasta are real stand-outs. I hope Poesia will succeed and grace our neighborhood with its presence for many, many years.
author: John M.

description:
I think this is 4.5 stars. I tend to be stingy with my fifth star.
What a great surprise in the Castro. Great Italian food.
Cozy dining room with friendly family style service.
First sat at the bar and had some interesting small batch bourbon. They now have my attention.
At the table, the Calamari is excellent. Maybe the best ever. Not breaded (thank you). Great texture, meaty and flavorful.
For dinner I had the ravioli stuffed with filet mignon and mushrooms. Rich and flavorful, satisfying. Not salty and fatty as the American taste buds tend to reshape ethnic menus.
Don't know what my Mate had but it was some fish...staring at me. He absolutely loved it. He rarely raves about food. The chocolate mousse was the perfect portion and perfect balance of sweet and savory.

Completely impressed and I would gladly drag a foodie or an Italian here.

On a side note: I used to work in this space 27 years ago. As we were dining I was having flashbacks to coked up waiters and drag queen owners....ahhhh, the 80's.
author: Monster B.

description:
We went here for dinner for the first time at the end of September.  We were warmly greeted and seated at a window table overlooking 18th Street.  Some bread and a very good olive oil were promptly served.
For starters, I ordered the tomato bread soup while my husband ordered the grilled calamari with mixed greens.  The soup was absolutely delicious, as good as everyone said.  My husband said his calamari was perfectly grilled so it was not chewy and he liked the lemon vinaigrette with his salad.
For entrees, I ordered the lamb shank and fettuccine while he had the shrimp and mushroom risotto. I was expecting a shank with the bone, but the lamb had been removed from the bone, chopped and served over the fettuccine. It was great.  My husband said his risotto was perfectly cooked and there were generous amounts of shrimp and mushroom.
We also had the black cherry soda which was surprisingly good.
We were offered dessert but we were too full.
The service was great and we told the owner that we will return and recommend Poesia to our friends.
author: Philip C.

description: Attended a wonderful private party at Poesia this past weekend and was very impressed with both the food and the service!  We were so lucky to have the whole place to ourselves and the complete devotion of the staff.  The appetizer, main course (pork) and cannoli were just great!  Great place for a birthday party...
author: Marcus T.

description: Hanging on the long wall is an eclectic and fascinating mix of vintage photographic images and lively black and white oil paintings. A projected old movie plays along another wall, silenced. There is a quaint artistic charm to the place that I like. I think that it being housed in an old Victorian helps to attain this feeling. Our appetizers emerged quickly, especially the olives, enjoyed by all as fun finger food over lively conversation. We waited longer than we would like for our main dishes, and when they came each of us cleared our plates with delight. I enjoyed every bite of the gnocchi, adding some warm marinara to it. The gentlemen found the calamari divine, and my partner clapped her hands in excitement for the filet mignon. We love the ambiance and food, however we prefer more attentive service. The tables are close together, and sound carries. Poesia is a delightful place for a small group, and romantic enough for two.
author: Gaya G.

description:
This is a cute restaurant with good quality food.  The server was very friendly and helpful, but it took a while for anyone to come to our table at first.  After we ordered our drinks the service was good.  The classic Negroni was excellent and the wine list had a lot of reasonable priced wines.  
The squid salad was great.  I loved that the had grilled squid instead of the fried everyone else serves.  
The home made ravioli was great.  It had a fish filling.
They squeeze a lot of people in a small space so I felt crowded.  We had to move the table candles and decoration onto the windowsill or we couldn't have fit our food on the table
author: Michael L.

description: If you don't have an Italian grandmother or you do and you miss her cooking, this is the place to go to try the best of recipes passed down through generations. Not only is the food amazing, the ambiance and staff are welcoming and you get to feel like you are at home in an Italian living room. The textures and flavors of the food were like a hug for my soul. This is the place I would return to over again in San Francisco. Each dish was my new favorite and the desserts were a divine treat.
author: TrueGaines P.

description: We came to Poesia the other week for a birthday dinner for my mother and husband. I'd read mixed reviews, so I was crossing my fingers that everything would go well. Poesia definitely delivered. The ambiance was wonderful, the service fantastic and the food delicious. They took note of the message I'd left regarding the birthdays, and although I didn't prompt them, the staff acknowledged both my mother and husband and helped us celebrate. The seating area was perfect as it allowed for some privacy, and we didn't have to shout across the table to hear one another. I would not hesitate to return and to send my friends!
author: Marisa B.

description:
Food. 4.5/5
Some bruschetta thing with burrata and jam. 2/5
Fileji di Renato. 5/5. Amazing texture of house made pasta but a little salty
Tiramisu 5/5
$55 for 1 post tip with wine. Will come back to try more stuff.
author: Olivia Q.

description:
I missed Italian food (I'm from NYC) and took a friend to this place last night, based on a recommendation from a stranger (strangers suck). 

Last night's dinner was an homage to Chef Boyardi. 

We never heard the specials (maybe the waiter didn't want us to get sick), the calamari tasted like tires (have you ever tried to eat a tire? Not fun, let me tell you). My pasta was gross, my friend's pasta was gross, everything was gross. I felt like I was being punished. Like I did something wrong to someone and my fine was to eat here. Please don't go here, unless you just got off a deserted island. Then this place is heaven. 

Made a rez to Flour and Water to make up for this atrocity. God bless.
author: J R.

description: Great food. Seems to have taken the feedback. The staff are great and Francesco when he's there is an excellent host. Try the lamb fettuccine.
author: Mahesh A.

description:
I was highly impressed with Poesia, maybe even more-so with the atmosphere and service than with the food itself, which was also very good. The space is very comfortable and welcoming like you are dining in someones living room rather than a full service restaurant just a block off Castro. The service was great because someone always came to check on us even though they were busy, but we never felt hurried to order or leave.

The Bruschetta di Goffredo appetizer was a bit underwhelming and is probably not something that I would reorder, however, the Calamari Salad was delicious - grilled, fresh and not overdressed so the protein spoke for itself. The ravioli dish I had was the highlight though. This is not something I normally order but I would definitely do so again if I came back to Poesia.

Overall a great dinner experience. It is not the best Italian food that I have ever had but did not disappoint at all, and the overall dining experience was pleasant and memorable.
author: Frank J.

description:
This restaurant has really gone down hill in the past few years. It was 5 years ago that I wrote a review of it, and I'm glad they've made a go of this space.

The service was the huge problem last night. We had a reservation and had to wait a half hour past the reservation time for our table. I know this isn't always in the control of the restaurant, but simply leaving you in the very small doorway (the bar was too crowded to sit and have a glass of wine) isn't really very pleasant. And half an hour is really inexcusable.

Then it took a long time for the waiter to take our order, and after the plates were cleared away from our starters, it took close to 45 minutes for our main dishes to come out. By that time there was hardly anyone else in the place and we couldn't figure out what was going on. None of our dishes were very complicated, but it apparently takes 45 minutes to cook ravioli and risotto.

The waiter rarely bothered to check on us, he and his compatriots were too busy setting the other tables up for the next day and ignoring the customers they had at that moment.

Frankly, the so-so food wasn't really the problem. Nothing was terrible but it was all missing something small (heat, salt). The best things was the beet salad, and also the soup with favas, fresh peas and calamari. 

But there's just no excuse for service that terrible. I very much doubt we'll be back here.
author: Mike F.

description:
My first experience was great. I enjoyed the intimate setting and the old movie on screen. I would have given them four stars. However, I went back just a few weeks ago and I was pretty disappointed.

The caprese salad and eggplant parmesan were great appetizers, but it took at least 40 minutes for our food to arrive after that. Our waiter made no effort to acknowledge the long wait by bringing us some bread or just simply apologizing. But, that's not why I'm taking away one star.
You would think that being so hungry I would think that any dish would taste good, but I didn't. I ordered the special, which was ravioli stuffed with beets and ricotta. The pasta was thick and rubbery. I also had the chance to try the baked fish, which was so under seasoned that we could hardly eat it. But we didn't skip out on dessert! I had the meringue which just felt like I was eating a block of sugar, topped off with whipped cream. No complaints on the taste but they should make it worth the money or just take it off the menu.
author: Natalie P.

description: We got dinner to go and it actually was really tasty. Burrata with tomatoes - mmm, delicious. Pastas were good (and we had leftovers). The only one  appetizer we didn't care too much was some dish with potatoes and peppers. Other than that - good stuff. We will come again. The place looks super cozy.
author: Masha K.

description:
I heard about this place while listening to Check Please! on the radio, and decided to treat myself and a friend to a nice meal so I could try it out.

The meal started out great.  The service from our very attentive and polished waiter, Alex, was outstanding throughout the whole evening.  We skipped the cocktails and went straight to the wine list, which had a lot of interesting, reasonably priced choices.  The bread, spiced with a hint of pepper, was also unique and very good.  For appetizers, we had the eggplant parmesan and beet salad, both of which were well proportioned and delicious.  All in all, a promising start to the evening.

Then came the mains...My friend had the fettuccine with shredded lamb shank, and I had the seafood risotto with scallops and mussels.  Both were beautifully presented, and after a great start to the meal, we could barely wait to dig into our food.  Unfortunately, both of our mains were a total disappointment.  Although both the pasta and rice were cooked perfectly, and both had generous portions of either lamb or mussels and scallops, we found both of our options to be incredibly bland and lacking in any depth and complexity of flavour.  

Also, the restaurant is small and intimate.  At the start of the meal, it was fine, but after the restaurant filled up, it got incredibly warm, to the point where both of us were sweating profusely by the end of the main course.  We ended up skipping dessert and going elsewhere.  

Unfortunately, by the end of the night, what had potential to be an outstanding meal ended up being a pretty average experience.  Given the endless options in the city, I'll probably pass on a repeat of this place.
author: Allan T.

description:
Well.....
I was so excited to come here because I've heard so many great things about Poesia.
I absolutely loved the design of the place - very cozy. 
We came here with a group of friends.  Had a reservation, were seated right away.  Placed out order.

For appetizer I had a duck brucchetta.  Now that was TO DIE FOR! 

For the main entree all of us ordered pasta, for which we had to wait 1.5 hours!! What?  Come on now, how long does it take to boil pasta?  Even though it was nice to sit with friends and chat, an hour and a half is a bit too long to be waiting for food...

One of my friend's pasta wasn't cooked enough.  Maybe an hour and a half isn't long enough after all?...

Anyway... I've had better pasta (quicker too) at a French restaurant and they didn't charge me an arm and a leg for it.
author: Dasha B.

description: Phenomenal food, experience. While in San Francisco for a week, i made two trips to Poesia. I even got the mussels twice. Delicious, decadent Italian food. Seasoned to perfection. Great full bar service and an attentive staff. A must if you're in the castro neighborhood. Can't wait to come back.
author: Mark B.

description: Ordered the AHI, BREADED TOMATO SOUP and BONE MARROW PORK along with a champagne for Valentine's Day.  Not bad!  My pork was a little cold and the ahi was somewhat blend.  Overall not bad.
author: Edwin R.

description:
All the food was excellent. 

The service could have been speedier and a bit better, but it did not hamper our experience at all. Though I don't think it deserves 5* no matter how much I liked the food.

All the food we had was great. grilled calamari, ravioli, whole fish, kale salad, stuffed pepper. 

Dessert chocolate carmel sea salt mousse.  very good.

Wine, Chianti Superiori Excellent as well. 

I had a jack and coke pre-dinner which was made with a designer cola. I did not like it.
author: Lance M.

description: Adorable location and ambiance, great service.  Burrata and Calamari appetizers were great.  The reason why it's just a 3 star is because of the main entree - Pasta (Lamb sugo).  It was just ok.  Bland, not that tasty and I have just had so much better.  And because it's the main dish and in my mind, raison d'etre, I would have to give it just stars.
author: Deal G.

description:
Met up with a friend Thursday night. This place was packed so we sat at the bar. Very romantic inside, cozy decor and lighting, great date place if you needed. Teddy, the bartender, was cool, friendly, and had a chill accent; great start to the evening! 
The entrees weren't amazing, but good. Mild portions. The fried calamari was delicious though; wasn't the battered and deep-fried kind; strong seafood flavor, must try! We also had the squid ink ravioli, which I thought did its job.
Sitting at the bar was fun, so we ended up drinking four cocktails and some wine.
1. Voice of the Moon: St. George Rye Gin, Averna, ginger syrup & grapefrult juice.
2. Juliet of the Spriits: Swan Neck Grape Vodka lemon drop with St. Germaine and Lavender.
3. Eight & Half: Hangar One Mandarin, Cointreau, fresh fennel - my favorite of the night.
4. Teddy's personal recommendation: Rum & Cynar. Pretty dam good.
We were feeling adventurous so got the pear dessert, forgot what it's called. It was either that or tiramisu, brownie, etc., things you can find at most restaurants... Best way to describe it was "pear meets pho." Trust me on that one, it was interestingly good.

I'd definitely come back in the near future.

*posted photos of the menu and the cocktails.
author: Ethan L.

description:
I brought my family here for dinner last month and enjoyed the food as well as the service. Everything tasted fresh-they make their pasta's in-house, even the gluten free pasta! 

On two occasions I made reservations for fairly large parties without any problems and everyone enjoyed their meals.

This place is great.
author: Shalana M.

description: Absolutely wonderful service and food! And a great deal for the price. My dinner companion and I split the burratta and beet appetizers along with two pasta dishes, wine and dessert! Highly recommended!
author: Jacob S.

description: Food was great !!!! I finished my espresso before our dessert showed up, that was kinda sad. I hate to have to wait for the check, I'm done PLEASE let me go .....
author: todd r.

description:
We decided to finally try this place, after passing it so many times in Castro. 

The dinner experience was good, but with no highlights. Wine selection was fine, and the service was fine as well. 

If you want some mind-blowing Italian food, this might not be your option. However, if you have some imminent Italian craving and doesn't want any bad surprise, Poesia will be ideal for you. 

In short, I didn't have bad experience there, but I also didn't remember what I ate that wow'd me, either. But it's still worth recommending to try at least once to make your own judgment. :)
author: Kai Y.

description: Best Italian food I've had in awhile. Excellent service, beautiful ambiance, and homemade everything. I will definitely be returning. This is going to be my new secret gem :)
author: Brittany M.

description:
We had the cutest waiter!  Too bad the food he served was not so good.  We tried the gluten-free pastas and they were just ok.  Even though the pastas as freshly made, I've tasted better gluten-free pastas from a package.  The highlight of our meal was the duck and mint pesto bruschetta.  It was delicious!  Another plus is that reservations are not hard to get.  

All in all, not a bad restaurant.  But I'd try something else before coming back here.
author: K V.

description: We ordered for a surprise cake/dark chocolate mousse for a birthday  boy and they completely forgot and messed up the whole surprise. Note that this is the place where we went for our first date and would have loved to keep that memory intact. The owner came to us and kind of accosted us and blamed us for being upset!!!!
author: Ashok B.

description:
Ahh Poesia, weren't you a jewel to stumble upon! Some friends and I had an impromptu dinner here last night after every other place we thought of had a long wait.  What a lovely surprise.  First off, the restaurant is intimate, cozy, and very welcoming.  The staff is authentic and ended up conversing in Italian with my friends the majority of the evening.  The bread was delicious asiago crusted and the olive oil had a rich flavor I couldn't get enough of.  And then we ordered our food.  Heaven in my mouth... a friend of mine from Italy went so far as to say it made him excited for his return home, which is QUITE a compliment! 

My sister and I each ordered the squid ink ravioli filled with crab and goat cheese with a lemon-herb butter sauce.... thank goodness the chef served us reasonable portions because otherwise I would have eaten myself to the point of pain.  It was so delicious.  The service was attentive and friendly, and the prices were very reasonable.  Honestly, I cannot wait to go here again.
author: W. L.

description: Poesia is lovely. The food, the wine, and the ambience just work. Last time we were there, we had the pappa al pomodoro (as good as it gets), a perfectly cooked filet mignon with arugula and farro, and a roast chicken with polenta. Heavenly.
author: David K.

description: Great place for dinner. Service is still on tap.
author: Marck N.

description:
Poetic.

Existing above one of the Castro's iconic intersections.*

Creating numerous incredible dishes such as grilled calamari salad and ravioli filled with Dungeness crab.

Providing complimentary warm, soft, and absolutely outstanding bread on the side.

Charging prices that are extremely reasonable.

Serving a clientele that has quickly turned this place into a favorite and with good reason.

Experience felt like culinary poetry especially while seated at a table with a view of the vibrant* life below. Easily a five star work of art.

*By vibrant I mean includes a view into shop with a neon penis across the street. Thank you Castro for keeping life interesting for gays and straights alike.
author: Jason B.

description:
Second time I've been here in 6 months and POESIA doesn't disappoint. It's like dining in a cozy home but space is comfortable, not tight. They continuously play old movies against a wall but no sound so it doesn't interrupt your dinner/conversation. Service is good and owner, I think, will frequent tables himself. Quite busy for a Tuesdsy night but no wait either 

Had Sardine alla Cesare - my usual Cesar Salad. Nice presentation with whole half spear of Romaine  and whole whole sardine. NO canned fish!!

Also try the pasta with squid. Think it was the special for the night . Good clean flavor, not heavy. We also had Branzino al Forno - sea bass. So much food for two people. Couldn't finish it!

Must try the orange flavor tiramisu for dessert. It's not SuperSweet and tastes heavenly. Not your typical tiramisu as it comes in a little glass bucket. 
Will definitely come back!!
author: Heather N.

description: Charming, cozy ambiance. Beautiful, fresh dishes on a changing menu. Italian service staff.
author: Curry F.

description:
When my hubby's grandparents came to town, we searched for a nice place to eat in the Castro and we ended up at the wonderful Poesia. The restaurant really has a nice, warm (both temperature-wise and feeling-wise) environment with attentive, friendly servers and a lovely constant projection of black and white (Italian?) cinema playing faintly on one of the walls, although with no sound, that I could hear anyways.

The hubby and I both ordered the squid ink ravioli filled with Dungeness crab in a White wine sauce. I love me some calamari but the ravioli tasted a little extra squid-y, however, I still thought it tasted divine and pretty damn good. Hubby concurred.

Hubby's grandparents enjoyed the delicious daily special arugula and mascarpone salads as appetizers as well as braised lamb (which hubby's grandpapa found yummy and tender) and another daily special, beet ravioli (which hubby's grandmama found delicious as well, sweet but not too sweet). Hubby's 

Hubby's parents enjoyed pink (from beet juice) fettuccine with gorgonzola, caramelized radicchio, walnuts; and soft polenta with taleggio cheese and crimini mushrooms.

The parents and grandparents all enjoyed a nice pinot noir. Hubby's grandpapa also enjoyed a smooth serving of Courvoisier with the desserts while hubby had a shot of espresso.

For dessert we ordered their chocolate mousse with sea salt, cayenne and mascarpone as well as a citrus and chocolate cheesecake. One of the staff members, possibly the manager (because he was in a fancy suit) also graced us with a free third dessert, a pear poached in red wine filled with vanilla custard. It was just the right amount of sweetness with red wine undertones, of course, and the custard tasted nice and smooth.

Overall, our experience at Poesia was immensely delightful. We will definitely return in the near future.
author: Lauren L.

description:
A great place for a romantic dinner. A Victorian house transformed into a restaurant, Unique! Walls adorned with small picture frames, silent movies projected on the wall, candlelit tables and dim lighting gives the place a very warm and intimate feel. 

- Best to come here with reservation. However Sundays are mostly low, so possibility of getting a seating fast
- Service is excellent, very attentive
- Great list of wine, full bar
- Several GLUTEN FREE pastas available!!
- Pastas are all hand-made
- Very small servings, so don't come very hungry!  
- Expensive.  A meal for 2 with an appetizer($9) , 2 pasta dishes($18), a       dessert($9) + a glass of wine($9) bills to $80.

Bloomspot deal of $25 for $50 saves the bucks for you. So don't miss the Bloomspot deal!!

Note: DONOT come on any special days, like Valentine's Day with Bloomspot coupon as they don't accept it even though it's not mentioned in the coupon! Else call before to confirm.  

The best dishes we tried:
Appetizer - 
- Roasted duck Bruschetta $9  -  4/5 Delicious, But -1 point for serving just 1 piece

Main dish -
- Risotto with shrimp and pistachios $18 - 5/5  The BEST dish. The risotto cooked in fish broth, with the crunchiness of pistachios was sooo darn flavorful!! Loved the prawns in the dish!

- Lamb shank ragu over fettuccine pasta - $18 Good  4/5

- Half moon shaped squid ink ravioli stuffed with dungeness crab $18 - 4/5 
Extremely small portion served, just 4 pieces of ravioli ,disappointing for paying $18 for this!! So -1 point. However, its flavorful and unique taste.

Dessert- 
Cannolo - BEST ! 5/5 score!! This dessert calls us back to Poesia yet again!  The mild sweet flavor of this dessert is perfect after a heavy meal. Fluffy ricotta cheese filling sprinkled with pistacchios, wrapped in a fried wrap with a drizzle of cinnamon sauce - Simply heavenly!

Great wine, romantic interior and flavorful food makes this the perfect place for celebrating special occassions or a date night.
author: Payal B.

description: Short review: big prices, small portions. Longer review: I had the "Fettuccine al ragu' di agnello" (shredded lamb shank ragu over fettuccine pasta) for $16. It tasted OK, but was nothing special. I lacked a certain "unctuousness" I was hoping for. The portion size was also too small (a mound of pasta somewhere between 4 and 4.5" in diameter). I don't see myself going back.
author: Paul L.

description: amazing! Loved our waitress - we have been twice and she remembered us our second time back. Great, traditional Italian food with wonderful service. They also have good cocktails and wine!
author: Emily B.

description:
My husband and I were in SF for a couple days. Before we got there I researched yelp for a decent Italian joint and narrowed it down to Poesia and made a reservation. Glad I did because it was lovely! 
It was a bit of a struggle getting here because of the bizarre (and dangerous for newbies!) intersection of Market and Castro. I won't go into detail but we could've been killed! And probably arrested for driving while stupid. 
Then it took my husband about 20 minutes to find a place to park so I sat in the restaurant sipping water wondering if he just gave up and went back to the hotel without me. I kept looking out the window for him so much I'm sure the couple actually sitting at that window thought I was a freak. 
So now the meal begins. The service was great from the moment I walked in alone and remained so, even though the restaurant steadily filled up to capacity. 
My husband started with the Carpaccio antipasti; I had the roasted duck bruschetta. Oh. My. God. I can't tell you which was better. 
We then ordered the meals....we were both very happy to see a few choices of either half or full orders. So we both got half orders--I got the lamb shank ragu over fettucini, and my husband ordered the farfalle pasta with fresh sardines. I dislike sardines so didn't really care for his, though I can tell it was good anyway. Plus he said it was good. Mine was simple and delicious and though Italian, reminded me of the lovely "menus of the day" at various little cafes off the beaten track in Spain. I'll assume they do the same thing in Italy. 
I would've loved to have tried dessert but we had a groupon for a dessert somewhere else in the city we needed to use before we went home. :(
I also like the vibe of the place and would love to eat here again when or if in SF again.
author: Laura P.

description:
My friends planned a dinner for my 21st birthday and took me here. I must say this was disappointing. I don't like talking smack about places, but the food was bland and it felt more like a house than a restaurant. The walls were decorated with bookshelves. Besides being bland, they were also expensive.

If you're looking for italian i'd rather just get pizza somewhere on the cheap than go here. Been to many italian restaurants and this was simply not all that great.
author: Ivan E.

description:
Drink / Food:
1.) Juliet of the Spirits = after she shoots herself prematurely to vengeance 
2.) Calamari = Not typical battered deepfried Yummie! In salad
3.) Squid Ink Ravioli = not bad
Food was okay. Presentation was good. Drinks were good.. 


SERVICE:
Good

ATMOSPHERE:
Charming, quaint... novel... felt like you were eating at grandma's old victorian home.. haha... bc it literally is in an old house... converted to a restaurant... um... we sat at the bar that was nice. Great place to catch up with a good friend ;)
author: Angela L.

description:
With the passage of time, I'm finding more and more great little places in the Castro! Poesia is cute, quaint, and somewhere I'd love to venture back to!

We made a reservation for 7:30 p.m. on a Friday night- which seemed silly, as the place had a number of open tables. Thus, when we arrived a half-an-hour early, we were seated without a problem.

Our server was friendly and attentive, and the host made me feel like I was back in Italy. 

We both started with the tomato and bread soup. OH MY GOD. Delish! I seriously could eat this every day! (Well at least every cold, foggy, and/or rainy day.)

I ordered the braised short rib pasta, and he ordered the roast chicken. The pasta is TO DIE FOR. Handmade and perfectly al dante with a spicy tomato sauce and meat that melts in your mouth. Look at me! I'm rambling- but it really is that good!

Although well-seasoned, I found the chicken to be a little dry. This is  no winner, winner chicken dinner.

We'll be back!
author: Annalise F.

description: Very disappointed by this place. Why is it so hard to find good food in the Castro???  I ordered the Tagliolini and it was basically flavorless.  My partner had the Cod special, and it was also totally unexciting.  We love Italian food and eat plenty of it.  This place is lacking and I don't understand why so many people seem to like it. For the price it should be fantastic. Instead it's not even mediocre, its just gross.
author: WestCoastYelper W.

description:
I've been here several times and seem to enjoy it more each time.....which is strange because I order the braised pork rib pasta every time.

This place is a perfect example of why you shouldn't judge a book by it's cover.
author: Gary M.

description:
I have been here a couple times and have to say its ok... but not outstanding! The bread is horrible!!  Not only is it pre cut and usually the ends are try and curling, but it lacks substance.  Both times ive had pasta.  Both were good, but give up my only child good?... not really.  The prices could be a bit more reasonable, but for most of the menu its not bad. The decor is cute... but dated.  I just get a sense that they try too hard to be something there not. 

The desserts and the service are flawless.
author: Alan H.

description:
Very cute/romantic setting, in a converted house with dim candlelight and silent films projected on the wall. 

The bread and olive oil are de-lish! And the pasta is oh so perfectly chewy - actually the best I can remember ever having. The beet ravioli was unexpectedly delightful (but the same amount as the half portion of the short ribs corkscrew pasta - also yummy). 

The Dino kale salad was a good healthy salad, and the calamari salad was very unique. But neither blew me away.

On my first visit, service was impeccable and not at all overbearing or pretentious. But my last/second time there, the server gave us that contemptful look and attitude when we just ordered entrees and declined his offers of wine, appetizers, and then dessert and coffee. I hate that... I'm not purposely trying to screw over servers by being cheap. Sorry that I don't feel like having wine today, am not super hungry, and am trying to eat healthier by not over-ordering!

This place is definitely not $$$ if you're just getting pasta (especially half portion) and an appetizer. Entrees start at ~$20 (and ~half that for a half portion of pasta). But I guess it adds up if you get all 4 courses and wine!
author: Amy X.

description:
Got a deal for this place for $70 worth of food for $35. They change their menu often, and I cannot remember the name of what I ordered here. Just know that any of their pasta dishes are delicious because they make their own pasta!

I had fettucini with a red sauce and pork (super yum) and the boyfriend also had another pasta dish with a creamy sauce. We also got a glass of red each. They have an assortment of Italian wines which I am unfamiliar with but the server was gracious and answered all of our questions about which wine would suit our palates.

Good place to go if you can score a voucher. If you can't, prices are very reasonable still! And afterwards, you can take a lovely walk down the always fun and lively Castro area!
author: Elizabeth V.

description:
I thought it was a restaurant and am delighted that it is really an osteria! Osteria means a place where guests are hosted, and the hosting here is top-notch. Up a flight of stairs, small reception with a bar in the back of the space and several tables scattered about the rest of the area. It's a bit crowded if the chairs are all filled, as they were last night when we went for our first visit.

Made a last minute reservation via www.opentable. From the moment a waiter greeted us, confirmed our rez and seated us, we found all of the wait staff warm and welcoming. Nice touch. 

Lovely food, very good selection of salads, a couple of soups, lots of starters, and of course pasta and secondi. And a nice dessert menu as well.

The wines we sampled, both whites by the glass, were quite good, and the wine list reads very well with lots of great choices.

Not dressy, a place where you're welcomed and served well and fed well, and can have a great time enjoying an osteria in the Castro. Enjoy!
author: William M.

description:
Special evening with friends.
Celebrating with family from out of town.
Date night.
Important business meeting with a little flair.

Poesia works for all of these.

This place is perfect for anyone looking for a calm, leisurely meal that is sophisticated without being pretentious. I've never had a bad dish... not even a boring dish. The food seems simple but it is always surprising and perfectly prepared. The wine and spirits are of the same quality. The staff are attentive, cosmopolitan, and just as tasty as the food.

Make the most of the atmosphere, food, and drink by planning on several courses and spending all evening, Italian-style.
author: Jenny W.

description:
Excellent cozy environment, not extremely rowdy crowd, and definitely a great spot for a romantic date :) There are movies of

We tried their duck brushetta, shrimp & pistachio risotto and the special of the day - one giant ravioli medallion stuffed with ricotta cheese and veggies, served over cream sauce and light pesto. The portions may be on the medium-small spectrum,  but definitely enough to fill two hungry stomachs with their delicious and incredible combination of fresh ingredients. The seasonal mandarin cocktail and popular basil martini hit the spot - sweet and tart! The dessert of chocolate mousse with sprinkles of sea salt and a dash of olive oil was unconventionally delicious too. 

Overall, this place gets all my stars for their fresh pasta, awesome cocktails and vibrant ambiance. I'd definitely come back and recommend to a friend!
author: Sofia C.

description:
As a local San Franciscan with many Italian friends who all agree this place unfortunately only deserves 1 star. The food came cold with not much flavor and waited way too long to arrive. The owner didn't seem to care when asked why the food was taking too long. We had to ask for water and bread. 
Overall, not a great experience where there are way too many incredible Italian restaurants in the city. We are lucky to have such a great variety. That's why I loveSF.
author: Laura P.

description:
We were pleasantly impressed with Poesia. We made reservations and got their early. So, we sat at the very cute little bar and ordered a couple of house specialty cocktails. They were great and the bartender was very friendly. 

The decor was very comfortable, like dining in a friend's home. They were playing a foreign film (silently) on the wall. 

The food was exceptional. My boyfriend ordered the fillet mignon ravioli. I ordered the sweet potato gnocchi. The servings were not big, for sure. So, if you're really hungry, it may pay to get an appetizer, as well. However, the quality and taste of the food was outstanding. 

We also ordered the Bosc pear for dessert and it did not fail to impress. 

The wait staff was also very friendly and professional, always with a smile on their face.

I would happily recommend Poesia and hope to go there for more date nights in the future.
author: Jenny J.

description:
We enjoyed our dinner here on a recent Sunday night.  The lamb ragu over fettuccine was wonderful. The pasta was fresh and home made, the lamb was tender in a very tasty sauce. My romaine salad with sardines could've been a bit more flavorful.  The sardine was nicely grilled but the romaine could've use a bit more taste whether it'd be a light dressing or lemon juice and olive oil. 

The service was very prompt and attentive with a nice unique cocktail selection. We enjoyed the cozy ambiance and a film running continuously on the back wall.  I'll look forward to coming back and trying more off the menu.
author: Jenny B.

description:
Returned here with the BF for his bday din and again it did NOT disappoint.

Had the branzino (again) (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/1FZM1wOnjMYg0KPSD9qTjg?select=_HjF_uTWMYJeXKIYssMNLA) and it was even better this time (how is that possible, Francesco???) and also a pasta dish with shrimp (might have been a special.. I really should not slack on my reviews).  We also of course had the antipasto misto which was fantastic.  

Also, our waiter was Italian with dreadlocks (fantastic) and Francesco was there which is always a good time.

Oh and of course the bf was impressed... because I'm amazing and fantastic... oh and so is Poesia ;)
author: Josie A.

description:
Took my parents here while they were visiting to meet my boyfriend's family and celebrate me turning old...

Not only was the service great, but the food was too. Delicious. Nothing out of this world, just straight forward and well done.

Plus our waiter did not rush us out of her biggest table on a Friday night, instead she made our evening even more special by being patient and attentive.

Well done Poesia, we shall be back.
author: Lauren B.

description: Delish!!! At first We were super disappointed that most of the dishes we saw on yelp like the grill squid was not on the menu. Reason for it was that they have seasonal menu. To our surprised everything we end up ordering was delish. The homemade pasta and sauce felt healthy and homemade. I recommend replacing the pasta on the menu with whatever homemade pasta they have.
author: Happi Y.

description:
I had been here once several years ago and been wanting to come back.  And when I saw there was a deal, I got it.  I bought a Living Social deal for a 3-course meal w/ wine pairing for two and used it on the last day before expiration.  

I had the special for appetizer, which was bruschetta topped with mushrooms and Ray ordered the carpaccio.  I really liked the carpaccio salad, especially the parmesan.  I felt like the mushrooms had a little bit of a kick to it which I was not use to.  

For entrees, I had the lamb pasta (sorry, don't remember the exact name) and Ray had the half of a chicken.  I was a little worried that the lamb would be gamey but it was perfect and delicious.  I don't remember if I tried the chicken or not, so I can't say.

Dessert, was the cake which was a tad dry, which is why they are receiving one star less than perfect.

For the wine, we were offered a glass each and I had the house white while Ray got the house red.

Before coming here, I read some reviews about how things been and it seems a lot of people weren't happy with the service they received since they were using a deal but I felt our service was attentive and very pleasant.
author: Mimi P.

description:
Great wine space is a bit small tables are very close 
But I loved the food and their Malbec was great
Sit by the windows great view
author: A. M.

description:
WOW!  We had dinner last night at Poesia.  When we walked in, I noticed a movie was playing on a large wall inside.  The place was small, quaint and oh so cute!  It felt like we were in someones home.

We ordered the Mozzarella with grill veggies to start.  It was amazing!

My girlfriend ordered the Ricotta Gnocchi.   It was fresh and cooked to perfection. 

I ordered the Corkscrew pasta with a braised pork ragu.  My dish was soooooo good, I wanted to order another!  The pasta was fresh, the red sauce was perfect and the pork was tender and tasty.

For dessert, the panna cotta.  The blueberry sauce was scrumptious!

I was not familiar with any of the wines on the list and did not try their wine, so I can not comment on the drink aspect.

I will return and hope to do so in the near future!!!
author: Sheryl M.

description:
Wow - such a lovely and inviting restaurant. I love that the produce they use is locally sourced and they use mostly organic foods.
My friend Linda suggested this place as she had been here before. I loved it so much we brought our friend Mary here for her birthday a couple of weeks later.

They have old black and white films projected onto one of the walls. It's fun to watch and great source for conversation. The staff is so friendly and I feel as though I'm home for a visit. We even got hugs upon leaving. :-) 

The food is AMAZING and they have a great wine list to go along with it. The waiters are great at recommending wines to go along with the food choices.

I will definitely be back here and will recommend this place to family and friends!
author: Susan H.

description: This is really a great place. Food is super tasty and the service impeccable. There are few good restaurants in the Castro, and this probably is the best.
author: James M.

description: The wait staff was delightful.  All the food was delicious including the (not sweet but) chocolate ravioli.  We enjoyed looking at the windows and watching the people on 18th Street.
author: Brad L.

description:
Poesia is a relatively intimate  venue. Lights are dimmed, there's an old Italian film playing on... seems "special" enough.

The thought is that you should not go straight to their entree but eat in courses. Try their appetizers-- something with cheese, then the main course, then end with dessert--- something with cheese (in Italy, they begin & end their meals w cheese,  I want to live there!) So the hope is that after you've ordered all three, you will be full bc everyone in the restaurant knows that if you order just an entree, you'll leave wanting some super duper or In n Out bc the portions are TINY.

We ordered the braised pork rib pasta (there's half and full portions of pasta). Think of the half portion as a kid's meal & the full portions is a smidge more than a kid's meal in terms of portions. That sh*t cray.

I had their braised pork rib pasta which was tasty, but not spectacular. Their corkage fee is $20/bottle. +1 for the service, +1 for the food/ ambiance, +1 for the location (so close to Badlands, yeeeeeee!)
author: Rosa L.

description:
The waiter Lorenzo was great! Very inviteful, helpful, and friendly. He even helped my son with the fish dish...now if only all the waiters in the world can be as sweet and kind as he;)

I gave it 3 stars for service but the food was ordinary and because my husband did like his meal I'll bump the 3 to 4.
author: Foodie F.

description: Incredibly adorable, cute little Italian restaurant located on the upstairs floor of a Victorian house...what more do you want? Perfect for a nice intimate dinner with loved ones or a first date. The decor is splendid, the lightening is soft and each table has candles. Sometimes they even project old black and white movies in the background - truly beautiful. The food is superb. Being Italian I can be really picky when it comes to "Italian" places in the states. But this place is on point. I started with the pappa pomodoro. It was delicious. Such a nice, comforting and warming tomato sou, which truly seemed like it had been made out of love. Then I had pappardelle bolognese...another hit! All of their pasta is homemade and boy can one tell the difference. The service was spot on and the low noise level made it a truly wonderful evening. Highly recommend for a more calm and relaxing nice Italian dinner!
author: Sami F.

description: This is some of the most disgusting Italian food you will find in this city, and the price point is just unbelievable given the quality of food you get. Catering to unsuspecting tourists and patrons of nearby cultural establishments like the Castro Theatre who have no idea how they are being taken advantage of and will likely never see this place again. I can't advise people strongly enough to give this place a very wide berth. There are so many great restaurants in S.F. that deserve your hard-earned money so much more than Poesia. Funny how much that sounds like "poison" -- there's a reason for that.
author: Katherine R.

description:
Great dining experience. We were promptly seated at a cozy corner next to bookshelves and a curtained window. It was a very homey environment and the food was top notch. I'm glad we ordered antipasti appetizers (grilled fresh calamari and mussels), as they proved to be excellent.  Although or mains, a scallop and mussel risotto, was a bit under cooked, the ingredients and overall taste was delicious. The flavors were light and nuanced, and the aesthetic presentation was beautiful.

Service was excellent and attentive. Overall, a superb experience!
author: Andy S.

description:
My girlfriend and I ate at Poesia last week while we were visiting San Francisco. Overall, the service was HORRIBLE and everything was over-priced for the quality and amount of food. Their main problem is that the owner thinks he can handle everything himself. We stood at the door waiting to be seated for over 15 minutes (we had a reservation) when there were numerous empty tables and a few "servers" standing around doing nothing. I put "servers' in quotes, because the owner barely let either of them touch a plate, check presenter, or seat any customers. They basically filled our water and cleared our plates, but otherwise were not allowed to do anything at the restaurant. Not a single female was employed here, which we also thought was odd. We could tell after standing by the door for 5 minutes that this place runs poorly because the owner tries to act like a big shot and do everything himself. We considered leaving, and I really wish we had.  We literally waited 20 minutes to even order drinks, which came out AFTER our food. No one came by once to ask how our food was or see if we needed anything. We sat there for at least 20 more minutes after we finished eating before anyone cleared our plates... We sat for another 30 minutes before getting our check, which we had to ask for. 
In general, we felt dismissed by the owner- maybe because we are young-looking, or maybe because we have tattoos. We were dressed very nicely, acted very polite, and did nothing to deserve the owner's smug demeanor. If you're in San Francisco and want homemade italian food, please eat ANYWHERE ELSE! We were extremely disappointed.
author: A.J. M.

description:
I'm picky, so I would actually say 3.8. The food is good, but it is pricy for what it is. The wait staff was attentive and the wine was good. The ambiance was cozy. I would definitely visit more if it weren't so pricy. 

The olive oil was delicious, the bread was average. 
The lamb pasta was nice and creamy, yummy!

Definitely above average, but not amazeballs.
author: Jamie T.

description:
Our meal at Poesia was mediocre.  The service was capable and all servers were attentive, but the price of the food is out of line with the quality.  I will not be returning.

We ordered the Antipasto, the Orecchiette with Eggplant & Pine Nuts, a salmon filet.  None of these dishes stood out.  Food wasn't bad, but it wasn't good and certainly not worth the 16 to 22 per entree price point.

Service was good, friendly and fast, but a bit disorganized.

Setting was nice.  Felt cozy and the classic foreign films projected on the walls were a nice touch.
author: Jonathan T.

description:
I hate repeating history...but it happens.  I've been here twice now and as much as I want to give it 4 stars, I can't.

The first time I came here I ordered an orechiette pasta that sounded awesome but when it came out it was so covered in cheese and dripping with olive oil that it really wasn't very good :(  The next time I ate here...yup, I ordered an orechiette pasta that sounded good (cauliflower, shitake, walnut pesto, why not?) and when it came out it was totally blanketed in cheese.  I could hardly identify what was cauliflower and what was cheese.  So sad.

The branzino (sea bass) was pretty tasty though.  Apps were ok, but not amazing.

Service is 4 stars though!
author: Priscilla T.

description: came here with my friend and her mother and the food was absolutely amazing! The service is very good and all the staff are very friendly. We started off with urrata con prosciutto stagionato e asparagi which is Fresh burrata cheese served with aged Parma Prosciutto and crostini bread. then we werent quite sure what we wanted so the head chef actually came out and helped us decide and she was very friendly. We ended up ordering 3 plates and all splitting. I got a Lamb shank and fettuccine, and the others got an Eggplant Parmigiana, and home made beet pasta with gorgonzola cheese, walnuts and radicchio. for dessert i got a cannolo and a cappuccino. Everything i ate was phenomenal, there is absolutely nothing ad i can say about this place or the food. By far my favorite was the lamb shank it was os favorable, its a must have!
author: Leeron B.

description: We came here with a small group and greatly enjoyed our meal.  The ambiance was great, the food was good, and the service was prompt.  We will definitely be back.
author: Scott And Jim H.

description: Went for Dinner after getting a recommendation from the bartender at Martuni's. This is a great italian place and Lorenzo was wonderful. It was my partners birthday and we felt right at home. The food was awesome and the decor was nice also. I would definately go back.
author: Michael L.

description:
Come here on sunday evening for dinner using voucher from Bloomspot. 
It was a bit hard to find a parking space in the area. 
I have to say that the pasta were very fresh. The portion was a bit small, but still filling. The service was good. Our server is very attentive. Things that i didn't like from the whole experience was the canollo (dessert) and we had to wait sometimes for the fresh pasta.

For the overall experience , i will give 4 stars.
author: Ira A.

description: It boggles my mind that this place has four stars on here and that it continues to stay in business. I have dined here a total of two times the most recent being approximately one year after the first. Both visits resulted in the same outcome--extremely mediocre food thats over salted and takes approximately 75 minutes to arrive at your table. The manager or host--I couldn't tell who he was has a pronounced air of indifference. The server to his credit was friendly, but overwhelmed. Do yourself a favor and go elsewhere. Life is too short to be waiting so long for such disappointing food.
author: Luis H.

description:
Nice ambiance.  Food was good but not as exceptional as some claim. Somehow the different elements don't merge - the calamari had interesting spices but ultimately it was not really a dish in itself. The pasta with lamb ragù was OK but the lamb pieces did continuously separate themselves from the pasta dish - it just did not "jive". The cosy place may intrigue some who are used to the bland style of most US restaurants but with so many options in the City, I see no reason to go back. For the food go to Zuni Cafe (noisier, bigger, much better food). We skipped the panna cotta that had a bit too many additional ingredients for my taste. Bergamotte oil anyone?

Coffee was not offered - so one less decision. Wine - not worth mentioning.

Across the street was a (their) Giannini 590 GT parked - so this was a nice after-dinner photo experience. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giannini_Automobili.
author: Flo B.

description:
My boyfriend and I went to Poesia the other night because I had purchased a Living Social deal that was offered. After reading the reviews, and even watching the owners video on the website, I was so excited to try the place out! 

The food was absolutely delicious and the waitress was very friendly. The only thing that did bother me was the owner himself.
