The restaurant was not very crowded, and the owner went around from table to table to make sure that they were enjoying their food/experience. However, the ONLY  table he did not come check on was ours. I am pretty sure it is because we had a living social deal! I saw the waitress show him our certificate, point to which table we were at,  and watched the owner make a face about it!  ... I would have definitely come back to the restaurant without the deal, but now that I know the owner is so snobby... i might think twice about it.
author: Meagan B.

description:
I really like Poesia, but the service is hit and miss. We had a three hour dinner here last weekend- and not for a good reason, but because service took f-o-r-e-v-e-r! 

Great food, but service has to improve for this to be a really stellar experience.
author: Rebecca A.

description:
I came with a deal, but realized later that I didn't "need" the deal since we would have equally as  happy with a shared appetizer and 2 entrees, and didn't need the extra appetizer + 2 desserts (dessert is not their forte).

My date ordered a kale salad, which I thought would be a mistake, but hey we had a coupon right? This turned out to be super tasty, and I stole a good bunch. I got the grilled squid to start, then the steak. It was cooked perfectly and the blue cheese sauce was amazing.

The meal was so good that we felt guilty eating such decadence when there are so many who go hungry. Quite the treat! Oh, we went on a weeknight and had no trouble getting a table.
author: christine l.

description:
Decided to try it out since it had 4 stars on yelp.  

Has a very cozy feel to it.  Probably since from the looks of it, it was converted from a house.  

As one of our apps, we ordered the filet carpaccio, which came on a bed of and wrapped around arugula salad.  Firstly, it came with very little of the citrusy/vinegary sauce that usually compliments this dish.  Then the filet wasn't cut thinly enough where it felt as tho I was chewing on meat gum.  And I'm sure as many people have, after chewing and chewing and chewing, trying every teeth to grind the sucker down with no luck, I decided to swallow the gristly chunk instead of spitting it out into my napkin.  

The other app, grilled squid, on a bed of arugula again, was actually quite good.  Probably one of the better grilled squids that I've had.  Perfectly cooked to the point that is neither under-cooked mushy or over-cooked rubbery with a nice smoking grilled flavor rather than burnt bitterness.  The citrusy sauce, which seems similar to the one that came with the carpaccio, complimented it well.  

As one of our entrees, we ordered the filet, which to our surprise, came on a bed of arugula, again.  I guess we didn't read the menu carefully enough to notice that we had signed up for an arugula colon cleansing.  I don't recall the salad saying specifically that it was arugula.  I could be wrong.  Again, it came with a very similar, if not the same, citrusy sauce as the first two dishes.  Perhaps, if this was the only dish that came with it, then I could tolerate it but given all 3 came on a bed of citrusy arugula, it was hard to bare.  Even though we ordered it medium, it was quite dry and it needed some sort of a reduction sauce.   

The red snapper ravioli in asparagus sauce dish was quite good but had only 4 pieces.  My friend said that the pasta was under cooked on her first piece.  Mine seemed ok.

The desserts were good, although the tiramisu didn't quite taste like a real one.  Maybe because it was missing too many of its signature ingredients - coffee/espresso & liquor?  

The service from our friendly waiter was decent.  

I would give this restaurant a 3 star rating had it not been for what had happened AFTER our dining experience.  We couldn't quite finish the filet and the third course of arugula, so we asked for it to go.  one of the waiters took the dish to the back to, I assume, box & bag it.  Normally I expect the restaurant to bring it to the table.  Because we were focused on our conversation, after the bill had come, we left the restaurant.  After having driven far quite far, we realized that they had not given us the togo box.  

Instead of turning back for our arugula and the filet, I decided to call the restaurant to bring up the matter after getting home. When I did, the attitude that the manager had was basically, 'what do you want me to do about it?  It's just as much your fault as it is ours.  You should not have forgotten.'  I am all about being fair and only raising an issue when I feel that it's due.  Had they brought the box to me and then I had forgotten it on the table, then yes, I accept the fault as my own.  Even if the manager's excuse was true that they do not want to bring the box to the table and would prefer to give it to the customers as they leave, then it should be their duty to remember to do so, not the customers.

Restaurants should remember that they are just as much a service business.  Had they given us the right attitude, given such an on-the-fence experience with our food,  it could have tipped me in favor of trying it again and recommending positively to others.
author: Young K.

description:
Sat night, all packed. I wasn't hungry. So I only had an organic tomato salad. It was sooooo good! I'm not a cheese person, but still LOVE the cheese on the top of those very delicious tomatoes. Did I mention those are organic? Oh, yes I did. 
Service are great, ALLLLLL the people who work there are very friendly and having a warm heart. And, the white wine I had... ummm... great recommendation from them as well. A bit sweet but in a very fresh way. Who haven't try this Italian spot in SF. Gotta go, make you RSVP! Cause it's always popular during the weekend.
Did I also mention the indoor decoration? Very homey and lovely. I'm sure allll nice people just like me should like it. ;-p
author: Flora F.

description: SO disappointed in Poesia. Used to be our favorite Italian restaurant in the city. Not sure if management has changed or if everyone is on vacation this month but everything about the restaurant has changed for the worse. Poor service, bad ambiance (stopped playing the black and white movies which were so cool), flavors/overall food no longer good, and painfully slow service.
author: Christina G.

description:
My experience at Poesia was less than poetic, affirming my belief that restaurants in the Castro are tragically overrated (e.g., 2223, Lime, Woodhouse). Poesia has a nice website, but the food! Mamma mia (in a bad way)!

I really wanted to like Poesia because it was my best friend's birthday. Unfortunately, I had the squid ink pasta. Imagine something bad masked by something equally bad and you have salt cod in tomato sauce. I like squid ink pasta, salt cod, and tomato sauce individually but together they're an inedible science experiment.

I also ordered the mussels and tried the ricotta gnocchi. The mussels were ok, but I've never had bad mussels. The gnocchi was delicious, especially was its citrus sauce. If I had to return to Poesia, I would have the gnocchi, a glass of water and the check please.

For serious Italian food, I recommend Acquerello ($$$) or Tommaso ($$).  Or my lasagna. Buona notte!
author: Liz T.

description: We were greeted at the door by a very welcoming, friendly staff. Started off with a refreshing cocktail that was well crafted. Then moved on to nice Italian wines by the glass. The handmade pastas were all fantastic. The sea bass was delicate yet flavorful. Tasty Italian desserts completed a wonderful dining experience at this cozy, warm restaurant.
author: Tina S.

description: We ordered grilled squid salad, their special for the night; ravioli with fillet mignon and mushroom, lamb shank fettucini and finally tiramisu. It was delicious!
author: Shinta L.

description: Poesia is spectacular fine dining. It's a beautiful cozy restaurant. Make reservations. This is a well loved restaurant. We made reservations for 7pm and were warmly greeted before being seated. We started with the Calamari alla Griglia and the Antipasto Rustico Calabrese. The calamari was perfection. The flavor integrity of the squid was not compromised by generic beading. It was grilled beautifully, not over done and was tender and delicious. The salad that came with the calamari complimented very well. The antipasto contained a Italian cured ham that melts in your mouth. Dinner standouts were the Fileji di Renato, a house made Calabrese spiral shaped pasta with pork ribs sugo in roasted garlic tomato sauce. It brought my Italian fiancé back to his grandmother's excellent cooking. We ordered tiramisu for dessert. It was the most decadent beautiful tiramisu I've had in my life. Come for the food. Come for the experience.
author: Caroline N.

description:
I had dinner at Poesia on Thanksgiving.  We made reservations at opening on Thanksgiving and were surprised how quickly the restaurant filled up.  It was my first time eating Thanksgiving away from family so fortunately the very positive dining experience helped to offset some of the homesickness.

Ambiance:  Romantic.

Service: Friendly and very accommodating for food allergies.

Food (gluten-free dairy-free perspective): Although they state on their menu that only the Fileji di Renato can be made gluten free, the waiter said they're able to make other dishes gluten free as well (basically they use the same gluten free noodles but add the specified dish's sauce/ingredients).  That said, I ordered the Fileji di Renato because it sounded tasty...and sure enough it was!
author: G B.

description:
Squid ink pasta has no squid in it!

Squid ink pasta is dark purple pasta with tomato sauce and cod ($16).  Although this pasta dish came highly recommended on yelp, the cod and tomato sauce literally tasted like something straight out of a can.  Think canned sardines but cod.

I know you were going to get that but order something else fast!
author: Fei L.

description:
There are simply far too many other italian restaurants in the city I would frequent before I go back to Poesia.

The Pro's -
*Greeted at the door promptly by the owner who invited me to have a glass of wine at the bar while I waited for my friend to arrive.
*Appetizer - Eggplant Parmigiano was DELICIOUS.  Not breaded and fried.  Baked in the oven and seasoned just right.

The Con's
* Tried 3 different wines from the list and not one of them were to my liking.  I'm not a wine snob but, a decent glass of wine would be nice.
* Service was inconsistent.  After being seated it took a good 15 minutes for anyone to take our order.  I think the owner finally realized it and came over to do so.
* About 20 minutes before our first appetizer appeared, the olives  Don't bite the garlic because the garlic is super fresh and had not been marinated for a long period of time as I was expecting.
*Another 40 minutes before our 2 pasta entree's arrived.  No one came over to update us.  Luckily my friend and I had lots to catch up on.
*Food - both entrees were under seasoned.  Olive Gnocchi was light and fluffy but, missing something.  The Orecchiette with sausage was very spicy which I was not expecting and lacked any salt.
*Oh, the best part was the waitress offering us parmesan.  I said yes but, when my friend said yes she asked her if she was sure because in Italy they never put parmesan on shrimp dishes as it masks the taste of the seafood.  True or not, just put the parmesan that you offered her to begin with!

I wanted to love Poesia - but, I did not.
author: Denise G.

description: Slow. Not like slow food slow but disorganized, inept service slow. Took about 15 min for our order to be taken (no waiters in sight, had to flag down manager to take order). After waiting an hour between appetizers and main entrees (for a table for 2) we left without eating dinner.
author: Urban C.

description: Absolutely delicious with a quaint, romantic ambiance.  I've been here twice now - once at the bar and once at a table, both experiences were met with stellar customer service.  Alex the bar tender from MN is so charming and hospitable.  The owner, Franchesco, is often present and always smiling which to me is huge.  I like support in a true locally owned restaurant.   The calamari is a must, fennel salad, and home made pastas are all mouth watering.  You will leave happy , trust me !! Going back tonight in fact.   **Finish with an above average coffee and the dark chocolate mousse with sea salt and olive oil !!!
author: T L.

description:
Excellent Italian place!

I went to Poesia on a sexy date night with my girl, and it was just what we both wanted it to be. The restaurant is really small, located on the second story of this little structure, and its quaint. The service was not rushed at all, which is great for a sit-down dinner. The bottle of wine we decided on (Fratelli Barbera) was extraordinary! I have not have many italian wines ouside of Chianti, which was barely on the wine list at all, but both of us really savored it. The food varies in portions, so ask if you want to know the size of the plate you get with a particular item. I had the fresh squash ravioli, which were something different than the usual meat cheese shell ravioli, and hella tasty. My girlfriend had some sort of very rich fettucini. The cannoli dessert special was small, but very delicious. 

This place exceeded our expectations, and it really made our night great! Thanks to the chef and wait staff for making this place so nice for us!
author: Alexander W.

description: Authentic Italian, laid-back place.  Slightly humid inside.  Video of some Bond knock-off playing on a large projector screen next to our table.
author: daisy s.

description: Such a great place to eat! The staff is amazing and so sweet and the food is to die for! Also, awesome cocktails! Will definitely be going back here!
author: Holly Z.

description:
Such a great, cute, romantic restaurant in the Castro...you actually feel like you're in someone's home.

The food was very good - we shared a cream-based vegetarian pasta, beet salad and baked trout...everything was very good.  The pasta was creamy, but not too greasy and had some great subtle flavors.  The beet salad, something I usually wouldn't order was good and the presentation was excellent - despite the goat cheese, it still lacked a bit of the salt that would have brought out the flavor of the beets.  The trout, one of their specials of the evening, was really good too - perfectly cooked fish, great texture and fresh flavors that came from simple ingredients like olive oil, lemon, vegetables and garlic - the taste of the fish was fantastic.  

The service was attentive and very good.  I'd definitely recommend this place for a romantic date or an evening to have a great meal in a nice setting where you can really talk to your companion.

Very good wine list as well.
author: Ken G.

description: Got lost trying to find it, it's upstairs. Cute spot. The service was ok, no complaints. I got the prawns and race and it was a little bland. It could have used a little more flavor. My boyfriend and a couple friends got the calamari and loved it.
author: Jamie B.

description: Best Italian restaurant in the whole Castro... Great staff and friendly!
author: Ron K.

description: Amazing!!!!! it was a great restaurant, very nice and friendly staff and atmosphere, the cocktails and mixed drinks and cocktails by Gianni were amazing! food was fantastic! it was 10 of us and we had a really fun and amazing experience! totally recommend it!
author: Leila K.

description:
Oh yelp! How you steered me wrong!

I went to go to another restaurant and yelp directed me to Poesia instead.  We arrived just past our 8:45pm reservation, and it was clear that had we arrived on time we would not have been seated immediately anyways. So it took about 15 minutes to get our table (why even take a reservation?)

Service was pretty slow. From getting water, drinks, bread, taking our order, etc. But whatever, we can over look some of that.

For apps we ordered the burratta cheese and the gnocci.  I wish I could review the burratta, because about 15 minutes later he came and told me they were out of it. Which is really bad.  I mean as a server you should know what you have and what you dont.  So we ordered the carpaccio instead. About another 15 minutes later it arrived.  The gnocci was pretty fantastic (the only redeeming thing about the night) the carpaccio was good... but not amazing. 

Food was not flying out of the kitchen, even though they were pretty busy. It took about 25 minutes or so for our next course. I mean come on... its pasta.. no pasta takes that long to boil.

I got the squid ink ravioli with crab meat and pesto.  It was above average, but VERY small.  4 raviolis does not make a meal. My husband got the seafood spaghetti. This was the goldilocks seafood.  The shrimp were overcooked (way rubbery).  The mussels were under cooked (two of the four were not opened) Thats just BAD to send that out of the kitchen.  The chef should be embarrassed that was sent out, and the clams were good.  The spaghetti was sub-par.

The waiter never came to check on our first couple of bites (thats just standard service) and we were never offered parma cheese for our pasta, even though every table around us was offered it when their food was dropped off.

At this point we just wanted out, it was almost an hour and a half of eating very little food, with very poor service.  It was just inattentive. I had my credit card out for like 5 minutes to pay, and he offered to bring the bill, I was like "no please just run it".

I NEVER leave a bad tip, but I thought 8% was pretty generous, looking back I wish I could take some of the tip away. And the sad thing is that he probably didn't realize why his tip was so low.  As we left, no good byes from the waiter, manager, hostess, it was just bad.  I would give 0 stars if you could. Over an hour and a half for Italian food?  there is a difference between slow paced service and SLOW service

Great location, cute decor, but horrible service and mediocre food.
author: David P.

description: Wonderful dining experience and service. My friend and I arrived at 9.45pm on a Sunday night. Since the restaurant closed at 10.30, we felt pretty awkward with the late dining time thinking the restaurant staff would be eager to close up and go home. Immediately they put us at ease and were attentive. The food was amazing and the Calamari was the best I had ever had; it melted in the mouth. At the end of dinner, a member of staff, a gentleman with glasses, came over with our aperitif and gave us many eating and tourist suggestions - a delightful man. I hope to visit again in the future for amazing homemade pasta.
author: Nicky D.

description: The food was delicious, but we honestly didn't have a very good dining experience at Poesia. Although we had a reservation, it took over 5 minutes for anybody to even acknowledge our presence at the restaurant. Might have something to do with the fact that there was no actual greeter -- it was apparently the bartender's job and he was too busy making drinks. We then had to wait over 15 min. to be seated (we arrived on time...). The restaurant is totally cramped. No space whatsoever. I felt like the crowded atmosphere and spotty service made it difficult to really enjoy the food, which was unfortunate.
author: Laurent L.

description: Ate here for the first time last week.  Totally loved it.  The food is fantastic and prepared with very fresh ingredients.  What really made the experience wonderful was the service.  Marney was so gracious and helpful with selecting our dinner choices and wine.  I would come back just for her.
author: Jerry O.

description: Excellent atmosphere and food! It was very cozy and noise level was perfect. Their calamari (not fried) was delicious and not rubbery. I had their roasted chicken and was very moist and full of flavor. Check this place out!
author: Ron M.

description:
Arrived a few minutes before our reservation time. Two fairly drunk guys showed up just after us with no reservation and one of the guys whispered to the host that he planned to spend a lot of coin (which he did - the cheeseball ordered all of most expensive items as well as a bottle of Barolo - just because it was "the best"). Not only did the host seat this group first, they tended to them very quickly, while we sat, just hoping for a cocktail. A little later a girlfriend of theirs joined--she was particularly classy: whenever she leaned over she showed us her nipples. Lovely.

Incredibly hot in the restaurant, little ventilation. Service took forever, just to get water.

The food was actually very good, and very authentic. But the restaurant was so hot and the service so terrible, we left without getting desert or more drinks.

While the food is good, if you're planning a nice dinner, don't do it at Poesia.

Better yet, go directly across the street to Eureka Valley.
author: Pat T.

description:
This review assesses the diner's ability to stay paleo at Poesia. If you're not doin' the Paleo and not even interested in trying it, you'll get little out of the following.

Though half of Poesia's dishes contain dairy and nightshades and you have to turn down the bread, Francisco does a ton right from the Paleo perspective: first, he doesn't fry many entrees, but what he does fry up he fries up in palm oil. This is almost unheard of in San Francisco--despite the health and food cultures here, most places fry everything in PUFA oils at best, trans-fatty partially hydrogenated vegetable oils at worst. (Rice Bran Oil, hugely inflammatory to the joints, is becoming standard operating procedure thanks to vegan influence.) Not here.

Notes: 'Arancino' (pronounced with a "chino") is a ball of rice and provolone, breaded and fried, and Poesia serves it. Oh, and the cod cakes use potato as a thickener--not dairy or gluten. Not even a problem for Paleo 2.0/Archevore. That's pretty much it. Francesco and his staff will mod your meals to exclude what you don't want without complaint, so if you want to stay strict paleo, you can. It's pretty easy because the meals seem to have sort of a healthy-meats-and-fats base already. For instance: Francesco's 'Lemon's House Dressing' is olive oil, lemon juice, red onion and chilis. If you go Primal and do the cheese, nobody can guarantee it's all grass-fed. But it's at least from mostly Italian or Californian sources.

The assessments I got:
The Mugellano cheese (usually made from sheep's milk) is imported from Mugello, Italy, and 3 weeks old. It's at least partially grass-fed.

His Goat cheese is from Sonoma: could well be grain-fed, it turns out.

His burrata's from Southern California, so it's either Di Stefano or Gioia, which both disclose nothing about animal-feeding practices. Have to assume grain-fed.

His Compagna cheese is from Compagna, Italy. Again--taking chances with grain and legume content from the buffalos' diets, but it's likely to be grass-fed.

His ricotta and parmesan: Unknown. Finally, I'll link you to a guide to Italian cheeses: http://www.italfoodsinc.com/images/cataloguePDF/2011%20Cheese%20Guide.pdf

But cheese is like that. It's almost impossible to find grass-fed. With Francesco you're at least in better hands than most. And dairy isn't Paleo anyway; this site isn't called PrimalFinder. Point being: if you want to stay Paleo they'll gladly leave the dairy, grains, legumes and nightshades out of anything. It's separable like home cooking.
author: Matt L.

description:
Pros:
- My boyfriend and I both had 3 courses (prixe fixe menu) because of a Living Social deal. 
- We ordered these as appetizers: Sardine alla Griglia (not bad, no bones, smells fishy but doesn't taste fishy at all) and Parmigiana di Melanzane (eggplant was really good in the tomato sauce, really filling because it was a pretty cheezy dish)
- My main course:  Pollo alla Griglia in Salsa Piccante (Grilled free range half chicken, lemon & thyme)--THE BEST GRILLED CHICKEN I HAVE EVER HAD!!!  You have to order this dish.  It comes with potatoes and kale as sides.  The chicken skin was crispy and so were the potato skins.  The spices were so well-mixed and flavorful, I wish I was able to finish it all...but I got full fast.
- His main course: Fileji di Renato (Corkscrew pasta with braised pork ribs, tomato sauce)--I didn't like the texture of the pasta so much because it was a little bit hard to chew, but it went ok with the fall-off-the-bone meat from the ribs.
- Our desserts: Red Velvet Tiramisu and his Orange Marmalade Cake--mine had too much cream because there were about 3-4 layers of the lady finger red velvet cake and each layer had the cream filling in between.  It was a little too much.  His Orange Marmalade cake was really good--tasted similar to a Tres Leche cake with a zest of tangy orange flavor.
- I also enjoyed the decor and ambiance inside the restaurant because it's technically a victorian house that they turned into a restaurant.

Cons:
- They should make the desserts less creamy with all the fillings because it's too much to consume at the end when you're already full.
- Pricey place, but well worth to try at least once...especially if you have a living social or groupon, or one of those deals.
- Parking is hard to find in the neighborhood, so go on a Sunday if you don't want to worry about constantly leaving the restaurant to go feed the meter since it's meters are free on Sundays (for now at least...).
author: Wendy T.

description:
An amazing gem in the Castro.  I suggested dinner there with two friends who also had birthdays that month and we were very happy.  The food is authentic Italian, well-prepared and just wonderful.  I'm not usually a dessert person, but given the occasion we all indulged in a different dessert -- WOW, each bite was a delight in itself.  

Atmosphere is more sophisticated than the usual Castro haunts -- quieter too, so you can converse without shouting. My only complaint might have been our waiter ... attentive, but a bit smug and condescending (bordering on insulting a couple of times). I had exactly the same service in a 5-star restaurant in Florence, so in a way it just added to the Italian authenticity, lol.

 "Poesia" translates from Italian into "poetry," and that is indeed what they offer with their authentic take on the food.  A few bucks more than most restaurants in the area but worth every penny. I'm looking forward to returning.
author: John Z.

description: Great appetizers. Squid, mussels, bruschetta. Just right portions. Very quaint ambiance.
author: Tammy T.

description: Best place in the Castro! Ophra comes here when she is in town!  Great italian cousine, very friendly staff, Franchesco (owner) is the best!
author: Ben P.

description:
My first 5 star review ever.  Why because everything had that je ne sais quoi, from the appetizer to the vino, from the the pasta to the desert.  Probably as close as you will get to Italy in San Francisco.

About once a year I will finish eating a meal and think that I want to order an individual desert for both my wife and I,  instead of sharing, and not because I'm still hungry, but because each part of the meal was so good and this is my last chance to not miss things off the menu.

Again if you are not a gourmand and have not been to Italy or Europe and don't have a palette  to appreciate the little nuances that add to authenticity, then this may not be the place for you.  Instead you may want to try the Sausage Factory, Pomodoro's, or Olive Garden.  But for those of you that have a palette for food, wine and little details that make an authentic italian restaurant so appreciable then try this place.
author: Ryan S.

description: Awesome food and great friendly service. The quality of the food ranks among the best I've ever had in any Italian restaurant, those in the Motherland included. I started with Crostini di Burrata, in which the whipped burrata with hints of lemon was an excellent delicate match for the artichokes. The main course, however, was even better: Fileji di Renato, a typical calabrese homemade pasta that was cooked to an al dente perfection, and served with a tasty and abundant pork sugo. I would return to Poesia even simply to enjoy that dish again. What makes this restaurant exceptional, in my view, is that their menu goes well beyond the conventional "Italian" fare to offer truly delicious regional specialties, prepared at a really high level. The owner Francesco and all the staff are extremely friendly and welcoming. A great discovery that will be a must-go for all my future San Francisco trips.
author: Marco D.

description: You're not a fan of Poesia's calamari? Unless it is midnight and some questionable decisions have led me to crave such a dish, i'll pass, too. I am not above the gut-busting pleasures of so-called stoner cuisine. But with every gastropub and pork-crazed spot in this foodie city taking up the mantra "more is more", when it comes to flavor,  l've had my fill. Remember when appetizers were meant to stimulate the appetite?  Now they often bludgeon them. Not at Poesia. No over-the-top calories or gimmick here. No over-the-top flavor trumps subtlety and can cover up bad technique and a lack of imagination. I am so glad Poesia offers beautiful food...it is not trying to be like Joel Robuchon or Jean Gorges and such likes or calling for the next incarnation of nouvelle cuisine.  It is simply simple, being simple, showing off just a little moderation and a lot more creativity, understandable and digestible flavors. This is more than an awesome restaurant in the gayest part of the city, it is very homely (in an old Victorian home, no less), and very pretty. Definitely a get a table for two!
author: Ambrose A.

description: Pleasantly surprised by this Castro gem.  Made reservations on a Saturday night with the BF and family.  All the food was excellent, decent portions, great service, and the basil cocktail was yummy and refreshing! I would definitely go back!
author: Selene L.

description:
3.5

Blueberry Manhattan- good
Mussels- fantastic, plump and fresh
Artichoke cake- fine
Insalata Verde- good
Squash Blossom farfale- good
Artichoke Orecchiette- good
Pork ribs pasta- meat was a bit tough, pasta was good
Chocolate cake- awesome

So, after having a hard time deciding where to go, we ended up at Poesia since my friend wanted pasta and we were going to hit the Castro bars.

I loved that this was upstairs and they were showing old movies on the walls. The service was very nice, very Italian. I could tell they had a lot of regulars so reservations are a good idea.
author: Min T.

description:
Reservations for a Fri night - we had to wait a bit, but not of serious note.  Just a few minutes in the cramped vestibule, squeezing in and out to let people by.
Our table was very close to the table next to us.  For as close as the tables are and the size of the dining area, the noise was manageable - we were able to talk and be heard by each other without too much convo leakage between us and our neighbors.

 BF and I shared the Grilled Calamari (YUM!) and a kale salad, which I expected to be chewy, but it wasn't and the dressing was a nice balance.   The Dungeness Crab ravioli was good, but could have used a little salt (no problem - they brought us some!).  Unfortunately, our pork dish was not fall-off-the-bone tender...in fact there wasn't really a lot of edible meat on it.  We did mention this to our server and I expect this isn't the norm.  She gave us some biscotti, which was a nice gesture.   Our white wine came to the table almost room temperature -  no problem, she brought an ice bucket then came by a few times to see how we were doing. 

The service was very nice, a bit slow, but this also isn't a place where you'll be rushed out.  Things move at a slow but steady clip and for a busy restaurant, they keep it going without being frenetic.

I would probably come back to try out some of their other dishes when I want a nice dinner out and want to stay in the neighborhood, but I'm afraid it doesn't get a top rating.
author: Maria C.

description: The new bartender, the little one, is suuuper hot. Also he made great drinks, try the Satirico!
author: Galen T.

description: Lovely atmosphere, delicious food, fabulous drinks, and a wonderful staff.  A group of 5 of us dined there last night and it was a great experience.  Everyone was attentive to us and even though we were a bit rowdy, they just kept serving us a fantastic dinner.
author: Michelle P.

description: Another great place in Castro with great selection of Italian wines and good service!  we got couple of starters that were great specially the PIPI CHINI. for main course we had the FETTUCCINE AL RAGU' DI AGNELLO & RAVIOLI DI CARNE MAGRA CON FUNGHI both of which were above average but not amazing. over all I will go back to this place specially since you can get in easy not like some of other similar spots in SF that you have to have reservation a week in advance!
author: Arash H.

description:
This is such a cool place, located right in the heart of the Castro in what at one time was an apartment/home. Everyone was very friendly and the owner was always there to make sure everyone was having a great experience.

I really enjoyed the Ricotta Cheese Gnocchi and the Pollo alla Griglia. My friend started with the Bresaola and had the Filet as her entree she loved both, the portions were large and we both had some delicious leftovers for the next day. The menu does change every few weeks.

We had purchased a 3 course meal for 2 from Living Social which included an appetizer, entree & dessert with a glass of wine. Really a great deal. 

They are closed on Tuesdays.
author: Scott F.

description: I celebrated 50th birthday here. Thank you Alex for being a great wait service and making our evening at Poesia most enjoyable. The happy hour drinks definitely recommendable! We loved the risotto nero, even when it makes our tongue go dark. Will definitely come here again.
author: MLovely R.

description: Was here on September 2, 2014. Again had a great meal. The squid ink risotto was great and the roasted cauliflower was amazing. Highly recommend this restaurant.
author: Paul P.

description:
Can you pronounce chrysanthemum? I can't. i can't even spell it. My biggest nightmare would be to have to stand in front of a large group at a flower convention and give a 2 hour lecture on chrysanthemums.

Just like the word Chrysanthemum, I have issues with the Italian language. Spanish, I am pretty good, French? I can sneak by, I have even gone as far as learning a few phrases in Farsi and Russian. But there is something about the birth place of the Latin language that gets my tongue tied. This probably explains my fear of Italian wine. But recently I found an Italian spot that has helped ease my fear.

We were in search of a dinner spot off the beaten track to host a casual business dinner. One of my coworkers suggested Poesia. So we all hoped in a cab and made our way to the Castro. Even though this was last minute, they were able to accommodate a table of six for an early dinner. We arrived shortly before 6:00 and were seated right away. Our server quickly came over and took drink orders and glasses of Prosecco and Pinot Grigio were quickly brought over. 

Drink time helped us study the interesting menu filled with creative dishes. One look and you will say "yes please" to everything. We narrowed the table down to four delicious starters, the calamari served with Monterey Bay Fresh Squid and baby arugola was delectable and the Gnocchi Silani was mouthwatering. Both of these dishes stood out and were the favorites. 

I saved room for dessert and passed on the second course and went straight for my main entree. I was told the pasta dishes were not to be missed so I concentrated on this portion of the menu. I decided the Orecchiette al Forno was the best choice and even though I completely butchered the pronunciation I was quickly forgiven and given a standing ovation for just attempting to say it. The Orecchiette pasta was perfectly cooked to al dente and it left no doubt in my mind that it was house made fresh that day. The pasta came served with Radicchio, Provolone Compano, and walnuts. This was a perfect combination and the flavor of each ingredient came through like a shining star.

Poesia won me over and if you are looking for something with a neighborhood feel, but still has a classy big city vibe look you need not look any further and make a reservation here.
author: V B.

description: We really like the food here, but the service is so spotty. Nice people but can be very slow sometimes.
author: R. S.

description:
The food is very good and I'm glad to have been introduced to this nice gem thanks to a Living Social or Groupon coupon (don't remember which now).  It is upstairs and looks to be in a former home, but the decor is quite nice with frescoe like faux finished walls in warm colors.

The table behind us seated about a dozen people, so they have room for a large group, and it was still nice just the two of us.
author: Miss C.

description: I love Poesia, which I found by accident just walking by one day.  I liked the menu posted on the street and decided to try it...lovely little place, good atmosphere, VERY good food, decent prices, good friendly service...and consistent! Great alternative to all the silly hoopla of North Beach Italian!
author: Richard B.

description: If you like Filet Mignon, go no further. Medium Rare is how I asked for it and it could not taste any juicier.  It was cooked exactly medium rare.  The beef was very high quality.  I can say I was in a state of ecstasy when I took my first bite.
author: Joey C.

description:
My first trip to Poesia was truly excellent, but after my second I don't know that I'd ever go back or could recommend them.

 I had reservations for 9:30pm on 12/31, and arrived a few minutes early.  When I checked in with the host he confirmed my reservations and explained they were a bit behind, but that a bunch of tables would be getting up shortly and we'd be seated.  The restaurant was literally overflowing with people waiting and looking extremely unhappy, with more people piling in every five minutes or so.  

By 10:10, seven two-person tables had become free.  Since I could see on their computer that I was fourth in line to be seated (after other two person tables) I assumed I was set.  Instead, the tables were combined so two large groups could be seated.  The owner and host (understandably busy on New Years Eve) seemed un-phased when, at 10:25, I asked how much longer the wait would be.  Since I had plans for after dinner (which I assumed would be by 11, with a 9:30 reservation) I had to leave--starving and extremely disgruntled.  

For a fairly classy restaurant, it's very disappointing to see that they could have such poor service.  They clearly overbooked and were not turning a single arriving party away.  My New Years Eve started off on totally the wrong note because of this, and I'd have at least expected some concern instead of the host seeming relieved that somebody was taking themselves out of the waiting list.
author: Danny G.

description: I have traveled in Italy and find Poesia as authentic and Italian as it comes here in The Castro.  The staff have been informative and great in conversation.  You have Italian born staff as well as owners who are accommodating and will recommend dishes based on when you are not sure what to have.  The appetizers are prepared with beautiful presentation as well as combining the ingredients to bring out flavors that you wil not believe.  The portions are perfect and the experience you will not forget.  It is refreshing to find an authentic Italian restaurant that makes me feel I am back in Italy.
author: Roger T.

description: Highly recommend the beef carpaccio and tomato soup!
author: Frankie L.

description:
I've been here a few times now, and it never seems to take me over the edge.  Very authentic feel, great interior (except on a hot day where it can get as hot as a crotch) with staff speaking as if their mammas drove them to work right after getting off the boat.  But it's all about food in my eyes so here we go:

It's just too bland for me, and very simply prepared.  If this is your thing then fine; however, if this is your thing and you love to spend a fortune, then you'll love this place.  It's just overpriced for what you get.  Dishes are served in the trendy huge plate with a nugget o' food in the middle.  

Gnocchi, good, but people were raving it was the cats meow.  I got some squid ink risotto which actually was really nice...what wasn't nice was the price tag.  Once again, the key take away is the price doesn't match with the quality.

Simply put: there's nothing special about this place.  I'd put it in a league like A16 where the hype blinds people into believing it is what they think.  There is much better Italian in town, like Delfina right down the road.
author: A A.

description:
Poesia is a new Calabrese restaurant in the Castro and was the perfect spot to celebrate a birthday last night (Happy birthday, LP!) I called early in the week and had no problem booking a table for 10 although once word gets out I imagine it'll be hard to get any sort of reservation, much less one for a large party.

First off - the food ranged from good to fantastic. We ordered a bunch of appetizers to share and the clear winner was the burrata. Oh burrata, how I love your creamy, cheesy goodness. As for the entrees, everything was fantastic. My fusilli featured a pork ragu that literally melted in my mouth. And the other items that I tried - from the orecchiette to the gnocchi to the cod were all really tasty.
And while I'm trying to lay off desserts (I'm watching my girlish figure)
the tiramisu was some of the best I've tried.

So why only four stars? Service was a bit hit or miss. Our waitress was awesome, joking around with us and quick with recommendations (plus she gave great massages) But in other areas, service was lacking. Our bread was never refilled and we constantly had to ask for more water - actually, I don't remember seeing a busser on the floor. One other note, one of our entrees was undercooked (rare chicken = bad) Our waitress apologized profusely and the chef even came out to apologize. They brought out a new order of chicken and assured us that we wouldn't be charged. Nice touch.

Poesia is so close to five stars that it hurts. I will definitely return and if the few bumps in service improve I won't hesitate to award them that fifth star.
author: phil h.

description: Blink and you might miss the entrance to Poesia, and that would be a real loss. It's next door to Brandy Ho's, up a small staircase and inside a lovely townhouse that lends the feel of dining at a friend's place. The food is great, the pasta dishes especially are expertly prepared and generously sized. The silent black and white films played on the wall add a romantic touch.
author: Marie F.

description:
The space is beautiful and romantic, and the service excellent (we had a cute and charming waiter with whom my mom inadvertently flirted). It was a moderately buzzing Sunday night, and they were happy for us to linger for a few hours, several courses and bottles of wine: my favorite style of dining. 

We were a mixed-dietary-restrictions crowd -- my step-dad likes straightforward meaty Italian, my mom's a vegetarian, and I'm a vegan -- but they were able to accommodate all of us. Delicious vegan mushroom risotto for me, adapted from a vegetarian daily special.
author: Erin G.

description:
Very slow service. Even though we had a reservation for 9 p.m ,we waited 15 minutes to get seated. 

I did not like my appetizer(gabanzo soup) and sweet dish (hot choclate with figs) but my entree(fish) was great.
author: Parmeet K.

description: Success is spoiling this little restaurant. Now charging $1.00 a person for "table cloth, bread, and olive oil" according to maitre d' tonight. His exact statement. Was one of our favorites. Been going since they opened. Will take a pass in the future.
author: Jim M.

description: Too small, food is too mundane, and just was not a good dining experience at all! For the price, I expected much much more.
author: Bradley V.

description:
They have such amazingly delicious olive oil, it's terrifying. It should be illegal, it's that tasty...and same goes for the drinks and even the basket of bread!

Our meals were tasty, but not earth-shatteringly delicious, and the service was a little slow for such a small space. I had the beet ravioli and they were pretty good, as was the eggplant parmesan. My dining companions had ordered lamb and fish dishes, and seemed generally happy with them , although they all agreed that our dishes were missing a little something.

The desserts were wonderful, though, and as a person who normally hates dessert, I can safely say that the ones on offer here are quite awesome.

So, overall, three stars: friendly, if slow service, decent, if not orgasmic food, and the Dante cocktail tasted like a basil-scented Jesus. I might not choose to go back on my own, but I wouldn't mind a second tasting if my friends invited me out here again. Oh, the clips from old Italian movies were really cool!
author: Liz L.

description: Come here only with Bloomspot.  We had two glasses of red wine, duck brochette, sea bass, and steak for $90.  The wine was better than I had expected.  Their wine list can get quite pricey.  Everything was okay.  The steak was good but it got cold really quickly because the windows are open.  Service here is a little cold for the price we're paying.
author: Byron L.

description:
I came here on a Friday evening, about 4-5 months ago, so my memory is rather hazy. However, I left Poesia with a very good impression and felt that I would definitely come back. The bruschetta and whole deboned fish were two thumbs way up!

The restaurant is actually a flat converted to a commercial space. It's very cozy and charming. The noise level was rather high though since everyone was crammed into the "living and dining" room of the unit. The service was really good and the staff was friendly. I used a Groupon here and there weren't any problems. Oh, parking is a huge pain. After 15-20 min. of circling around, I ended up parking about 5-6 blocks away.
author: Freckles H.

description: It's the most splendid living room I have ever dined in. Intimate, persimmon tablecloths and mustard napkins, a glass of smooth Pinot Noir, and the most adorably sweet woman with a leather tie making my dining experience as pleasant as possible. One of the best caprese salads I have ever had: heirloom tomatoes and fresh burrata - seriously would make the perfect light Monday night meal all on its own. We tried out one of their specials; baked eggplant with cheese and scallops. Great texture, big on flavor, and I really don't think I've ever had this combination of flavor before. And if I was full after those apps, my hunger was conjured back up with the site of the fettuccine with lamb shank ragu. Doesn't that just sound sexy?! Tender, melting, lovely lamb nestled in al dente fettuccine, dressed in a heart pumping red sauce. If Angelina Jolie was a pasta it would be this one, fosho! One thing that I really want to come back and try are the lamb chops and the roast chicken (lots of patrons ordered this and it looked like straight up heaven). Poesia, I heart you like no other.
author: Natasha P.

description: The food was decent and the servers were well versed on the food they were serving.  Poesia is a fun spot to feel as if you're out and about in the Castro and yet be above it all... literally.  Grab a spot by the window and watch the action happen below you outside. it's a quiet little restaurant that plays cute movies against one of their white walls in the middle of the space.
author: Kevin J.

description:
I wouldn't have noticed this amazing little Italian restaurant if I was just passing by. It's located inside a house on a lively Csstro neighborhood where everything else is just on street level. We made a RSVP at 8 pm on a busy Friday night, got seated about 10 minutes after. Not a big deal, considering how packed the restaurant was that night.

Food is excellent and service is efficient. Nice ambiance-low, warm lighting, and simple, homey decor. We ordered the arugula & fig salad, beet and ricotta ravioli, mediterranean deboned seabass, and dark chocolate mousse with seasalt and extra virgin olive oil.

I would definitely come back.
author: Rika P.

description: This is just a review of their pasta bolognese as that's all I've tried.  I was craving a good bolognese (dreaming of the one from Madeo in Los Angeles or Max Soha in NY.)  I found Poesia on yelp as I'd never noticed it despite the hundreds of times I've walked down 18th street.  The take out process was quick and easy (the staff was friendly) and it's so close to me that I wish I had liked it more.  Next time I'm craving pasta I'll hope I can get into Emmys, Deflina, La Ciccia, Locanda, Perbacco, SPQR or Flour + Water.
author: Christina M.

description:
We had an excellent time here. Great staff (waitress, host, and bartender) and really friendly patrons enjoying their food!

On a Friday night it was quite packed (a good sign for this cursed location!) but we only waited 15 minutes for a table, and we were able to wait on a cozy couch in the corner with some red wine.
The entree's were divine (good flavors and not too heavy like Italian food can be) and I am elated I can get a good Canoli in my hood!
author: Nikki M.

description:
Delicious! We went on a friends recommendation, she was so right about this little place. The room atmosphere is warm, comfortable and happy! 
We started with heirloom tomato salad, calamari, and farro salad all seasoned perfectly. Main course was home made pasta with pork ragout ! did I say delicious! 
and a very nice wine list. We will be back!
author: Ray E.

description:
Ambiance: lively and cozy at the same time! It gives off a totally comfortable feel.

Staff: At first they were slow with us, we had to wait for our table and wait to order. But we figured that they were just giving us more time.

Food: Their bread and olive oil combo is very appetizing.
Sadly they ran out of the item I wanted, but I know we had a late reservation, so when I go next time I hope I am not in that situation again. However, the options that night were delicious, so I was quite satisfied.

Wines: even their more affordable wines tasted refined and accommodated our meal well.

Dessert: just the perfect touch to a good meal.

I find them very accommodating since I'm going again with a very large party this Friday.
author: archiee n.

description:
I would have never heard of this place if it wasn't for ScoutMob. Nestled in the vibrant neighborhood of the Castro, this quaint little restaurant differently made an impression on my taste buds. From the exterior, it looks like you are walking into a dinner party at a friends house. Upon walking up the steep stairs and entering the restaurant, you are greeted by a very nice hostess. My husband and were seated at a nice table right by the window. 

The cocktails were exquisite, my favorite being the fig cosmopolitan. Soooo yummy! They actually use fresh figs. It was delicious.

I really enjoyed the tomato soup to start and the filet mignon was an excellent way to end the meal. 

At the end of our meal, upon walking out, the owner of the restaurant walked us to the door, thanked us for coming by, and waved goodbye as we walked down the steps. That was very memorable!
author: Cheryl S.

description: In a word:  authentic.   When I've eaten in non - international restaurants in Italy the simplicity,  top ingredients and adherence to traditional techniques (no foam!) stands out.  Here, too.  The Calabrian pasta with fresh sardines and hot peppers was challenging because I like, don't love,  sardines;  but I would order it again for its balance of sardine nastiness offset by the heat, all moderated by the fettuccine and oil.  And by the excellent Bucci Verdicchio (I'm in the wine biz). Our table of 4 had 2 apps, 4 entrees and 2 desserts, with only an overcooked, too - thin slice of swordfish standing between this review and 5 stars.  Oh, perfect atmosphere for their regional offerings.
author: Arthur K.

description:
Excellent food, great wine list, good service.  The overall experience has been consistently excellent.  It's a great family atmosphere with lots of interesting things to eat and an evolving menu.  

The Castro is notorious for bad restaurants and this is a nice little gem that stands out.
author: Zack K.

description:
After spending an hour driving around town looking for a a Saturday date night spot, we luckily stumbled upon Poesia.  With its quaint cottage appeal, intimate lighting and inviting staircase, who could resist?

We were greeted warmly by Francesco and seated immediately at the bar, which seemed surprisingly roomier than table seating.  Our servers were most friendly and attentive.  The Burrata is scrumptious (if you love Mozzarella, check out this water-buffalo version) and the rolled Carpaccio is incredibly tasty with a perfect pairing of greens and parmigiano shavings.  Although the best part of our dinner was dessert: mascarpone chocolate mousse topped with rock salt (!) and drizzled with olive oil (!).  

Can't wait to go back !
author: Amelia C.

description:
Delicious food, charming staff, warm ambiance. 

Do what we did. Plan to meet an old friend; make reservations. Leave your partner with the kid(s) and the whole bedtime fiasco and get to the restaurant early. Snuggle up to the bar, and stare blankly at the bartender when he asks you what you'd like, because frankly just  managing to escape from the household madness in good time was a miracle and you hadn't thought about anything further. Trust the specials and the waiter's recommendations. Flirt confidently, eat and drink well, stay rooted in your seat until the floors are being cleaned around you, and then, finally, reluctantly, drag yourself home, feeling satiated and comforted.
author: Razili D.

description: What an amazing place to enjoy authentic Italien food. The home made pasta was amazing., and the tiramisu is super yummy.  Thanks to the attentive staff we had a fantastic evening in the Castro. Thank you Poesia.
author: Juju J.

description:
Love this place. Its super cozy with the decor and the silent movie on the wall. And of course the food is awesome!

we tried everything; the lamb special (beyond amazing) tomato bread soup (comforting), bean soup, squid ink ravioli, the veal (excellent) the beets, the mussels..I could go on and on..we all sampled from each others plates and it was all good, all of it from the appetizers to the desserts.

we were a big group and service was amazing. super friendly and nice and helpful. They even moved up our reservation time last minute!

Good times.
author: Tom L.

description:
It's actually Poesia that made me realize what my own criteria between 4 and 5 stars is.  You see, the food is good quality, and well executed.  The service was quite good - with the bartender coming out of his station to refill wine.  

It sure stands out in the culinary desert called the Castro, but I am not so sure it would stand out at all in North Beach.  It's good - don't get me wrong.  My ricotta souffle was extremely well executed, the pancetta was crispy, and enough meat and fat to satisfy any end of the pancetta-eating spectrum.  My filet was good - well prepared and with a good dish.  

And this is where I start having to split hairs - because they are a 4-star restaurant that could be 5.  Poesia is like a lover who rests on technique, because they're bored.  It's fantastic food served well - but without a soul.  I kept thinking that the chef wanted to serve something different.  

The well executed filet was basically a steak salad.  The ricotta soufflee was good - the pancetta was nice, meaty and crispy - but the elements of the dish were not completely integrated.  The dessert choices were boring:  the sign that the chef had given up because the customers weren't interested in interesting choices.  I took the chocolate mousse - which tried to spruce itself up with cayenne pepper, olive oil and salt.  But even taking bites out of the cayenne pepper on the plate - the passion wasn't there.

Like so much else in the castro, the bored lover put on the sexy outfit for the 60 minutes.  Like a good customer, I left the money on the nightstand, while the bored chef, looking out the window and not even remembering my name, smoked a cigarette.

I feel empty.
author: Joe S.

description:
Two Stars..... Nice place, I like how the layout was a converted house, very small though... The wait staff was very attentive and friendly, the busboys however were sincerely unprofessional. 

 I really couldn't believe that these busboys are still employed after displaying their behavior..slamming plates down and shouting, "HERE" to a server setting a table, mocking servers as they recite the specials and yelling across the restaurant to each other.... maybe in a bigger space they could get away from it, but being that anyone working there is pretty much in your space, super lame.

The food
 
Calamari alla Griglia.. really good grilled squid, really simple.

Pappa al Pomodoro con Bocconcini di Pesce (tomato bread soup) umm.. not good, pretty much tomato sauce over store bought white bread with chewy over cooked cod... These guys had killer bread on the table but used crappy bread in the "soup".. Really weird consistency. ew

Fileji di Renato- Handmade Corkscrew pasta with braised beef short rib ragu.  I liked this alot, great pasta, good flavor in the sauce, table side parm shredding nailed it...however, the beef flavor in the sauce was enough, the actual beef short rib meat itself was really chewy...no bueno..

Gnocchetti di Ricotta Gratinati in Terrina- The star of the meal!! Pillow soft Gnocchi great sauce, awesome cheese, its all melted in the oven.. make sure to ask for the Italian Pepper... its not like red pepper flake but more like spicy paprika.... makes the dish..

Tiramisu standard and good.

I did notice that moving forward from the antipasti the prices went up and portion got smaller, couldn't justify spending $20-$30 for any Secondi.. after spending $10 on tomato sauce and crappy white bread. 
after writing this review and reliving the experience....its going down to ONE STAR......I wont be back
author: Casey C.

description:
Pretty decent place and I like how the restaurant is basically in the first floor of a house, makes it feel very understated.  Service is fantastic and it is not too expensive.

Calamari alla Griglia - this is grilled/on the slightly burnt side, not a fan of the burnt/smoky taste, but it is probably one of the largest grilled squid appetizers I have ever seen; also was not a fan of getting a spoonful of olive oil when I ate the salad, even if it is lemon olive oil

Scallop over black in risotto - very yummy all around

Lamb shank ragu - bf had this, it is yummy but not my thing because it's too meaty and gammy but hey if that's your thing

Dessert - can't remember what I had, but it was a dry cake, which I am not a fan of

While it's mostly good and service is great, I also could not find myself dying to return either, I guess this is a bit of a conflicted review, but by all means, go check it out for yourself.
author: Li Y.

description: Food was amazing. I could have made a meal just on the Bruschetta. We shared the roasted beet salad, which was very fresh. The pasta is made on site and my entree was the Tagiolini Rosa which was very very good. Our waiter was even from Italy and shared his experiences. If I can't go to Italy, I had Italy brought to me. He even suggested our wine and it went perfectly with our meal. Five Stars!!!!!
author: Pamela N.

description:
We open the meal with calamari alla griglia which consists of Monterey Bay fresh grilled squid served over baby arugula with lemon olive oil.  This was nearly as delicious as the seafood stuffed squid we had for lunch albeit not as exceptional.  

For an entrée I opt for the gnocchi con ragu' di branzino e pomodorini which featured gnocchi in a fresh Mediterranean sea bass ragu, cherry tomatoes and ciro' bianco wine sauce.  It was an unfamiliar combination having fish accompany gnocchi but it was surprisingly good.  

My wife chooses the branzino al forno which has Mediterranean whole sea bass served deboned with broccoli crowns, zucchini and roasted potatoes.  This is a delectable piece of fish and the fact that it was deboned made it even better.  

Unfortunately they aren't serving what looked like an amazing cannolo I viewed on Yelp.  Therefore we select the spuma ricotta which is similar to an ice cream cake with thin layers of caramelized cake on the top and bottom and candied almonds and raisins inside.  Cinnamon sauce was drizzled on the plate.  While this wasn't my first choice it was very well presented and resulted in a tasty new dessert experience.
author: David E.

description:
I dined at Poesia based on a Recommendation of a very good friend of mine that is the chief Concierge of one of San Francisco very high end hotels. I was excited as my friend is very picky.. We did not have a reservation and waited about 30 minutes at the bar for a table even though there lots of tables available. We Sat at the Bar and ordered wine and cocktails. They had Very nice bartender who was very personable.  I thought however that the drink pour for a glass of wine was maybe 60% of normal.  more on this later. 

 I would give the wait staff five stars for friendliness and making you feel welcome.
our orders were taken and me and my partner ordered another glass of wine.
when the wine came out it was the same tiny pour as before.  it was so small that I decided not to order any more because this was a rip off to get maybe a 4oz pour for $11.00.  if you go to this  dining establishment be sure to bring your own wine and pay the corkage age of $20.00.  I wanted another glass of wine but chose not to because I would have found it upsetting to pay full price for something that was less than one would expect.

two of us ordered the salde.Insalata di Rucola  with
Baby wild arugula, bosc pears, rosemary goat cheese, citrus dressing
it was a nice salad, fresh, but nothing to write home about.

 I ordered Eggplant parmigiana, fresh mozzarella parmigiano reggiano.
it  arrived cold and I had to send it back to be properly heated. the waiter took the dish and had it heated to the proper temperature graciously.  the the tomato sauce had a lot of flavor and yes the eggplant dish had a lot of flavor. I can recommend it if they can get it right the first time without having to send it back for proper heating.

my friends had the following  dishes an a main.

1.Spaghetti allo Scoglio 
Mediterranean mussels, manila clams, calamari in a light spicy tomato sauce
very fresh and tasty. especially the  Mussels. However,  the portion was somewhat small.

2.Fileji di Renato 
Corkscrew pasta with braised pork ribs, tomato sauce
I did not taste but look very good

Pros
-Friendly and welcoming staff five Stars
-very warm and romantic environment 

cons
-ripoff wine pours-(bring your own bottle and pay the $20.00 to open. as their wine pours are mini pours.

food was good not great.  I don't think I will return.
not a bad choice but there are much better places to dine in San Francisco.
author: Glenn T.

description:
Let me explain my rating system and provide details on why this place only got one star.  You get one star for being clean and  being that all important step above McDonalds.  This place got that much right.  

The next star is for service, good service gets a star.  No star here. The service was extremely impersonal, slow--even for a saturday night,--and our server seemed entirely uninterested in our experience. It was apparent that the restaurant had no vision of what the service experience should be like so the waitstaff was left clueless.

The next star is for the food. I would describe my partner's dishes as disgusting--not a word I have ever used on yelp.  The swordfish pasta was metallic and fishy tasting and smelling with pasta like paste. My dish was okay, but greasy. Nothing remarkable about the menu or the taste combinations. Desert was forgettable, except the moment when my partner's lemon meringue made me gag because it tasted like fish. No star.

Next possible star is for ambiance.  With nice candles, white tablecloths, and a nice neighborhood feel, I expected this place to do fine in this category.  But then they sat a large, loud party next to us and it turned into a bar scene. No star. But on the right night the ambiance here might be quite nice.

Last star is if the place has something special, not this place.
author: G F.

description:
Eh.. Really. Last day to use my groupon. No openings till 9pm on a Monday night. Arrived a few minutes late, get our seat prolly 15 mins later.
Did not take us long to pick out our food. We were served small pieces of bread, with olive oil. I asked for vingerette, which NEVER came.  We ordered the grilled calamari, which was pretty burned, and dry over salad. I was very disappointed. I thought its the usual calamari. I have to say i actually enjoyed the oily salad more than the squid. Totally bummed. 
Then our entrees came, it was eh, ordered the braised pork (two tiny small piece) with probably 10-15 piece of pasta. it was yummy (braised pork), since it was cooked perfectly. It melted in my mouth. However, the pasta tasted it wasn't cooked to perfection, rather is was luke warm. The other dish ordered was the free range chicken, which was tasty on the top, but rather dry. My overall impression is Eh. I love the setting, and design. But not impress by the food. It was below average, maybe they were busy servicing since everyone probably waits till the last minute to used thier coupons.
author: Monika T.

description:
Came here on a Friday night and the place was pretty crowded. Good ambiance. Everyone here was on a date.

Shared the calamari salad and that was delicious. 

I had the Pappardelle al Baccala', which is ink pasta, salted Cod, with light tomato sauce. It was kinda too salty because of the code. Pasta was fresh though and cooked a little bit al dente.

My buddy had the fettuccine al ragu' made with slow braised lamb shank, covered with tomato sauce. That was way better than mine. yumms. I'll get that next time.

For dessert we shared the chocolate/hazelnut gelato. That was soooo good. Perfect ending to a hot day!
author: Cynthia C.

description:
A wonderful dinner full of exiquisite flavors and not to mention the added perk of good company.

There is something about eating in a converted house that exudes the feel of dining in San Francisco. We opted to wait for a window table, which had a wonderful view and a roomy feel, in the meantime enjoying a tasty pinot negro and spending the entire time flirting with no rude interruptions. Always a plus!

The salads were crisp - my insalada verde stock full of crisp apples and endive, followed by a moist, tender bone-in pork shoulder with handmade pasta. Not quite an osco busco, but the pork perfection on the same level. I cannot help but be wooed over by tender pork - call it a love love situation.
author: Alita M.

description: Ah, where to start? Perfect service, perfect ambiance and last but not least, perfect food & wine. Long story, short. Tomato bread soup = amazing! homemade gnocchi in sage sauce = perfectly light and flavorful! Scallop and mussel rissotto = delicious! Beet ravioli in sage butter sauce = unique and flavorful. All the pasta is homemade and the bread at the beginning was so fresh and soft. Of course the dessert can not be forgotten, it was chocolate mouse with sea salt and olive oil......wow!! Yes, the next day we actually discussed going back and ordering the exact same things. Although we decided that may be a bit much. This will definitely be one of our top spots from now on and we can't wait to try everything on the menu.
author: Vickie B.

description:
Meant to write this a while ago, so apologies for lack of detail. 

This place is one of the best kept little secrets of San Francisco. We wound up here one night in large part because of poor planning - my boyfriend, his best friend, her boyfriend and I had forgotten to make reservations elsewhere and they were the only place that could take us. Everything we had was fantastic. Each of us ordered four different main courses and passed plates, and everything was just completely delicious. Great wine selection, too.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Great food, very attentive service, great atmosphere, great price point!  My friends have been singing this place's praises for a while and it absolutely lived up to expectations!

Bravo!
author: Jory S.

description:
I used to like to go to Poesia for its grilled chicken, not until the last visit.  The portion has dramatically shrunk.  They used to serve half chicken, now its only a quarter, so is the portion of side vegies.  I just don't think i will pay $18 for that.   

Poesia is a decent restaurant, however, when the entree portion shrinks but not the price, they are competing with other higher rated restaurant.
author: Preston D.

description: One of the best Italian restaurants in the city. We found this via a Bloomspot and have been back many times since. We love the food, the service and the ambiance. The menu changes but every pasta dish we have had has been excellent.
author: Elzabeth G.

description:
Not your averae italian restaurant. Cozy, and cute inside. The manager/owner was great! He spent more time with us than our server. Service was fantastic and the food was delicious! Roasted chicken was perfectly seasoned and the potatoes and veggies were soft but had a nice crunch. I got a filled pasta with cheese and walnuts that was rich but worth every bite. The coffee was strong.
Not a casual spot or an everyday joint but perfect for a nice meal.
author: Aubs J.

description:
Amaze-o! Homemade pasta, delicious wines, cute upstairs setting, Italian movies playing...everything was perfect. They even put a candle on my dessert mousse :) Oh boyfriend, how cute are you?!? 

The only downside to this restaurant was the fact that they were out of the raviolis I was dying to try. But the dish my waiter recommended far exceeded my expectations so I'm good ;)
author: Emily H.

description:
It was time to have Italian food back in our meal rotation since returning from a vacation which featured stops in Rome, Amalfi coast, and Venice. The wonderful lasting impression that Italy left in my mind gave me slight concern as my tastebuds might be bias to the local flavor. The experience at Poesia did not disappoint .

We began with two starters. One was from the specials, a beet salad. The other, heirloom tomatoes and burrata. The freshness and simplicity allowed for mother nature's gifts to shine. I am not saying these were the best appetizers that I ever had... but, they did not stand a chance on the plate.

We had the Orecchiette with sausage and Lamb Ragu with fettuccine for our main dishes. Both excellent homemade pastas, nice heat from the sausage, and the Ragu did not carry the funk associated with lamb. My wife and I ate to our max capacity and left with two to go boxes.

The leftovers heated up for the perfect midnight snack!
author: Leosanti R.

description:
We had a very good experience at Poesia as an early birthday celebration for a friend from LA.  Francesco was a gracious host as he seated us though I was surprised he didn't make the rounds of the tables later in the meal.  Ambience was excellent; the Italian movies being broadcast on the wall a la Foreign Cinema were a nice touch.  I'm not an expert on Italian cinema but both films were refreshingly unfamiliar to me.

First Courses - Bacala (salt cod) al forno was exceptional; I think even diners who haven't liked the fish before would enjoy this preparation.  The roasted sardines had a satisfying crunch and the golden-and-red beet salad was also very good.

Second Courses - The risotto nero was perfectly cooked, the squid ink giving it a smokey flavor.  I thought the lobster reduction served with it was a little overwhelmed though.  The half chicken was tasty but slightly overcooked and dry.  The branzino was roasted whole and expertly de-boned at the table; also a satisfying meal.  The crab ravioli were the star of the course though - plentiful sweet crab in perfectly cooked pasta offset with a sauce that had a bit of a kick (unlike previous reviewers, the pasta wasn't swimming in sauce; it appears the chef is paying attention).

Cocktails were fun - the specials were a blood orange cosmo and a blueberry Manhattan.  We had a very serviceable Arneis from an interesting wine list.

Plus - the servers waited until all four of us had finished before they cleared the table; this is the way I was trained in restaurant service.  I never liked feeling rushed when I was the only one with a plate still in front of me.

Minus - three of the dishes were plated by a round mold.  It made an attractive presentation but I would've rather seen more creativity.

Prices are on the high side - even with a Groupon - but we would definitely go back for a celebration dinner.
author: Cal C.

description:
I got a groupon the weekend right before the fiance's bday. It was dreary and raining... we almost missed the restaurant bc it's not street level. Luckily I saw the restaurant's sign. 

The restaurant is very homey and sweet. It is small, but has a fair number of tables. I love the movie projected on the wall, the decor and the lighting make you feel like you've found a hidden gem in the busy busy streets. We got a little table next to the window, and it felt like being a world away from all the people who were running in the rain down below the streets.

The wait staff was very attentive and helpful with suggestions for wine and food. The homemade bread they serve had a nice crust but still soft and chewy -- not your typical loaf of sourdough or "italian" white bread. For an appetizer we ordered the beef carpaccio. It was good quality meat and the dressing went well with the little bed of salad but it was too acidic for the both of us. I looked like Popeye after every bite.

I ordered the much praised squid ink risotto with scallops and lobster reduction. I felt like it was a bit on the salty side but still good. It included two scallops halved on top the risotto for presentation more than taste IMO. The soon-to-be hubby ordered the pork rib pasta w/ roasted garlic and tomato sauce. I was a bit bummed when I didn't see ribs in his pasta dish, more like pulled pork. The meat was tender, but nothing to really to write home about especially for that price. We had ordered dessert bc neither of us was actually full/satisfied yet. We ordered the orange tiramisu.... they should have just left the classic alone -- it did not work for us. all i tasted was the cointreau. The fluffy cream just didn't melt into it like a normal espresso tiramisu would.

All in all, I don't think there's enough food for what you pay for. Had I not had a groupon, I'd have been pissed for spending $70-80 and leaving unsatiated.
author: sasa w.

description:
The wife and I came here for her birthday.  The food was really good and the atmosphere is great.  If you can get a spot by the window, you have your choice of the black and white movie or the street below as your entertainment.  The service was above average, albeit "paced out."  To be fair, it was really busy that night and it's not like we weren't expecting slow service given the reviews.

The Saturday we went was the night before Folsom Street Fair and it was crazy warm out with people everywhere.  Come to think of it, I'm pretty sure we saw more sausage on the street than on the menu...
author: Patrick C.

description: By far one of the places to dine out with the best service in the city!
author: Ann H.

description:
A friend brought me here for dinner and I wonder why I never tried this place sooner.

Poesia is cute. Its like going up someone's house, only to be greeted by an Italian host. 

The atmosphere is warm and cool with old movies playing on their brick(?) wall.. or was it white? Sorry my memory is hazy BUT the food is unforgettable!

I ordered their calamari for appetizer. It was grilled squid with lemon olive oil and baby arugula. My friend ordered a salad, which I wasnt able to try but she said it was very lovely. 

I had their Fettuccine al Ragu di Agnello. Oh my! Sooo good! The pasta tasted so fresh and the lamb shank was so tender that it melts in my mouth!

My friend ordered their specials. It looked really good but I was so focused on my own that I didnt bother trying hers. lol! Based on her reaction though ... I know she was enjoying her meal as much as I am.

Only thing about this place though ... it get too dark! I guess if it was a date, I wouldnt mind. But that night it wasnt, so there.... :P
author: RED C.

description:
Seriously good. So good that I can still taste the flavors and the experience years later. 

I have dined here twice. The first with an Italian friend who had met the owner at yoga that morning. He couldn't have been more gracious and the food better. Such a wonderful evening of great flavors, great atmosphere and a gracious host. 

The second time I dined here was just over a year ago. I was disappointed at how they had tightened up the seating. I really had loved the amount of space between the tables before. I can understand the need to make a buck though. And I guess they needed the seating for all of those people I had been sending them. 

The food and wine here really is great, a gem in the minefield of the Castro dining scene.
author: Jason L.

description: It is not often I have eaten in Castro and have been impressed.  I found the service very attentive. The food was lovely.  We ordered the steak which was cooked perfectly.  The gnocchi was unique and a nice surprise.  The lamb sushi had a great flavor and a portion large enough for me to take home leftovers.  The daily special was a well executed and very traditional Beef Ragu.  I would highly recommend Poesia to anyone looking for a nice Italian meal out in the Castro.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
I thought the atmosphere was nice. I'm partial to my brother in law's mother's eggplant parm, I have yet to have one that matches hers.

Eggplant Parmesan was decent, but could be better.

Portion size for the price could be a tad larger

I did like that the employees were actually italian.
author: Eric A.

description: Warm and welcoming ambience. Delicious food and wine (especially the muscles - yum!). Left in a great mood!
author: Bryan C.

description:
I wasn't that impressed this place... 

The idea of converting a house into a restaurant is pretty cool, but the food wasn't that impressive. I had the squid ink risotto, and it was interesting but not GREAT....

Food was very forgetful and I wouldn't come again.
author: Stephen N.

description:
