Perfect choice for a romantic/intimate dinner with a great staff and some excellent food choices. I really enjoyed the chef's efforts at creating some unique and delicious choices. Located in the castro so obviously plenty of post dinner options. 

Between this place and the upstairs Eureka bar across the street you can have a great date night!
author: James H.

description:
We almost had a great experience, but I'm taking off 2 stars for them straight up LYING to us. Had they handled it correctly, we would definitely given them 4 or 5 stars. 

We ordered the corkscrew pasta with pork sugo, the filet mignon, and the risotto. We were pretty happy with all the dishes except the filet. Presentation was good, flavor was great. and our bartender was super friendly. 

The filet came out and it tasted like fish. We both confirmed this and we asked the bartender if it was suppose to taste like that. Maybe, it was cooked with some fishy broth? I don't know, but he went to talk with the kitchen. I even said that if they say that was suppose to taste like that, then we'll just box it up and take it to go. He came back and said that it was the broccoli that made it taste that way. The dish came with broccoli but the strange thing is that my boyfriend took a bite of the broccoli first before continuing onto the fishy tasting meat. The broccoli didn't taste like fish. But the bartender (I assume he was repeating the lie that was told him by the kitchen) said the broccoli came in today and had a very strange smell. It was broccoli rabe. I've eaten it many times, and it doesn't have a fishy flavor. Obviously the kitchen cooked with utensils that touched fish and also the meat. 

So, he said they will separate the meat from the broccoli and cook it so that it won't have the fish flavor. 

It came out again on top of the broccoli, but the bartender intercepted it and brought it back to the kitchen. They re-plated it and had the meat on the side. The meat tasted fine, but it was not medium rare anymore. Plus my boyfriend had a fishy flavor in his mouth, which pretty much ruined his appetite. 

We were pretty insulted that they would think we're stupid enough to believe that broccoli tastes like fish, especially when the broccoli on the plate didn't have ANY fish flavor, while the meat did. 

They should have apologized. Admitted that the meat was crossed over with fish due to cooking utensils or the same grill and just remade the entire thing being careful not to mix the two together. 

That really sucks, because we live up the street and we were hopeful to find a good dining place in the Castro. So far, we're still looking.
author: Cake W.

description:
Okay so just spent my Birthday at this amazing restaurant... Had squid for the first time, it was incredibly fresh and prepared to perfection!  Both of our meals were beyond yummy and I would go back everyday if I could.  

The atmosphere was great, really made you feel like you found a hidden gem in the busy Castro.  Service was awesome too, had multiple people serving us and all were totally attentive and sweet.

recommend Recommend RECOMMEND!
author: Ally Marie F.

description:
First of all, I don't like restaurants that pack you in like sardines.  This place is ridiculous.  The staff have a difficult time getting around and if you're of  size at all, it's horrible.
Now, the food is nothing spectacular.  We ordered the mussels with sausage and the beet salad for apps.  The mussels were old, mealy and very "fishy" tasting and there was no sausage in the sauce, at all.  The beet salad was good, but could use more than 4 pin-head size pieces of goat cheese. Our entrees were the lamb ragu and crab ravioli's.  My husband liked the lamb, the sauce was rich and lamby although there was very, very little meat.  The ravioli's were okay. They have pancetta cubes along with the tasteless brandy sauce and the pancetta overwhelmed the delicate crab meat in the pasta.  Bad choice for an ingredient. But the ravioli pasta was well cooked.  We ordered the chocolate mousse dessert and I was expecting a pudding cup or something and out comes a rectangular plate with 2 mounds, no more than a tablespoon each, of mousse surrounded by a drizzle of olive oil and chili powder sprinkled on the plate.  For $14.00  I expected more, not that it was bad, just stingy.
I have to mention that the meal was okay, but toward the end of our dining, a man came into the tiny, packed restaurant wearing an Aqua Velva/Old Spice cologne which he bathed in, apparently; the air became thick with this smell and it absolutely ruined the meal.  I immediately got a headache and started to wheeze, which is not something I do! We had to exit quickly and I felt like it was clinging to my clothing and like taking a shower, it was that bad.  
I know the restaurant can't do anything about this, but with all the laws out there about offending peoples sensitivity, can we do something about these smelly louts?
We're going to stick with Bar Bambino for excellent Italian food, where it's much easier to get to (no parking nightmare) and the food and staff are top notch.
author: Mary D.

description:
I really want to like Poesia, given its avg high ratings. However, I must follow my taste buds and give it 3 stars. The food was just average. Nothing outstanding, sadly.
* Beet ravioli - pretty interesting taste and idea, but not worth $15
* squid ink risotto - I thought I'd like this more! It was just ok.
* eggplant parmesan - good, because it was smothered in cheese, but that's about it
* orange mascarpone dessert - YUM

Service, I must say, was simply outstanding, and the atmosphere was pretty cute and intimate. Sadly though, the service/atmosphere didn't make up for the average food.
author: Carol L.

description:
In an economy where restaurants are opening and closing quicker than the red to green lights along ocean beach it's comforting to know there are holding strong due to simplistic presentation and allowing the food to scream for itself.  Food arrives unassuming, w/o the you fancy huh attitude...but the minute it hits your palate immediately you appreciate the difference between dry pasta and  pasta that's fresh blessed w/ unconditional love.  Ink squid ravioli stuffed w/ Dungeness
crab in pesto sauce...REDIC.  Fully stuffed, no messing around enclosed in chewy teeth sinking pillows, then the pesto clinches and there's no other response but moan.  It isn't a matter of should you or shouldn't you...it's a must.  To the owner(s) of Poesia, the chef and staff you have something special happening here and it's been my pleasure to partake.  Applause, encore, bow.
author: D C.

description:
Noisy but the food made up for it.

My boyfriend and I came here for our Valentine's dinner. We ordered:

Grilled squid- around 6 giant head squids, tasty and very chewy. It came with a salad which went well with this appetizer.

Tortellini- filled with beets, at first I didn't want to try it but the waitress convinced me. Beware, there are only 4 big tortellini's which were packed with beet puree. It was really good.

Pasta with fresh crab- very generous with shredded crab and comes with a light sauce. The pasta was thick and chewy. It was good also.

Blood Orange Cocktail- I RECCOMEND THIS COCKTAIL! Strong and not as sweet. It was the perfect balance. 

I really liked this place for the food quality. It was hard finding parking especially since it's in Castro. Oh and the waitresses and waiters all had italian accents. It was a bit difficult understanding them but the food was awesome and I would go here again. I love me some fresh homemade pasta!
author: Jennifer D.

description: I really appreciate that they offer gluten free pasta options on the menu. The service is on the slow side but they are very gracious and attentive once they get to you. My husband and I always enjoy a romantic evening here and the food is outstanding.
author: Rachel K.

description:
Really a great place.  Nice to hear Italian spoken by so many of the waitstaff and customers!

It was busy and a bit noisy, not sure how that can be helped as it's a relatively small space.  But it was busy for a reason...the food was delicious.

Between six of us ordered various insalate, antipasti, pasta and secondi.  They were all so delicious that there was lots of sharing.

My choices were the Tortino ai Carchiofe (Fried artichoke cake & mozzerella) and Parmigianna di Melanzane (Eggplant parmesan.)

The Tortino was splendid and creamy.  The eggplant fried to perfection, but not dry.

As typical with Italian cuisine, suggest to eat multiple courses and sample your way down the menu.  Plates are prices moderately, and sized appropriately.  OK, well by the time we got to Dulci, we had to resort to sharing one cannolo and coffee.

The Fellini film showing on the wall was a nice touch.  The service was very attentive, and they did dietary accommodations for vegan & vegetarians we had in our party.  

It's not a place for a quick bite, so plan on lingering and enjoying every course.

An all-around good showing!
author: Ken B.

description:
Amazing place.  I took my husband here for his birthday.  I made a reservation and asked for a window table.  When we arrived, we were seated right away at a table with a great view of the street and a view of the black and white movie they were playing.  The service was great and the food was to die for.  The squid ink risotto was one of the best italian dishes I've ever had the pleasure of eating!  The wine selection was good and they even brought out shots at the end of the meal and said " on the house, happy birthday".  

I highly recommend this place for a date and the service was excellent!
author: Jessica H.

description:
Cute place with interesting nooks, it's basically a converted house

The food, for the price, was so-so. Not very memorable.
author: Captain B.

description: I was really looking forward to eating here - but my pasta with beets was swimming in oil, we returned the potato side dish because it tasted funny, and the mussels were a bit too fishy.  The service was not great and my cocktail was uneventful.  Good ambiance and wonderful location - but the food and service needs a bit more attention.
author: Gretchen H.

description: A  quiet little spot for great Italian food in the heart of crazy Castro.  Service was impeccable and food was delicious.  We had beet salad (ok), grilled calamari (outstanding), lamb rigatoni (quite good), and the best damn chocolate mousse on the planet.  Wine was good and waiter was quite helpful in letting us try several before selecting a bottle.  A real gem of a place!
author: Jason S.

description:
Food-amazing
Wine-delicious
Matron D- Hot ;)
Ambiance- Cozy (although a little small so not for large groups)

What more needs to be said
author: Melinda B.

description:
I seriously love Poesia. It's a grade A place.

Yes, it's in the castro - but we all know how picky gay men can be! (aka it's GREAT food).

I had this creme brullee tira misu styled cake once, I die. Seriously. 

We had a huge party there the other day, the staff was so tolerant, friendly, and nice. The place is quaint. It's an old house remodeled into this great restaurant. The place packs too! So call ahead or do what you can to get yourself a spot.
author: Leanne D.

description: Excellent service, romantic atmosphere and great food. A great place to take a date, do get reservations though!
author: Matthew V.

description:
It started out good, great ambiance, friendly staff, nice service, we did not have any problems with service being slow as mentioned in many other reviews.

Downhill from there:

It was very warm and stuffy in the room, I realize Victorian homes may not have air conditioning but a ceiling fan would have made a world of difference.

No one ever mentioned the specials of the night as was done at neighboring tables.
As we were early and had a drink at the bar, we basically already made our dinner choices as we had plenty of time to peruse the menu, but still would have been nice to be aware of other choices, my review may have turned out differently, who knows.

In general very disappointed by the food, it did not have a Wow factor for us. 

Appetizers Bruschetta and Tomato bread soup were OK

My main entrée: FILEJI DI RENATO* 16 
 Typical Calabrese spiral shaped pasta with pork ribs sugo in roasted garlic tomato sauce, only had a sliver of meat way at the bottom of the dish, wayyy too much garlic and I love garlic but this was overbearing. I felt this was really just pasta with a very bland tomato sauce, nothing special.

My husband had the ORECCHIETTE ALLA CALABRESE * 16 
 Coin shaped pasta baked in the oven with 'Nduja sausage, porcini mushrooms and provolone which was slightly better

We had the tiramisu for dessert and felt there was too much whipped cream and not enough "tiramisu" if you will. We had high expectations after all I heard about Poesia and chose to go there to celebrate my husbands birthday, but don't think we'll be back.
author: Gitta W.

description:
We've been here four times now.  Two things struck me: 1) I can't believe such a good Italian restaurant lives in the heart of Castro, which is really not known for it's food; and 2) this place is hella consistently good.  We had the squid ink risotto with scallops and the lamb fettucini both times, among other things, and both are just ... mmmmm .... so, so good.  The fettucini is perfectly al dente, and for both dishes, the flavors were rich and satisfying.  

Only negative?  I would not recommend the dessert here.  The tiramisu was surprisingly bad, and the gelato was icy, like it had been stored improperly.
author: Lisa S.

description: Simply delicious. We sat at the bar and had a great evening. Would highly recommend it.
author: Carrue Robin M.

description:
You will feel quite the king or queen as you enter the townhouse that is home to Poesia.  You will also receive a very warm welcome from Poesia's owner.  Furthermore, parking (at least on a Sunday evening) is not nearly so horrid as you might think.

The food at Poesia, on this visit, ranged from good to outstanding.  A beet salad was good.  It was nicely composed and well presented, however, the beets were pallid.  Not at all sweet or vibrant.  

Ravioli stuffed with crab came with a brandy cream sauce.  This was outstanding as they didn't skimp on the crab and the sauce was a nice accent that didn't overwhelm.  

A whole branzino, served boned and stuffed with some lemons, was all you could wish.  A bit of charred taste on the outside and sweet, fresh, firm fish flesh within.  THe fresh vegetables that came with the fish detracted a bit.  The potatoes were over-salted and gave ever appearance of having been prepared well in advance.  

Poesia is well worth visiting, especially for its pastas.
author: David D.

description:
There is not enough stars for this place! Once again we hit this fantastic little spot in the Castro! Hidden away it maybe but trust me its a destination place for sure.  We got introduced to the CRAZY COOK last night as one of the staff said to us . But can we say that she made the fresh bread which was out of this world,, and then brought us out bread sticks and very thin sliced meat wrapped around and OMG off the charts for the taste.. That was not even on the menu and she did this ..  We also got to meet the manager which we did not last time and nice and sweet as can be  so you should all call up make reservations and try this spot , I do not want to give away everything they have on the list but again its worth every penny and bring friends u want to spend time with and enjoy every bite.  the thing that got me the most is that its been weeks since we first went and when we sat down the waiter came over and said " NO WATER RIGHT" lol i said OMG that is so right on .... bring on the cocktails :) 
Thank u to  the entire staff !!!
Randy Scorpio Moore

Randy /Scorpio 
aka 
Randy Moore
author: Randy M.

description:
Nothing bad to say here.  The food was innovative and delicious, the waitstaff courteous and knowledgeable, and the ambiance was lovely.  Poesia is located on the 2nd floor of a house in the middle of the Castro, and it really feels like you're eating in someone's fancy living room - very cozy and inviting.  They have old Italian movies projected on one of the walls, which creates a cool effect.

The calamari appetizer was perfectly done - smoky and with a great texture... not rubbery, like calamari can be.  I had the beet tortello entree with smoked ricotta, which was beautiful to look at and *extremely* tasty!  In fact, everyone at our table had a pasta entree, and no one left disappointed (the corkscrew pasta with pork ribs was particularly well received).  And you can't go wrong with a perfectly-executed tiramisu.  Awesome.

Some people may not like the modest (i.e. normal) portions... but it was nice to be able to clean my plate and not feel like a whale afterward.
author: Laura R.

description: I feel conflicted about our experience this weekend at Poesia. I love the idea of it -- small restaurant, warm staff, lively location and second-floor deck -- but the actuality of it wasn't up to snuff.  We arrived just before 7pm for a 7pm reservation and were not seated until 7:40pm!  Apparently, they only have one table for 3 and couldn't seat us anywhere else.  They apologized a couple times, but did not comp us our drinks or otherwise go out of their way.  Once we sat down, we enjoyed our meal -- calamari, beat salad, lamb ragu, sardine ravioli, and tiramisu -- but aside from the calamari, I wouldn't come back for any of it.  And it was LOUD!  Maybe the answer is to try it earlier in the evening on a weekday...
author: Taly J.

description:
Keep your eyes open, because if you don't you might miss it.  We did, a few times.  Its so small, on the upstairs level of a townhouse or something.  But it was worth the find! 

You want to make reservations here because the dining room is pretty small and it was packed the saturday night we decided to try it.  That being said, we did have reservations, which we cancelled because we were obviously seriously confused, but then decided to go and called back and they still had an opening as long as we got there in fifteen minutes.  Which we did!

This inside is super adorable.  Candlit, dark bar...people were dressed up but not over the top.  The tables are small and very close together, but its intimate.  There is also a big black and white silent movie that plays by a projector on one of the walls, which sort of bemused me initially but once the incredible food came it faded into the background.  

There wine list is decent, you will find something that you like.  Then we split the beet salad with goat cheese.  This was so good, I almost want to go back right now and order it again.  It was two different kinds of beets cut up with goat cheese all inside its knooks and crannies.  

For dinner we ordered the eggplant parmesean and the orichiette al forno.  All of our dishes came timely though we never felt like we were being rushed.  The waitstaff was very nice.  

All in all it was a great experience.  My dinner date wanted me to add a disclaimer, her company was so engaging and enchanting that my memories of the dinner, outside of her incredible company, are probably just a vague recollection and should not be taken to seriously.
author: Kierstan G.

description: Went here with a group of 7 on a Friday night while visiting the city. Had an excellent experience. staff was attentive and the food was delicious. They kindly accommodated multiple changes to our reservation and added more seats as our numbers grew. Overall a very pleasant meal in a great ambiance.
author: Angela W.

description:
Service was attentive and nice. Started at the bar and to help me decide which prosecco to choose the bartender poured me a splash of two, which made my decision super easy. Appreciated.

The food? Not bad, not good, and certainly not worth the price. 20-something for a "special" mushroom risotto? Fugeduhboudit. (And while they were from Mendocino, they weren't THAT kind of special mushroom.)
Awkward tuna and onion salad with what was basically an onion ring under some lettuce.
Dining companion had short ribs special that was ok but also overpriced and unexciting. Neither of the specials we had came with prices attached when they were described and we didn't expect that they would fetch such a high price. 
This is San Francisco and I completely understand that good food isn't cheap, but for a far superior dining experience for a similar price, I dined at ZUNI a couple weeks later and the experience makes me think Poesia would be better off as a cheesy overpriced North Beach operation than the intimate fine-dining thing they're going for.
author: Kelly N.

description: Skip it.  This place was a disappointment from the start, and with that I've concluded that SF/Bay Area restaurants are the most overrated restaurants on yelp, a 4 star rating in SF is the equivalent to a 2.5 star rating in NYC.  SF is an ok city, but not the culinary mecca it claims and aspires to be.  The problem is that Poesia and many other SF restaurants that claim to be fine dining are all essentially wine bars that throw out a few trendy dishes to the pickled patrons, rather than a restaurant that builds a wine list around the chef inspired menu.  From now on fine dining will be limited to my visits to NYC and I'll stick with the sports bar type places when I go to SF.
author: Ryan B.

description: Stay away. This was one of the worst SF restaurant experiences I've ever had. From an unfriendly waiter, to a 45 minute wait for what turned out to be terrtibbbble food. Homemade pasta was dense as hell and swimming in cream sauce and lacking basic seasoning (salt). Owner clearly not interested in improving- saw my untouched plate and asked if I want to box it, never even asked why I said no. Had a hard time getting the bad taste out of my mouth. Definitely better options in the area.
author: K G.

description:
Calamari 5/5
Risotto 3.5/5
Squid ink ravioli 5/5
Service 5/5
Tiramisu 5/5 SO GOOD!!!!!!!!! ITS SO DIFF. i thought they gave us the wrong thing LOL
I like their portions!!! very little but good for girlS!
author: Cindy L.

description:
Great timing of the dishes, attentive and knowledgeable servers, a well-paced perfectly executed dining experience. Going here goes beyond just the food--Poesia lulls your other senses with it's quite romantical atmosphere. 

To put it succinctly:
This place has charm.

The food is also very well prepared with a level of attention and detail orientation that sparkles in each dish. We had the gnocchi, fettucine, sea bass, and the calamari. 

The gnocchi had an orange citrus based sauce that I dug. Great texture, soft little dumplings

The calamari was delicious as well, nicely charred on a grill with some fresh, buttery arugula.

The fettucine was my favorite. These pasta noodles kick any others ass. They have real texture,bite, and flavor to them. Really artisan quality homemade pasta. The lamb-tomato sauce it came with went very well with it.

The sea bass was impressive and cooked tender and moist. It took on the essence of the lemon slices that were wedged inside the bass. Yum.

All in all, I spent a good $80 bucks. Pricey, but worth it if you want that real upscale attention-to-the-details kind of dining experience. Portions are also not American (hella big) sized, so keep that in mind.
author: Sunny M.

description:
Starting with dessert, I should not have listened to the pseudo-Italian waitress who proclaimed every menu item to be "fantaaastic" when she suggested a chocolate mousse creation with three small squirts of mouse, and olive oil and sea salt smeared on top. It tastes exactly like it sounds, so unless you enjoy salty and oily chocolate, I'd avoid this one.  

Since it was her hyped-up suggestion, our waitress accommodated us by offering the orange cream tiramisu instead. A creamsicle in tiramisu form, soft and flavorful, not too overpowering...what's Italian for heaven in my mouth?? Definitely the highlight of the night. 

For dinner, I ordered the beef pasta dish that was special of the day and tried my friend's ravioli. Good. Not fantaaastic. 

I did enjoy our seats with a view of the shady bar with purple curtains playing Beyonce videos across the street. Very interesting characters going there, especially one guy whose personal chauffeur waited for him on the corner. 

*Check note*
I noticed the next day that they charged me twice for dinner, and the manager wanted me to come in to get my money back...or get it from my friend that wasn't charged (so not happening). I was not in the mood to return to the Castro anytime soon so I convinced him to mail me the check and he promptly sent it my way.
author: Contessa S.

description: Old-fashioned Italian restaurant where the pasta is home-made. It was pretty good and the portions generous. Especially generous in size was my post-dinner coffee... it was huge and another meal in itself!
author: Angie C.

description:
I came here awhile back with the bf as a surprise romantic dinner.  It's sooo cute.  Its pretty much a flat in the Castro with really great lighting and ambiance.  We sat near the window which was perfect for the nice night.  They were playing an old Italian movie on a big screen in the back of the restaurant.  

He had a fish and they brought him the WHOLE fish and cut it there on the table for him.  Unique touch, never seen that before...  It was really tasty.

I had gnocchi that wasn't the best I've had but pretty good.  We also had cosmos made with fresh fruit...sooo good.

It was really romantic and I loved it.
author: Angela S.

description:
Again, we need more granularity than five stars. Poesia is a 7 on a scale of ten and it's not quite fair that I must offer only a 3 star review.

This is a small house but was full on a rainy Monday night. Given they're one flight up, this is indicative of good word of mouth. Parking in this area always is challenging but we got lucky and found a spot right out front. We went upstairs and were met with friendly Italian staff. Seated right away we noticed the warm color scheme and the projected (silent) French film (starring a very young Alain Delon). Seated I started with the Gnocchi Silana (Ricotta, Citrus Sauce, Cherry tomatoes) and my guest had a salad with slices of fennel, pear and arugula. My gnocchi was really good. The salad, on the other hand, was bland with the fennel sliced too thick. One for two.

For our entrees we both ordered the special of the night, a tagliatelle with lamb ragout. This was outstanding. We both finished every bit. Wine...I had a decent pinot and my guest had a fairly generic chianti. We both ordered dessert. I had a chocolate soufflé and my guest had the poached pear. Her pear was fine, my souffle was quite good but the ice cream had ice crystals infused in it. Ugh.

Service was very good. Ambiance was really nice. All in all a nice dinner though not quite memorable. Competition for a good Italian dinner in SF is fierce. I'm not sure this quite makes it to top notch.

3.5 stars
author: Gary C.

description:
Sorry.  I really am.  I read the reviews here on Yelp and decided to take my family here.  My options were Poesia and Cha Cha -- I should have chose the latter.  

My step-mother is difficult to please and I really hoped they would perform, but they didn't. 

The food was good.  I will say that.  Very good.  My father ordered the Lamb Chops, and he liked them.  I ordered the pasta with pork and smoked ricotta cheese ...

Any way,  it took more 40 min to receive our main course, and our first ... and second rounds of drinks took even longer.  After seeing the boredom that came over our faces, and my sister who was slumped over the table sleeping, our cute foreign waiter attempted to ease our stay.  

Unfortunately, that wasn't enough.

Overall, I enjoyed my food, but did not enjoy my experience.  

Very cute inside.
author: Alicia J.

description:
The food was fine - i think.  Unfortunately, it took so long to arrive that anything would have sufficed.

And it all started off so well.  Got a reservation the day-of.  Showed up and they had a table waiting for us.  Greeted and seated in 2 min.  And then we waiting.  And waited.  And waited about 20 minutes before anyone came over to take our order.

Then the real waiting began.  

Almost 2 hours to get served 1 pasta course???
author: Sarah L.

description:
Decent Italian can be found in the Castro!!  

We ate family style and everybody  was happy with everything we tasted. The gnocchi was fluffy and a perfectly balanced with perfectly roasted tomatoes.  Pappardelle was perfectly al dente.  Scallops with squid ink risotto was simply epic.  Crab ravioli was bursting with fresh crab. 

Deserts were awesome as well - they even made us an affogato, which was not on the menu.
author: Josh M.

description:
They turned the living quarters of an  old house in the heart of Castro into this cozy restaurant.  I had the Oreccheitte which was the most delicious I've had since that time in Sorrento in 1990.  My partner had the Calabrese Antipasto  and proclaimed it quite delicious.   We both had the Pollo al Mattone which, altho very delicious was not truely  al Mattone as this was cut up chicken then broiled/roasted whereas real al Mattone is one piece half chicken fried or grilled with a brick (mattone) on top and whenever I see such on a menu in the USA I try to see if it compares with the dish I had at the little hilltop restaurante in Capri in '92.  The veggies with the dish were perfect.

We shared a dish of chocolate/hazelnut gelato and it was as good as gelato can get.

I wish they had really made the chicken al mattone instead of the way they did no matter how good it was.

All in all a nice ambiance and very attentive/professional service, and very delicious food.
author: William G.

description:
This is one of the best restaurants in the Castro. Poesia features an authentic Italian menu with great flavors. Every dish I've gotten there has been good. If I remember correctly, most of their pasta are made in house or was it that they were imported from Italy. Whatever the case, it was yummy! I also really enjoyed a lot of their meat dishes (I've tried the pork and the steak). The staff is mostly all Italian and really proud of their culture.

I also really like the fact that it's easy to get a reservation. Make sure to try their cocktail specialties.

~A
author: Alex C.

description: Friendly staff, including by the owner.  Traditional Italian cuisine, with good-sized portions and lots of flavor.  My favorites: the grilled calamari salad, the tiramisu, and the whole branzino fish -- delicious!  They also serve great cocktails and wine.  Service can be a little slow when they're busy (we were there for two hours, from apps to dessert), so plan on going there when you're not in a hurry and enjoy!
author: Carlo A.

description:
Excellent dining experience. Best meal of the vacation.

Adorable spot, delicious al dente pasta (on special: housemade tagliatelle with porcini mushrooms! get it if you can!), incredibly friendly, knowledgeable, Italian service. 

Also, the clientele was smily and well-dressed, and employees and guests alike seemed to be having a lovely Sunday evening. Go here.
author: Catherine R.

description:
The ambiance is totally romantic. Dimly lit but not dark, and we had a seat by the window so we could people watch, but on the second floor it was still quiet. The staff was charming, (actually Italian), but the service was slow. They brought out the wrong dish for my fiance's dinner, and let him eat several bites before they realized their mistake. 

The food was ok, not the best Italian, it was tasty but not to die for. However, there is a great wine list with prices for everyone. 

This has potential to be a good date place but don't bring someone you're trying to impress. Luckily, we tried Poesia because of a groupon. If we didn't have that savings I would have been very dissapointed. 

Tip: Make reservations on open table! They were very, very busy.
author: Halley B.

description: A test of a great restaurant and its staff is that last minute end of the night clientele.  That was me tonight.  I had finished a nice evening with friends and was walking by Poesia on my way to my car.  I remembered the choclate mousse with the sea salt, olive oil, and the hint of cayenne pepper.  So I walked in and sat at the bar and was welcomed into this quaint and beautiful space in the Castro.  The waiter remembered me.  I ordered the mousse and a late harvest dessert wine.  It was perfect.  The food here is just not good, it is exceptional.  The decor is tasteful and the atmosphere is warm.  Subtle instrumental music plays in the background.  The staff is friendly, well dressed, and clearly focused on making your dining a positive experience.  The last couple times I was here, the owner personally came to my table to make sure the evening and dinner were to my liking.  This is a must have experience in the Castro.
author: James W.

description:
Looooved it!

It's so tiny, but they manage to pack everything in there...

* A full bar with the most adorable (and talented) bartender - get the strawberry basil martini with Grey Goose

* Vintage Italian movies projected onto the back wall make for a nostalgic, romantic atmosphere

* Charming maitre d' - he high-fived me to commend my wise choice in leaving the stilettos at home for the hike from where we parked to the restaurant (parking sucks here)

* Terrific wait staff - loved our Italian server who gave us a great wine recommendation that paired perfectly with our varied menu choices that night

*Small but decent wine list with some quality, reasonably priced bottles. A good number of them are poured by the glass as well.

* Fresh and oh-so-tasty food - whole sea bass grilled to perfection, rack of lamb at double the portion for the same price as most decent restaurants, al dente eggplant tortellini, and a perfectly dressed heirloom tomato salad. 

Poesia offers simple but flavorful fare at a good price with delightful staff to boot...seriously a wonderful experience. It's San Francisco at it's best...class without the pretense. Keep up the great work, Poesia!
author: Virg Y.

description: This has been our go to place in the City for years. We LOVE Francesco and the other adorable wait staff. The food is great as is the atmosphere. The energy is always infectious. Love it here!
author: Michael F.

description:
Sage ravioli was spectacular. Citrus gnocci was incredible. Cucumber margarita was delicious. 

Very cosy atmosphere. Let us keep the table as long as we wanted (even though the whole place was packed!).
author: Villager E.

description:
I took my lady here for a fancy-pants Italian dinner. It was delicious. 

A little pricey but totally worth it. The service was awesome, even though we went when the place was packed.
author: Ciarán M.

description:
Some of the best Italian food I've had in the city - one of only two that I think are actually authentic and fantastic.

We went early on a Tuesday so had the restaurant to ourselves for the first hour. Great service (bonus: they staff is really, ridiculously hot) and the food was fantastic.

The gnocchi in citrus tomato sauce, the soup special (chorizo, mussels and local cranberry beans in a spicy tomato sauce - don't miss this!), and the chocolate mousse with olive oil, sea, salt, chili and pepper were phenomenal - I considered a second serving of each!

Wine suggestions were also spot-on.

They were also playing rare 1960s Italian film noir on the wall behind us - a fun addition to the ambiance which led to a couple of lively discussions.

I'll be back. Soon. And often.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Poesia remains my favorite Italian restaurant in the city.  

Their eggplant parm is divine, and I'm not usually a fan. The star of the show for me is their fish special, which to my luck is frequantly a special. I can't recall the name of the fish, but it's shipped to them from Italy, still alive. The outside is crispy, the inside is moist, and it's served whole. One of the favorite dishes I've had in my dining out life!

My most recent visit (last Tuesday) was with my boyfriend's mom. She asked our host (who is also the owner I take it) whether they have a happy hour on cocktails. I had a feeling they wouldn't since it's more of a restaurant then a lounge or bar, but the host said they don't, but would check to be sure. He returns to share the good news that for us it is happy hour and we can have half off the cocktail menu.

Their cocktails are not the usual, plain mixed drinks, they are along the lines of the Alembic, Beretta, and Orbit Room: elaborate, elegant, and delicious! I had the one with citron and basil (highly recommend). As our server, Devon, returns with our drinks we learn that after some discussion they decided to start a happy hour for first seatings! How awesome! Furthermore, Devon is the mix-master and creates the cocktails from the finer-shelf liquors (no well drinks here!) and any fresh ingredients the chef has, which tells me this list is seasonal, always fresh, and made with care (he even makes his own simple syrup for the drinks). If this isn't a drink made with TLC, I don't know what is. At $8-10 regualr price the price is fair, at $4-5 during happy hour it's insane, in a good way.

I'm proud to be part of this movement and guarantee satisfaction. Their wine list is mostly (if not all) Italian wines, which I usually don't prefer. During all my previous visits I had wine that the servers recommended based on what I told them and I was very pleased.

I love this place and you will too.
author: Aristocles P.

description: Went here with the better half for a bday dinner. Service was good. food was great. everything arrived and departed on time. Its small so there can be a wait. make reservations.
author: Tim B.

description:
I went back to Poesia tonight and I was not disappointed. 
The food is consistently good. I had the Lamb again and it was perfect!
You must try the Tomato Soup it is like no other Tomato Soup I've ever had. I like that the menu changes and pricing was very fair for what I had.
author: Sparky W.

description: Bad bad bad service. We came on a Thursday night and they happened to be busy. But, it didn't mean we should wait for an hour for our food to come out cold. They had 3 waiters circling around the restaurant and each of them came over every half an hour! The waiter didn't have a spine to come notify us about the food being late. Thanks  for the ok food but we'll never go back there. The service should reflect the price of the food and for us, it didn't. I could have gone to Burger King and get better and more caring service.
author: Lan T.

description:
Having lived in the Castro for more than 7 years, I find Poesia to be a great addition to the neighborhood as place to get a consistently good mid-range dinner (I am talking about the price range).

I have been there maybe 6 or 7 times already, and never had a bad meal, with everything ranging from good to sometimes outstanding. My personal favorites: the grilled squids and the beet/smoky cheese raviolis. They have good cocktails, too.

The environment is nice - both cozy and festive. Nice dining room and bar.

Why not 5 stars? The environment feels a little too "Fellini cliche" for my taste. Also, it's very good and definitely on my shortlist of regular places, but not "as good as it gets" for the price range (I try to stay faithful to Yelp's meaning for 4 and 5 stars).

Still, definitely check this one out if you're in the neighborhood.
author: bart m.

description:
I ended up agreeing with this comment from a review on Chow: "a mixed bag. They have lots of friendly Italian staff covering the tables... a red sauce joint re-imagined for the Castro with some trendy appetizers thrown on top" (http://chowhound.chow.com/topics/501616)

That seems just right. Very nice people. Some of the food was great: the crab ravioli was great on our night. In other dishes the pasta itself was often great, but it was drowning in way too much red-sauce that hid both the pasta and the nice meat (both a lamb dish and a pork dish had this problem).
author: idrather n.

description: Fresh, delicious Italian food with top shelf service.  A real gem, tucked away in The 'Stro.
author: Kurt L.

description:
He's not late, he's Italian. 

Poesia is in the heart of the Castro, and as such, it could not have been more friendly and attentive to a table of four men. Only one of us was wearing a wedding ring, which made three of us, apparently, fair game. The bartender was particularly amicable, mixing us some strong Negronis, making great wine recommendations (like a Monchiero Carbone, Roero Printi 2004), and even going so far as to give my friend a massage...(that's in the good waiters' handbook somewhere, right?).

The pastas are all handmade - no self respecting Italian would have it any other way - and so our meal consisted of a fantastic cauliflower orrechietti and the tantalizing burrata and eggplant tortelloni. We also had an off menu risotto that was sublime in texture/taste/consistency.  Some of our other choices were very good, but they didn't match the brilliance of these three dishes. Our pork ribs, rack of lamb and filet mignon were all highly respectable, with the only outcasts being the gnocchi and arancini, which bummed us out given how much we love both these dishes. For dessert, we had the tiramisu and a cannoli - both textbook Italian/Sicilian perfection.

Consider this: there's Italian food, Italian cooking and Italian restaurants (Sbarro be damned). Italian food can be made by anyone that can follow some simple instructions with a few key ingredients; Italian cooking - not to be confused with a cooking Italian - can be achieved through hard work and careful study (personally, I recommend Essentials of Classic Italian Cooking by Marcella Hazan); and Italian restaurants are a dime a dozen, which is why selectivity is essential (and why Yelp.* is god's gift to foodies).

In the instances when you discover a place that fits all of the above (and throw in a cooking Italian, to boot), you've got yourself a rare find. The size of this place alone is a testament to its authenticity. Restaurants in Italy are generally TINY, and the chefs are their embodiment in personality, style and substance. As such, chefs take great care to see, socialize, listen to, and enjoy their patrons. Francesco d'Ippolito, Poesia's chef, works the dining room and the kitchen, because that is how it is done en Italia.  If your meal takes anything short of two hours, then you've rushed things and probably missed out on something. Instead, expect to come for an evening and lose track of (and interest in) the time.

All told, think of Poesia not as a restaurant, but as a first rate Italian kitchen. Francesco even cooks with the "TV" on, projecting old B&W  Italian films on the wall (boy, did I ever miss the memo on this trend http://www.yelp.com/biz/specchio-san-francisco#hrid:Wz8rbSeL3drmhqk6wm9z3g).

And like all good Italian kitchens, no one walks away hungry.
author: Nils E.

description: The food was good but portions were small. So plan on appetizers and entrees for sure.The location is cute and service is friendly.
author: Maryam M.

description:
Dinner here was fantastic. I have been to Italy (lived there for several months) and can say that their pasta is authentic and tasty. The drink specials (Blood Orange Cosmo) and prosecco were excellent. 
Unlike many other restaurants, every person on staff in the restaurant was helpful and friendly. I hate when servers exclaim that they cannot help you (even when your request is for utensils and you have already been served) because you aren't their table. I also hate when staff know nothing of the food they are serving you. 
Delicious all around. Make sure to save room for dessert. Will be a return customer for sure. 
Small and cute. Great for dates, not so great for children or super-picky eaters.
author: C H.

description:
The ambiance at Poesia is exactly what I want in the first home that I buy. I not only found the space to be warm and inviting, but I absolutely adored all of the colourful art pieces strewn on their walls. They also display black and white foreign films through a projector on the wall, making your experience here feel really intimate and special. 

As for the food, holy lord on high.... so yummy and delicious. The shame about Italian food is that a little can go a long way before you reach the point of feeling painfully and absolutely stuffed. So, I consciously put myself in check and made sure I didn't renew my membership in the Clean Plate Club here the other night.  

Survey says: I'm a fan.  =)
author: Katie C.

description:
We've been to Poeasia a number of times; brought quite a number of friends there.  The food is consistently good; a refreshing change in Castro. 

My fav is the gilled calamari.
author: teatzar s.

description: We came1 hour late to our reservation and they were very accommodating on a friday night. The place is cozy, but in a charming sort of way (because its a house). Although it is small, the place is suited for a date or for groups of 6. The sound levels are definitely at the higher decibels, but it's not overwhelming. The appetizers didn't feel  heavy and the main dishes were very filling. I'd recommend the lamb shank and my girl friend got the pink pasta. They need more vegetarian options, but she was happy with her dish. So it gets a 4.
author: John R.

description:
Outstanding! 

The service here was nearing perfections. The servers work together as a seamless team. Everyone was charming and helpful with everything from helping my partner with his jacket to giving accurate descriptions of the menu. The staff treated us like we were regulars even though we were clearly two Midwest boys out of our element. Classy joint! 

The food followed the obvious theme of hospitality. Everything was great. There were many "mmmm" moments. I especially enjoyed the pesto garnish which accented the already delicious red sauce. 

It is pricey, but what isn't? Its worth it, I'd recommend Poesia to anyone.
author: Harry W.

description:
Overall, my experience was just okay. The food was pretty good; I had the signature pork dish (good pasta and sauce) but there was too much gristle and fat; my antipasti starter - the brushetta, the tomato chili paste, salami - all excellent but the anchovy brushetta stayed with me for my entire meal and the cheese just wasn't tasty. We had the chocolate souffle to share and it was well prepared and presented.  

The service was 2-3 stars at the most. There was about 10 minutes when our plates needed to be cleaned and we wanted another glass of wine and the waiters kept missing us trying to grab their attention and there were only about 5 tables full in the whole place. 

When we arrived and sat at the bar, we weren't offered an aperitif but rather shown the menu and told the specials and seeing as we were 30 minutes away from ordering at that point, it seemed a bit pointless. I asked where the meat comes from and was told Australia for the lamb and various other countries for different cuts...I don't think there's any excuse for SF restaurants to not buy from sustainable local farms these days...maybe that explains why my pork was a bit stomach churning.

The interior is cool, it's small but very comfortable but it's too small to warrant the movie dominating one whole wall. TVs and the like have a place in Sport's Bars, elsewhere they are distracting at best.

This is the kind of place that I'd love to recommend to friends, but it didn't offer the entire package for me.
author: Jo M.

description:
I've been meaning to try this spot for a while & finally did. Sadly it must have been an off night cause other than the buratta & the bread nothing else we tried was any good. Not the risotto, nor the Pink fettuccine.
Atmosphere is cool, kind of loud however.
Try the margarita. Cheers!
author: S. R.

description:
Wonderful.

Romantic. Intimate. Cozy. Great food.

Perfect set by the window. Sofia was attentive and lovely. 

Can't wait to go back.
author: Maria Elena R.

description:
Owner Francesco has created perhaps the BEST Italian restaurant in San Francisco.  This second-floor walk up restaurant spotlights the flavors of Calabria (the toe of the boot of Italy) and Southern- style cooking.

I ordered the Gnocchi with Spicy Citrus Sauce, which was made with Ricotta and not potato, which changes everything: it had bite!  My Pollo al Mattone was also fabulous!  The bread is fresh and dipping it into the oil was marvelous.  Francesco had the Fellini movie "8 1/2" running in the background, and the whole atmosphere with the coral -colored table clothes was pure romance and Italian hospitality.  A MUST GO!
author: Margaret L.

description: It felt like a cozy, warm family Italian restaurant transplanted from North Beach.  The appetizers and entrees were all very fresh and delicious.  The restaurant was a bit stuffy but it was Friday night and they were completely packed.  Our server did a good job - when she forgot our drinks she apologized and quickly brought them over.  Based on the outstanding, fresh quality of the pasta and salads, we will return soon.
author: philip k.

description:
A North Beach gem in the heart of The Castro! Terrific, authentic Italian cuisine.

Starters: The antipasta misto had a nice selection of cured meats, olives, fried zucchini & goat cheese. The special bruschetta (thank you Jessica, our server, for teaching me the proper pronunciation of this common enough word) topped with local Chantreles in a buttery drizzle of sauce. 

Dinner: My Dungeness crab raviolis were stuffed and al dente perfect with a sprinkle of mixed greens with baked cherry tomatoes on top. My friend's rack of lamb was juicy and full of flavor, get it rare (it's local too). My boyfriend's Fusselli pasta with braised pork had one of the freshest tomatoes sauces, it almost squeaked.

Wines: Start with the Prosecco, light and sparkly, switched to the Pecorino (I thought that was a cheese:) then finished with the Arneis, full flavored but delicate, not smack you in the face dry.

Dessert: A must try dessert is the chocolate mousse with chili and olive oil (yes you read correctly). Quite a combination. The tiramisu was a layer of flavors, that thank goodness the chef had the good sense NOT to drown in cocoa powder. Grand Marinier soaked cakes with a creamy, almost zabbione like textured filling. A candied orange peel on top with a mint sprig was a nice touch.

Service: From the moment we mounted the steps and the host opened the door and greeted us warmly in Italian, I knew we had found the right spot. Jessica our server was absolutely wonderful, funny and knowledgeable. There when we needed her, but not hovering. The rest of the waitstaff assisted whatever table needed help. This is the kind of service that everybody needs to incorporate in their establishments. Even as the small dining area filled up, the waitstaff just kept going. Clearing tables and setting up for the next guests with ease and grace.

Price: Yes, the secondi dishes were $19-$29, but the rest of the menu is very reasonable. Wines are at the upper end per glass, but you get to explore true Italian imports with little risk.

Cons: only two; the noise level is quite loud (especially with the braying hyenas two tables over - yes you know who you were) so pleasant conversations are out of the question. Also one of the waiters decided to take a break right behind me and cracked his knuckles several times. Perhaps he didn't think I could hear, due to the din of the dining room, but he was only 10" away from my ear. Not a major issue, since he was cute, but management might want to take note.

All in all an extremely pleasant evening! We WILL be returning soon.
author: Doug W.

description:
Where do you take out of town guests requesting Italian food in the Castro?  Poesia.  

We really enjoyed our evening.  The space intimate and warm.  The service attentive and not overbearing.  The tables were not too close, a tough thing to do in a small space.  We all remarked on the Dino De Laurentis Italian film showing on the wall, nice touch.   
Ambiance: 4 stars (temperature a little warm for us)
Service:  5 stars

Appetizers:
Gnocchi Silani:  Ricotta Cheese Gnocchi, Citrus Sauce, Pachino Tomatoes
a winning dish, the flavors bright and the texture perfect.
Insalata Caprese:  Local Heirloom Tomatoes, Fresh Burrata Cheese, and a light Balsamic vinaigrette.  YUM!  Gotta love the fresh Heirloom tomatoes while still available.
Bruscetta of the day:  Last night it was the perfect blend of sauteed mushrooms.   

Dinner:  All the pastas are house made, and it shows.  We enjoyed all the dishes.  The pastas were perfectly cooked with the right amount of sauce, nothing swimming on the dish.  Really appreciated the fresh shave of parmigiano reggiano tableside...YUM!
Orecchiette al Forno: Baked in the oven shell Pasta, Local Artichokes, Portobello Mushrooms and Provolone Cheese.  The winning dish of the table.  Everyone loved the creamy texture and flavor profiles.  A reason to go back for sure.  
Fileji di Renato: Corkscrew Pasta, Pork Ribs, Tomato Sauce.  The meat slow cooked and tender, but this was the weakest dish at the table.  The portion small.
Fettuccine al Ragu di Agnello:  Lamb Shank Meat Ragu'  Tender lamb in a delicious red sauce.  Hearty and filling.
Tagliatelle Prosciutto di Parma e Fagiolini: Prosciutto di Parma Aged 24 months, Romano beans, Extra Virgin Olive Oil.  Definitely my favorite dish.  The flavor balance perfect.  I would go back for this, and will.
Food:  4 stars, some of the portions on the small side, which we were not expecting.  Would have appreciated more direction from the server about portion size.  In hindsight, we should have ordered salads and shared the risotto special as well.  We brought our own wine.  The corkage $20.00 per bottle.  We didn't stay for dessert (opted for ice cream instead).

A very enjoyable find, thanks to Yelp.    

Rating: 4.3 stars
author: Kim A.

description: It was very good! But the service takes too long and the place is really noisy! Other than that great food and beautiful decor of the place!
author: Jimmy N.

description:
The high turnover of restaurants in the Castro steered me away from trying Poesia over the last few years. I regret waiting so long.

I owed my friend dinner from somewhat of a lost bet. It was monday night and I suggested we try Poesia since we've seen it, heard great things about it, but never made the effort to drop in.

Our table was one of two dining this Monday evening. The service was polished (it took a moment to understand what the server was saying, but that's culture for ya) and attentive.

Starters: grilled sardines, beheaded and deboned: fantastic!
              mussels with a tomato broth: succulent

Main Dish: fillet mignon on a bed of arugula: both medium rare and     medium cooked to perfection

We were so full and could not make room for the tiramisu with grand marnier I was eyeing on the menu. 

Oh well, next time!

P.S.- the wine list is extensive and expensive, but i'd throw some bucks down for the overall pleasing dining experience
author: Jonny M.

description:
OMG! this restaurant is amazing. From the moment I walked in, I was welcomed and greeted with open arms. I felt like they had known me for years. I was made to feel like an old friend that had been away for some time. I was impressed with the charm and elegance of the room. Good Times and good people.

I was there on a first date. The wait staff was fun, engaging and very efficent. This Team was a well run machine. They all helped each other and my stay was incredible.

Now, the food......OMG OMG OMG! Absolutley the best food I had on my vacation. I tried things I wasnt familiar with and yet I'm so happy I stepped out of my box. From the appetizers, to the wine, to salad to the entrees all were amazing with bold flavors and great textures. I want more!

Great ambiance, great Teamwork, great people, great food. GREAT GREAT GREAT! and one more time.....OMG!
author: Kelly O.

description:
SO wonderful.  My friend and I shared the orecchiette and eggplant parmigiana. The orecchiette was handmade... smothered with cheese with a cauliflower puree.... I'm salivating just thinking about it.  Also, I've been looking for a great eggplant parm in the city and this one really hit the spot... tender... great sauce... not a bit of bitterness. 

The boys got meat dishes that they loved but I'm not sure what specifically.

The strawberry dessert was very good.  Simple but delicious. 

All in all - my new favorite Italian spot that is in walking distance of my apartment!  (Which is saying a lot because I live right by Delfina and Farina.)
author: Natasha P.

description:
We had been wanting to try Poesía for a long time, allured by its romantic air and tempting menu items, but we were really disappointed with the food. 

The service was very friendly, but the meal got off to a bad start with our appetizer, the grilled eggplant, tomato and zucchini with fresh mozzarella salad. For $11, it was very small with only a couple slices of each veggie. It was really bland but the worst part was the tomato -- hard and pale and not grilled at all! We were surprised that they would even buy that tomato, much less put it on a plate. 

The server was very nice and took that off our bill. Then we had the gnocchi, which were tender and chewy and cheesy, pretty tasty. We also had the grilled seabass, which i found to be tender but lacking seasoning. I know that Italian cuisine is about letting the ingredients shine, but you do have to add a bit of salt and pepper at least to bring out that flavor.

The worst part was that for the whole first part of the meal, two older people were singing opera at the front. That might be nice if everyone is quietly listening to a concert, but with the din of everyone eating and talking it sounded like wailing in the background. NOT romantic.

We won't be back.
author: Créme d.

description: Consistent excellent food, great cocktails, and comfortable warm environment. The staff is always friendly and on top of their game. A true gem.
author: Aldus M.

description: A taste of Italy in SF! I had no idea this wonderful place existed but I'm so thankful to have experienced it. I wanted to take my roommate to dinner and told him to pick the place. So we ended up here. You feel like you are walking into someones beautiful victorian home then, once you walk through the door it becomes a small italian gem. The hostess greeted us with a big sincere smile and took us to our table. We ordered a wonderful bottle of wine and several amazing appetizers: Bruchetta, Zucchini blossoms and beet salad. All were phenominal! The main dishes were equally as wonderful as well. But it was about the service and sense of genuine desire to provide a fantastic expereince from the moment you enter until the moment you leave. It is a very cozy restaurant so if you dont like people you may look to sit at the bar area but we enjoyed talking with the table next to us and checking out all the dishes that came out. I will definitely be back for sure!
author: Miriam L.

description: Top Notch!  Came in on Thanksgiving evening, no reservation, and were promptly seated.  Each of the staff members were pleasant and attentive.  Every dish we ordered was exceptional- fresh ingredients, very balanced and complimentary flavors.  Coffee was phenomenal as was the tiramisu.  Can't say enough good things about the experience.  Quality of food and service far exceeded the cost.   Poesia is not to be missed!
author: Bobby R.

description: I sat at the bar for a quick meal as the place was packed.  It was a good meal just not my ideal Italian dish.  Great ambiance and friendly staff.
author: Jim R.

description: Poesia is absolute perfection.  Great service and fantastic food.  You won't be disappointed.
author: Teresa P.

description:
I enjoyed dinner with my family here.  The food was very good.  I had excellent roast chicken, and the special appetizer with porcini mushrooms and burratta was delicious, as was the tomato bread soup.  Our waiter was friendly and sweet and the ambiance was nice and homey.  It was an all-around lovely evening once we were seated.  Unfortunately, it began with waiting at the host stand for fifteen minutes with no host in sight.  Six parties collected at the door and all were wondering if they could hope to receive a greeting, let alone a table.  Several parties left and all were confused. I know things can be insane and stressful, and I am fine with almost any problem as long as I receive a status update.  Had he come around with a "so sorry, I'll be with you in a few minutes," that would have been fine, but it was as if he was hiding!  I don't know what may have been going on behind the scenes, but it was a bit strange.  When he finally arrived, he offered no explanation and told us we had longer to wait, blaming the table ahead of us.  This restaurant could be a neighborhood gem but it took twenty minutes to ease into a pleasant meal after the delay at the host stand.  And pleasant it was.  

Disclaimer: I get testy when I haven't eaten, so that may have affected this review.
author: Eliza L.

description:
Do you want to be welcomed home by your Italian brother that you never knew you had?

Do you want to be flirted with by your Italian brother's gay best friend?

Do you want your Italian brother's cousin's wife's spanish husband to create one of the most memorable dinners you'll ever have the honor of eating in the Castro?

If you answered yes to any of the above, you need to go to Poesia.

One of the best Italian restaurants in the city and it's amazing that it's in that restaurant cursed townhouse on 18th St.

Clearly, the curse has been lifted.  Even if you're just going to the bar for a glass of prosecco you'll be treated warmly and offered delicious bread and olive oil.  But really, stay for dinner and enjoy their menu that's updated quite often.  One thing never changes, the housemade pasta is always perfectly made.

Sometimes they do get a bit in the weeds (hey, it's popular now, deal with it) so I'm giving it 4 out of 5 stars, but relax, order a bottle of wine immediately and you'll thank me later.
author: john m.

description: Had the squid ink risotto. Really delicious. Had to wait a bit longer than I liked for our food, but they were really busy and their food is obviously carefully prepared so I can't slight them much for that.
author: Kyle F.

description:
Poesia was chosen by my brother (a foodie) from out of town, and not only was it good, it was amazing!

We booked thru open table and called the restaurant  ahead for parking advice, they offered an OUTSTANDING spot under the restaurant in the owners garage. In real life, parking is tough in the Castro. This was a once in lifetime (small cars only) gift from the manager!! Restaurant requires a climb up a big flight of steps, has the feeling of an intimate living room over the street.

The food was fresh and engaging and very fresh California Italian and we LOVED it !! Service was A+,warmish living room atmosphere with cool vintage videos on the back wall. We  arrived on a Thurs at 730 and the restaurant was packed later.  Very fresh and interesting menu, wonderful marinated huge and tender calamari and salad, large breaded sardines, yummy gnocchi with ricotta and buttery flavored tomato sauce (golden tomatoes?) and pasta with lamb ragu and tomato. Desserts were pretty and OK, best was lemon with meringue and vanilla ice cream. Areas to improve: better bread (need one of the many excellent SF bakers), cooler room temp (in summer), desserts need a master to match the food. I notice ceramics, liked the porcelain plates, simple white ceramics with double edge feel.. This place has a wonderful wait staff and low pretentious vibe. Feels like we could all move to my house next week...an intimate dinner with friends...

Fairly priced, gracious and informed service and warm friendly feel. We had some AMAZING red wine from Italy, $11/glass. Aperitif and proseco were just OK. Need to grab the info to order a case of the amazing Italian red. The best I've had in a restaurant by the glass in a while.  Not the cool and too impersonal corporate touch of bigger more famous top 10 and equal/better food. I could go once a week.

Loved it, will  be back with friends!!
author: Peggy C.

description: I like the place and the setting but the food was very unspectacular. The portions are a little small and the pastas did not stand out to me. The pasta with pork ribs in tomato sauce lacked an identity; sauce was a little plain and the meat, even though tender, had no flavors to contribute. Staff is very hospitable and friendly which made the experience pleasant.
author: Ed L.

description:
Poesia was not supposed to be good and I waited 2 years before venturing in.  Place was astoundingly good.  it's sitting on the second floor of a victorian flat in the Castro.  We had some really nice dishes  First thing to note is that I believe their homemade pastas (all of their pastas are made on the premises) rival those of Farina or Delphina  They serve more and are priced about as well.  But the pasta might be better.

We had a beet salad, fusili pasta, and a whole seabass (baked).  All were prepared perfectly, and there were no down points.   I'm pretty sure everything we had was a special, so not normally on the menu, but I'll be back there for the pasta and the lack of hip Italian. I'm also going to note that getting there early makes a difference.  They didn't have enough servers when we were there, and once full, the service seemed to get a bit slow.
author: Wes W.

description:
Hands down the best restaurant in the Castro!!  I celebrated my birthday here with my parents, sisters and husband this week and we had a wonderful experience.  They sat us at an intimate table in the corner near the bar & if felt like we were being served a home cooked-meal, but with out-of-this world service (and no dishes to do afterwards! yipeee!).  The man who booked our reservation over the phone greeted us at the door with a warm smile (and he even said, "you must be Sara"!).  So cute.

We started by sharing the salad w/nectarines; heirloom tomato salad (hold the anchovies); beet salad & amazing tomato soup.  Best tomato soup ever.

Then a bunch of us shared entrees.  My hubby & dad both had the filet with arugula (WHOA!  It was butter melting in your mouth!).  My mom & I shared the eggplant parmigana, which was tasty and light--very good!  My sisters shared the lemon chicken with veggies.

We left feeling satisfied, but not too full.  This is a great restaurant and I think that they will be successful and hopefully a staple in the Castro for years to come.  Go try it!  Enjoy :)
author: Sara W.

description:
Delicious food, not grossly obese portions, small intimate space and great attention from the server.  Wish the menu had more choices. 

The beet salad was delicious, as was the scallop pasta. Would consider coming here again, as it's very conveniently located right in the Castro area.
author: Matthew G.

description:
We were told about a new-ish place that opened in the Castro that was pretty good, so we made a reservation w/ some friends & went on a Saturday night.

Arrived at 7, it was pretty empty, though filled up completely later on.  nice ambiance, decor, liked the italian movies projected on the wall.  once full it was pretty cramped to get around, squeezing between several chairs to walk from our table to the restroom 

my three companions all had the special grilled squid appetizer, which I tasted & thought was quite good.  I had the carpaccio, which had an interesting  preparation - thicker than normal & wrapped around the greens & anchovies: it was tasty.

had the fileji pasta w/ pork ribs for entree - also tasty.  I don't recall what kind of red wine we had, it wasn't super remarkable however.

for dessert I had the unusual chocolate mousse w/ salt, powdered chili &  olive oil, which I actually didn't care for that much.  the chocolate itself was great, but seemed way too salty, there was a bit too much oil & couldn't taste chili at all.   I had regular coffee w/ dessert.  it was really good coffee in my opinion, but it seemed really odd that after finishing a cup it was simply taken away rather than refilled.

So, all in all, I liked the food fine, the service was good.  I give three stars for it being a solid dinner with a few flaws, but not making any of us say "that was *really* good"
author: Mark R.

description:
I love this restaurant.  From the beautiful chandeliers, the intriguing silent film pieces projected onto the walls, and the calming colours of the interior - it's a great place to be.

My daughter and I came here after the final show at the Silent Film Fest at the Castro Theatre.  It's a short walk from the theatre and also from the Muni Castro Underground Station.

Benjamin our waiter was wonderful. Francesco, the owner was welcoming and sweet when called upon to explain about their 3 homemade liqueurs (which are wonderful).

Anyways, the pasta is to die for, the tomato bread soup is wonderful, and the poppyseed cake with fruit macerated in liqueur was the high light of our dinner.

We came here late on a Sunday night and it was quiet, I can see that it may become a tad bit boisterous early evening but the food is what brings you here.

Drool, might come go back tomorrow.

Oh, they locally source their produce and use organic/grass fed food as much as possible.
author: LMoo P.

description:
3.5 stars. 

Cute, charming Italian fare in the Castro. The owner is super nice too. We wanted a place on a Wednesday night that took reservations, and everything on the menu looked delicious.

We had the gnocchi appetizer which was creamy and perfect to share with 3 people. I ordered the lamb shank linguini which was tasty. My friend had the pumpkin ravioli (sweet), and other friend had the pasta dish with the sausage. You could tell the pasta was made in-house and homemade which made it that much better. It's a cute intimate restaurant to catch up with friends, as it is social but not too loud.

I enjoyed my experience here and would order squid risotto if they had it back in season! Too bad we couldn't have it...
author: Jeanne C.

description:
2 Stars

I read all the positive reviews on Yelp and I decided to give it a try! What a disappointment!!! After sitting for 10 minutes I had to ask for water and bread. The water came at room temperature I had to ask for ice which took another 10 minutes. I ordered a vodka and soda which came with lots of ice and soda very small amount of vodka. The portion were very small, smaller than those at a French restaurant. Limited menu... The quality of the food was very poor and way over priced. Small tight sitting with small tables. Our waiter was wearing way to much cologne for a food establishment. I would not go back.  There are much better restaurants in the area.
author: John L.

description: Had the pasta and it was over cooked and the sauce, NO TASTE and very bland.  The lamb dish was way overcooked and dry.  Very disappointing establishment.  Saw the owner, he seems to pick and choose what table he wants to visit.  Tacky, since aren't we all overpaying customers?  There are much better places to eat at.
author: Kim M.

description: Had a very nice meal and great service at this place.  the menu is small but interesting and has 3 homemade pasta dishes.  we started with the special asparagus wrapped in speck with buttata which was outstanding.  also had the grilled calamari  which were perfectly cooked large pieces with a nice small salad.  we had t the fettucine with lamb which was just ok . we also had the sea bass in parchment paper which was just slightly overcooked and suprisingly didn't come with anything but the fish.  we also had the squid ink ravoli which was very good.  wish we had time for desert as the list looked great.  pasta's were very reasonably priced and a decent size portion.  i just wish they had more pasta's to choose from.  corkage was $20. place is cozy and a good spot in the castro.  leave extra time for parking.
author: Pm H.

description: I'll give that it was Dining out For Life night but the food could do with some seasoning. I had the radicchio salad a little slat please. Carpaccio. Again salt the salad. Gnocchi whole tasty need more. The one thing that was brilliant was the stuffed sardines. Incredible. But maybe pair with some roasted fig. Still good though. Over all. Very bland food. Good service on a busy night. Not great by the glass wine selection. Oh well. For a good cause but MUCH. Better italian food in this town than here.
author: Skip E.

description:
I came here after purchasing a voucher, which came with 2 glasses of wine, 2 starters, 2 entrees, and 2 desserts. The restaurant is a cozy lil place. I enjoyed the environment and set up. The service was good and the waiters were all very friendly which is always plus.

As for the food, it wasn't bad. For starters we had the Frisee salad & calamari alla griglia, which were both decent. Not much flavor though. I had the Orecchiette al Griglia (shell pasta baked with cheese, mushrooms, cauliflowers...). The dish came out in a soup bowl and did look like soup & not that appetizing with the missed oils & cheese, but I think it was supposed to be served that way. Anyhow, it was mostly cheese & shell pasta because I barely got any of the mushrooms & cauliflower. My date got the the Mediterranean sea-bass and I thought it was good. I enjoyed the flavors and was refreshing with the lemon. I enjoyed the red velvet tiramisu cake. It was very light & soft. I would definitely come back for the seabass & red velvet tiramisa cake :)
author: Nai S.

description:
Pros:
   Cozy Atmosphere
   Friendly Service
   Great Italian Cuisine
   Nice Selection of Wine
   Good Location
Cons:
   Can be a bit crammed. Very small restaurant.
   Parking in Castro is hard to find
author: Tom W.

description:
Meh, I wasn't impressed. My bff gave me a groupon for this restaurant which was nice since I didn't have to cook dinner. I made reservations at 5:30 PM on a Monday night. We were the first customers in and seated, but it was filled by 6 PM. Service was great, no complaints there. Decor was nice and welcoming. The food is what the 3 stars are for. I would honestly say 2.5 stars to be brutally honest. 

We ordered the prosciutto with asparagus and cheese for the appetizer. It came pretty fast, which was great since my husband and I were both hungry. I didn't like it.. but my husband seemed to enjoy it. 
My husband ordered the lamb shank fettuccine.. he said there was a good amount of meat, but was lacking some flavor. The quality is obviously there, but the flavor wasn't. He was shy to ask for salt and pepper.. he didn't want to offend the cooks. I ordered the deboned sea bass, from my BFF's recommendation. I didn't like it.. much at all. It came with potatoes and veggies which were good. The fish was just... IDK lacking in the flavor department. There was a sauce that was on the side of the fish, but even when I dipped the fish in the sauce it wasn't heaven. It was more like.. IDK I just can't describe how plain it was for me. Maybe it was an off day.. or maybe my BFF and I have totally diff taste buds. (she is a smoker LOL) Presentation was nice.. I have to give them that. 

It was a nice dinner out overall, but me and hubs had the urge for more food as we walked out of Poesia. So we walked across the street to Nizaro's and enjoyed a slice of Pizza. :P
author: Alice E.

description: Again, I think that I feel the same way about Poesia that I do about Farina: For the price, it's really nothing THAT special.  I can get the same quality food for 1/2 the price elsewhere and there really is nothing revolutionary or even sensational about this restaurant.  I mean, don't get me wrong, the restaurant's dinning room is cozy, intimate, and can be down right romantic.  And while the service is impeccable, the food is only moderately above average.  The squid ink risotto was good but uninspired.  When I envision my last meal, none of these dishes even make the top 20.  When friends come into town and want Italian, this restaurant barely crosses my mind.  When it's date night and I'm trying to figure out where to take the boyfriend, Poesia isn't even on the radar.  Moral of the story: for decent food served by an excellent service staff in an above average location, try Poesia.
author: Sean H.

description: Our good friend Fernando gave Dave and I a sweet gift certificate to this charming, tiny, very upscale Italian restaurant.  Tiny it really is and the tables are pretty crowded and jammed together.  We arrived a few minutes early and the host greeted us with no smile, but a para military and dismissive attitude, but we didn't really see him again until we left, so he wasn't dampening our dining.  We were given a small two top table along a wall banquet and promptly serve water and our menu's.  A waiter appeared right after with a spot on description of the nights specials, and they all sounded great, damn these choices between great alternatives.  We ordered two different entree's and started with their quite good version of Caesar salad adorned gracefully with fresh Monterrey Bay Sardines.  We then shared a fettucine pasta with braised lamb shank and for entree's I had the sliced filet mignon over an arrugala salad with sliced parmesan, and Dave had pork tenderloin wrapped in pancetta.  All the sauces and pasta are hand made slowly, gently and deliciously in the restaurant every day.  The service once past the host was excellent, the ambience perfect for a romantic dinner although a little cramped for hand holding.  They have a full bar and specialize in some amazing concoctions that the best mixologists would have trouble matching.  This is a wonderful little Castro gem.
author: Stu S.

description:
This was my first visit to Poesia and I was impressed. Heard about it on KQED's "Check Please!" several months ago.  It's located in the heart of the Castro in a walk-up location previously occupied by other restaurants before it.

My GF had an artichoke "cake" and eggplant parmigiana, and I had baccala (salt cod) and pan fried brazzino (seabass).  The artichoke "cake" was a fried crust with pureed artichoke in it surrounded by a tomato-based sauce. The baccala was flaky and accompanied by a light cream sauce. Both were excellent.  Eggplant parmigina is not a favorite of mine, but my GF said it was very good.  The brazzino was stuffed w/lemons, garlic and cilanto, which gave the fish a wonderful taste and flavor.  Ended the meal with a strawberry & chocolate cannoli and a complementary glass of Poesia's homemade chocolate liqueur, both of which were excellent. 

Service was  friendly, courteous & attentive.  Plates weren't wished away before we had finished and noticed that the waiter backed off on his own from taking my empty brazzino plate when he saw that I was still sopping up the sauce with bread.
