Our water and prosecco glasses were always filled, entrees were delivered by 2 waiters, and we were escorted to the door which was opened for us when we left.   This is the best service I've received for some time -- even better than received recently at much more expensive restaurants.   

A definite find and highly recommended!
author: Martin C.

description:
Went to Poesia for dinner before our group went to the Sound of Music Sing-a-long around the corner at Castro Theatre.  This is a cozy little place that holds about 25-30 people tops.  It seems like the people that come are mostly regulars.  When we were there, only about 6 other people were dining and at the best point there were about 10-12.  Our group of 5 fit nicely into the central area.

The place is moderately lit and inviting.  The people that work there actually are Italian, which is a good sign.  Our server, Mattia, was patient and attentive and answered all of our questions.  The menu is small but varied, so we had a lot of questions.  We agreed to order different things so we could try them all out.  Gotta love the Asian family style dinners.

Tortino Carciofi, a fried artichoke cake.  Flakey, crispy, and very good.  We cut it into 6 slices and there were 5 of us ... imagine the struggle when we all wanted the 6th slice but are too polite to take the last one. [4/5]

Menabrea, an Italian beer.  I'm no beer expert, but this was good.  Kind of lite Stella Artois but a little punchier and more body. [3/5]

Orecchiette al Forno, very good, probably my favorite dish.  This dish just seemed earthy and hearty.  [4/5]

Fish of the day.  Sea bass that was poached and lightly seasoned.  Good, but not quite enough flavor and pretty pricey for the lack of taste and preparation. [3/5]

Eggplant Parmigiana. Pretty good, you can tell the eggplant was good quality and not musht.  I actually like this dish a little heartier with more cheese, kinda old school.  Good but not great.  [3/5]

Gnocchi silani.  Appetizer of gnocchi with ricotta and heirloom tomato sauce.  This is not nearly as dense as they gnocchi we usually know.  This is partially due to its freshness, gnocchi made fresh can afford to be lighter and less dense. [3/5]

Fileji al Ragu.  This is supposed to be their favorite dish, pasta with pork ribs and roasted garlic.  The pasta is very good but I was expecting both a little more pork and a little more flavor from the pork.  It is not bad but for $20 I expect a little more substance.  If you're in a group, definitely try this one but if you had one dish go with the Orecchiette. [3/5]

This was a good dining experience and we had fun.  Thankfully we got the 2 appetizers because the dishes were average sized but not quite enough for a large appetite. Torn between 3 and 4 stars because the quality doesn't quite justify the cost of $33/person without any alcohol (I had the one beer).
author: Dave K.

description:
Small restaurant that could be easily missed

Pro:
-Good for groups
-Interesting decor


Con:
-Forgot the name of my order but the chicken was bit dry
-Sardine appetizer was way overcharged for 3 little sardines
author: Jenny L.

description:
Tried Poesia for the first time last Friday evening.  

I ordered the lamb shank and my BF order the grilled whole fish.  They took all the bones from the fish and it was pleasure to eat.  The fish was fresh, properly seasoned and very tasty.  The lamb shank came with pasta and was also very tasty.  The service was attentive and good.  The restaurant was packed and all the customers are having a good time and enjoying their food.

I would definitely go back and do consider it as one of the best restaurant in the Castro.
author: Sfscubaman T.

description:
Intimate Delicious Sexy Italian Fare in a Quiet Victorian Flat, YUM!  You can Whisper to your beloved across the table:)

We couldn't tell who the owner was because everyone there seemed to have a sense of propriety about them.  They made us feel very at home *and* like special guests both simultaneously!  

The dishes we ordered knocked our sox off as well!
author: Laura B.

description:
Nice location on the 2nd floor of a converted house. Shows movies on the wall, which is a nice touch. But, don't plan for fast service, especially on busy and weekend nights. Friendly staff, but they do overbook reservations, so we had to wait for a table to open up.

Food - overall, very good - the appetizer of sardines (4/order) was delicious. This is NOT typical Italian American, as others have said - so, it is nice welcome change from many of the other places. Nice, cozy, but somewhat loud atmosphere.
author: MandS R.

description:
The food at Poesia easily warrants 4 stars, but ultimately we found the restaurant overpriced, and service rushed.

I had a special rack of lamb ($36), an absolutely delicious Gnocci starter with a citrus cream sauce ($12 for maybe a half cup of pasta).  My partner had an anchovy and heirloom tomato salad and a special pasta with zucchini blossoms, both of which he enjoyed a lot.

We brought our own wine ($20 corkage), and the tab was $150 with tip, so we left feeling that we'd had many better meals with as good or better atmosphere and service in San Fran for less.
author: Wino K.

description:
Cute little place and great place to go for a date. It is very small but very welcoming and warm. To my surprised they had a full bar too. 

Our waiter was great and very attentive. He told of all the specials and of course as Yelpers we all looked at the reviews of what's great to eat here. To start we shared the fried artichoke, which was really good. Then again anything fried is good. We also go the Gnocchi which was very light, but the sauce was on the tangy side for me. 

I end up getting the special of the night which was a whole fish for one that came with a side of veggies. Other got the pork pasta and "ears" pasta with mushrooms, and Eggplant Parm for dinner. Of course we tried each others dishes. I enjoyed my fish, it was perfectly cooked and was light and good. Since I didn't get to eat my fish at Thea this made up for it. The veggies was good too with came with broccoli and baby carrots. 

Overall dinner was great, good, and filling. I enjoyed my fish dish and the "ears" pasta the best. I would love to come back when I am in the neighborhood again.
author: Donna Y.

description: Wonderful Italian in the Castro, which is welcome in a good-food wasteland despite the sparkling liveliness of the neighborhood.  The branzino was flavorful and exactly fishy enough, wonderfully oily without being greasy or over-salty.   The owner is charming and extremely competent.  Plus, it's in the cutest Victorian right on 18th Street.  Good for date night or larger parties.
author: rebecca g.

description:
I have been here many times,but it keeps getting better and better. Now there is a new bartender named Teddy from Cuba! Great personality. Sit at the bar and get to know this guy! 
We had 3 appetizers. Sardines, grilled calamari and a bruscheta with duck!  Each one was perfect!
author: Eileen C.

description:
After seeing this restaurant for a few years, my partner and I finally decided to give it a try.
There is nothing particularly appealing about the restaurant when you look at it from the street; as a matter of fact it's pretty easy to miss.
Once you climb the stairs (yes, you have to climb a set of stairs to get in) and walk in the front door, the charm becomes apparent.  It's a cut little place and the staff are all friendly and fairly attentive.
The real draw for any restaurant, though, is the food.  

We began our meal with a Grilled Calamari Salad.  The Calamari itself was tasty, though I will nit-pick and complain that while the mantle was excellent, the tentacles were a bit overdone.  I would have liked a creamier dressing, but overall it was something I would eat again.

We each had a plate of pasta: Lamb Ragu for him, Pork Ribs for me.  
Major bonus points for the silky texture of the house-made pasta, but equally major negative points for the sauces.  The pasta was so delicious that I really WANTED to like the sauce, but I couldn't get past the Chef Boyardee-esque flavor profile.  We aren't exactly light eaters, but neither of us finished our plates.
Yes; it made me sad.

The plates themselves were beautifully presented and looked amazing, I just wish the food had been better.

For dessert we split an order of chocolate mousse that came plated on a smear of devonshire cream finished with a drizzle of extra virgin olive oil and a light dusting of cayenne.  
Conceptually it was interesting, but again, the execution was sadly lacking.
After about two bites I was finished and we left more than half of it on the plate.

The coffee was excellent, as was the (small) wine selection.
I would probably go back for appetizers, but definitely not for dinner.
author: Christopher H.

description:
My dining experience at Poesia was what dining dreams are made of!  My three friends and I walked out of the restaurant feeling like princesses.  If only every night out were that way!

The beginning of our night started weeks earlier at the Yelp Unwrapped holiday party.  My plus one and I enjoyed the samples at Poesia's table so the restaurant owner, Francesco, offered us free wine tastings and desserts for our first visit.

The ambiance is delightful and stirred immediate excitement in all of us.  Poesia is a cozy second story restaurant that is ideal for intimate parties.  The maître d' was charming and kind and made good conversation while we waited for our table.  Francesco also made it a point to give us a warm welcome and explanation of the restaurant's history.  The paintings on the wall were dramatic and powerful and I found them even more alluring after learning they were paintings of family friends and that the woman in the main painting was his grandmother.  

Four girls shared 3 appetizers and 2 entrees.  It was the perfect amount of food.  Among the risotto with scallops, gnocchi, and squid salad, the fresh squids from Monterey over a bed of arugula was easily the most tastiest appetizer.  Our mushroom linguine was great and filling.  I believe they hand make all of their pasta, which makes a huge difference. We also ordered the sea bass...and it was delicious!

The wine tastings and dessert certainly made our dinner.  The wines Francesco brought over paired well with our food and for "tastings", our cups were overflowing!  For orange liqueur fans, the grand marnier tiramisu is the choice for you!  My favorite dessert, however, was the cooked pear covered in chocolate served with a scoop of gelato.  You MUST have this with a cup of Americano!  

At the end of our evening, we could not stop talking about how we hoped to return soon with dates.  Planning to return is surely one of the best signs for a fantastic restaurant.  Thanks, Poesia!  Until next time  :)
author: Sarah Z.

description: Very nice setting, it's a pretty small and intimate restaurant. I came here for a romantic dinner with my boyfriend and we both really liked it. However, it's good for groups as well, as it's not a very quiet setting. The food was pretty good, nothing too special, but the service was excellent. Both the host and out waitress were very attentive and kind. Overall, I really enjoyed my experience here and would definitely come back!
author: Pega H.

description:
This cozy and beautiful restaurant was fantastic!  It is tucked upstairs in an old gutted San Francisco house, with a dimly lit space adorned by ranucculus roses!  Reservations are right, so I would recommend making one.  

Their pastas are homemade and taste authentically Italian.  Things we loved devouring or chugging:

Prosecco rose
Tomato soup
Pear/chicory salad
Gnocchi
SHORTRIB PASTA (this was the winner of the night).  The pasta is tossed in a light tomato sauce, with two perfectly tender ribs stuck in there.

Dessert:  Chocolate mousse with rock salt.  The combination was phenomenal.

I highly recommend this restaurant if you are walking distance of Castro.  Otherwise, prepare to cross your fingers for some close parking or accept the fact that you may need to walk 16 blocks from your car (as our friends had to)!
author: Lady Q.

description: I'd have to say, it's the best Italian I've had in the city. Small and authentic.
author: Jon Z.

description: Every dish is great here. The setting is cozy and romantic, second floor overlooking 18th in the castro. Service can be a bit scattered, but they make up for it by being charming and welcoming. Mostly the food is terrific, original and authentic.
author: Benoit M.

description:
I have been debating whether or not to write this review. Though the waitstaff didn't have anything to do with my horrible experience here, it was one of the most horrible dining experiences ever.

It was date night and Eugy picked the place.  We find parking nearby and walk on over.  When we found the restaurant, both of us were surprised. This is someones house that has been turned into a restaurant. Seriously. The living room has been made into the dining room and the bar is in the entry hall along with some stools and low table to sit and wait or have a glass of wine at. Very interesting. I loved it. On the wall is a large projector that has an old black and white italian movie on it. Very nice touch.

The service was great. All the servers did somewhat of a ballet throughout the night with plating and clearing and pouring. It was nice. 

But the biggest problem for this place seems to be the communication between the kitchen, the servers and the customers. For starters:

On the menu there is a dish which the menu states:
- Squiqink risotto with scallops and squid. 

What actually came out was squidink risotto with scallops, squid, mussels and some unknown white fish. 

As most of you are aware, I'm allergic to fish. Not thinking that this would have fish on it since the menu listed the other items only, I popped a piece of what I thought was scallop into my mouth. And before you go asking me "You can't tell the difference between fish and scallop?", in this case, no, I couldn't. It is really dark in the restaurant and this fish was a small piece and looked exactly like the scallop that was right next to it. 

Second form of lack of proper communication between the kitchen and the staff:

When our really handsome waiter was telling us about the specials, he mentioned a duck ragu over tagliatelle. SOLD! I ordered that, while Eugy got the rack of lamb. 

What came out however was halibut over fettuccine. 

Apparently, the chef didn't erase everything from the day before special and then wrote today's specials and it got mixed up. 

Overall, just a bad dining experience for me, mostly because I was sick for the rest of the night and all of the next day, due to a poor communication error. 

NOTE TO RESTAURANT: It would be a good idea to list the things that actually come with the dish that is listed on the menu. You don't have to write every single item with sauce and such. But if you are going to list 2 meats served, why not just list all 3?
author: Jen D.

description:
The only con about this restaurant is the price...It's pretty damn expensive, but some of the best italian I've had in SF...

Came here with 3 others and 2 of us started with the spicy chickpea soup! DELICIOUS! I couldn't get enough.  It was the *perfect* temperature and had the perfect amount of spice.  It looked real fancy too with the olive oil on top in a fancy little design.

Two ordered the spaghetti with shrimp and zucchini, which came with a nice white wine sauce.

I had the fusili pasta that came with spare ribs and a red sauce. Uhmm, amazing! It was definitely the table favorite. The pasta wasn't really fusili. The noodles were long and skinny and had the consistency of gnocchi. The spare ribs were a bit fatty, but still delicious. 

The only male at the table had the special, which was lamb chops.  They were pretty good, but could've used some salt in my opinion.  

The servers were super awesome and overly friendly! We learned about Rome and how's it not kosher to ask for cheese with a pasta/fish combo.  One of the waiters used to work (he told me he was the owner) at Steps of Rome (pretty sure he licked some tiramisu off my neck there for my b'day a couple years ago). Hahaha

All in all, this place is great, but not really in my budget and a bit too expensive for how much you get.
author: Jenny W.

description: Everything about our experience here was excellent.  5 stars all the way around.  First off the place itself is situated in a renovated victorian style house.  We walked up some stairs to the front door and were immediately greeted by a happy host.  We were quickly seated at a beautiful spot by the window.  We ordered their special drink of the night which was one of the most delightful cocktails I've had in a while.  The appetizer and main courses were delicious.  I ordered the Filet Mignon and it was cooked to perfection.  After enjoying a great meal and experience, the owner of the restaurant opened the door for us, thanked us for coming to his restaurant, and said goodbye.  Highly recommend this place.  Definitely coming back.
author: Ash S.

description:
4/25/08 UPDATE: Had my 2nd dining experience here the other night, and once again, it was a delightfully exquisite evening, all around! :) 

---------

Wandered in here last night for supper, having heard that it had just opened up a couple blocks from me and wanted to check it out... 

Boy, am I glad I did! This place SURPASSED my expectations by far - and in many ways: 

FOOD:  It was unbelievably fresh and tasty. We started with the seafood salad which was very good. He had the black squid ink risotto special, and I had the papardelle pasta with duck special; both were flawless. 

DESSERT:  We shared the cannoli for dessert because I had spotted a few of them being served, and they looked truly authentic; kinda reminded me of my days in Boston, where I'd CRAVE the mafiosa-made cannolis from the North End... Mmmmm! Apparently a guy from Sicily makes them fresh and delivers them every morning to Poesia... Yum! It was also a nice touch that the owner brought us 2 after-dinner, chamomile-infused liqueurs, to accompany our dessert. 

OUR WINE:  The california russian river pinot noir (under $40) was amazingly good and our waiter didn't balk (even for a moment) at the fact that we didn't order italian. Absolutely no attitude there. Love it. 

SERVICE:  I wonder if they perhaps read Phil H's review, complaining that the water and bread were never refilled, because I noticed that both our bread basket and water glasses were replenished *regularly* throughout the meal. So we were able to stay hydrated while drinking some fabulous vino. 

OWNER/CHEF/SERVERS:  I think we met every single one of them over the course of the evening! All were friendly, fun, professional, and genuinely cared to hear how we were enjoying our experience and food. And yet they left us alone at the right time, allowing us to linger a long time after the meal, not rushing us with a check until we asked for it.  They just left us to enjoy 'til we were ready to go. 

I'm PSYCHED this place has opened up, and even moreso that they've opened up just a couple blocks from where I live! Whohoooo! 

See you again soon, Poesia! : )
author: beth l.

description:
For some reason, this spot keeps being a hard location to make happen. I do think the current management has a great concept. Just got back from a nice dinner there. It is a true taste of southern Italian cousin. And it's authentic - they guys are from the south of Italy and learned how to make great food from their mommas. 

Neighborhood is Castro. Ambiance is romantic and warm. Food is simple. Ingredients are first class and very high quality. I had a squid salad for my first followed by gnocchi with spicy tomato sauce for the main dish and a 600-calorie chocolate mousse  for desert. The waiter paired our wine very well, I think.
author: Marko G.

description: The best homemade pasta that I've had in SF, although I haven't been to Flour+Water yet somehow.
author: Sam E.

description: This restaurant is located in a cute house. It has a great view of the street for people watching and lovely large windows. We went on a nice warm night and it was delightful. The filet mignon is to die for, I would definitely recommend it. Great ambiance, loved every bit of it!
author: Kelly T.

description:
Only two stars. We wanted to like this place, but after meeting up with another couple for dinner we couldn't justify the price of about $360 - which is equivalent to what we spent a few weeks before at Spruce (where the meal and service were superb!).

Unfortunately at Poesia, we knew we were in for trouble when we sat down for our 8pm reservation and noticed that while all the tables were full, no one else was eating either.

So we twisted our waiter's arm to get us some cocktails and waited. And waited. And waited. Once the cocktails arrived, we waited for bread. We ordered and while the food was fine, it wasn't a lot of food.

The restaurant was noisy - and I really found the projected Italian movie on the wall a bit much. Sure, you can steal ideas from Foreign Cinema, but at least there they have the space for it. Here it became a big distraction on the wall.

After the appetizers, entrees and two bottles of wine, we just wanted out. We asked for the check and were provided with a complimentary dessert for the table. Nice, but um, can we have the check?

They are trying hard, but after the fact. It's not that it was a hideous experience, but considering the experience we had just had at Spruce, for the same price point - it just didn't cut it.

We wish them luck, but won't be back anytime soon.
author: Bill E.

description:
Perfecto!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
I live nearby and have eaten at the restaurant that previously occupied this space, blah! What a change!
Poesia was perfect! Wonderful service, we had an interaction with every single waiter and there was no snobbery. They were projecting a Fellini movie on the wall with no sound to enjoy while we ate.

The food was spectacular,we had Orrechiete and the Maiale pork tenderloin. Every ingredient every vegetable was perfectly cooked, sauce was excellent. For desert Berry Tart, I could've eaten 4 of them!

I work at an Italian Specialty store and this was some of the best Italian I've had in the city, my Italian co-worker loves this place.
author: Kelly N.

description: This restaurant is so nice inside the staff is so nice and attentive we we're introduce to the chef who cooked our food and they went out of their way to be friendly. Food is really good too
author: Allan A.

description:
I went here twice in the last week. The first time, I was amazed and incredibly impressed with the food. The second time wasn't as great.

On the first visit, We split the kale salad and grilled calamari. Both were outstanding. The pasta courses we ordered were perfect: home made pasta, fresh ingredients, tasty and perfect portion size.

On the next visit, we ordered the same appetizers and they were again outstanding.  However both of our pasta dishes were over-salted. One was so bad that we had to send it back. They brought a replacement that was still too salty, though not as much as the first. 

Other than this bit of inconsistency, I think this is a great place. Service was amazing and decor is cute and funky.
author: Michael T.

description: Very nice place.  A former house remodeled into a restaurant.  Attentive staff, very clean restaurant, food was delicious(had the pasta, made fresh!).  Parking can be a little tough, depending when you go.  Definitely will be coming again.
author: D.C. F.

description:
Grazie mille, Franceso!  Franceso graciously accomodated our group of 22 (!) on a Saturday night with about 45min notice.  The place I booked one month ago for my going away party closed due to sewage problems...for that night only.  Lucky me...

The waiters didn't blink when we kept adding more to the table, one latecoming diner at a time.  

The food was outstanding!  The grilled squid salad was perfectly grilled, coated with lemon juice and served atop arugula.  The sea-bass standout, served deboned (with head and tail, though artfully removed by Matia and other trusty waiters) was so fresh you could practically have gone swimming with the little guy that morning.  

It's pricey, no doubt, but these guys know how to create a great dining experience for a group that still feels intimate, attentive, and oh-so Italian.
author: Anita K.

description:
Finally, a good meal in the Castro!  It's such a shame how much mediocre food there is in the Castro district in general... I would think that the neighborhood would be perfect for refined dining, but it has been disappointing to dine there in the past.  Now that Poesia is open that problem is solidly solved!  

First of all, the space is lovely- on the second floor, it looks like a converted flat.  The staff, including owner, were so plea sent and genuine we felt like we were already regulars.  I even stuck my head in the kitchen at the end of the meal and was rewarded by big smiles from all the line cooks.  Everyone seems really happy to be there, which always makes a meal more pleasurable.  

The zucchini carpaccio w/ truffles was delightful- I never thought I would enjoy a vegetarian appetizer so much.  The pastas are all house-made and taste it, and the portions are small enough that you can also have an entree.  However, you simply must have dessert- as a bratty ex-pastry chef, I can be very critical on deserts.  The Tiramisu and (get this) chocolate mousse w/ olive oil and sea salt were among the most "honest" desserts I've had- I'm so sick of gorgeous desserts that taste like cardboard.  These were divine.

Wines were also lovely- we had a Brunello for $90, among the most expensive on the list, but worth it.  Someone earlier wrote that they ordered the "Iron Horse champagne for $27 and were charged $70"... if there is a place out there you can get Iron Horse for under $60 I'd love to hear about it.  I think that must have been a misunderstanding of some sort!

Only open a month (as of yesterday) so some slight inconsistencies barely warrant a mention.  We ate too much, but that's not their fault!  We'll definitely be back in the near future, skipping all the action on Castro and heading straight upstairs-

Only deducting one star for being quite expensive in the long run... not their fault that we ordered a lot of food and wine, but it still remains true that it averaged $80/ person that night... and with wines only around $45 or so a bottle that seems high.  Still, yummy.
author: Jennifer P.

description:
I had not even noticed this new place had opened in the second floor spot that had felled several other restaurants in recent years.   I walked by and decided to give it a try.   

I hope this place stays for a long time!

Our meal was fantastic.  The fennel salad was light and refreshing.  My crimini mushroom gnocchi melted in my mouth with just the right amount of earthy flavor.  The staff was friendly, food-smart, and of course gorgeous in that Italian smoldering kind of way.  

They were showing the film "La Dolce Vita" projected onto the wall by our table.  We were so inspired we went home and watched "Under the Tuscan Sun" after dinner.  

I doubt you will be able to just walk right in once the word gets out on this place.    BRAVO!!!
author: John A.

description: I took my friends here for a surprise dinner.  They took our coats and sat us in the bar while they got our table ready, it's nice to not just stand around.   It was superb from service to the appetizers, wine and dishes.  The server and the owner was very attentive.  We would go back to this place again.
author: Lauren C.

description:
Prerequisites regarding this review:

1. Southern Italia. thru and thru.
2. My family hails from Maratea (Scalea) and are quite proud of it.
3. I have an obsession with all things Italiana, la bella figura, e uomini de Italia.

Okay. So I wish to be more eloquent in my review being the name of the restaurant is "Poetry" but I will just say that it is amazing. Absolutely amazing. Service, Bartender, Food and Atmosphere.

There are days I long to be back in Italia, where I can enjoy great wine, lengthy conversation and a sophistication that America lacks. When this overwhelming feeling comes over I head straight to Poesia.

I really enjoy this style of eating. Order a couple things and share amongst the group. You will get to try everything and be impressed. Portions are not overwhelming so you aren't going to shovel in food, but you will not leave even close to hungry. Order like an Italiano. Appetizer, pasta, entree, then "digestivo" such as grappa or porto.

Although you may spend a little more than usual (really I don't think it is bad at all) it is an excellent, leasurly meal in the Castro.
author: LJ S.

description:
Amazing! It's more than you could ask for. Perfect menu, cozy little atmosphere, fun servers, and completely authentic. We went with 15 people for a nice week-day birthday dinner. We had half the restaurant to ourselves and the most wonderful Italian dinner we could have asked for. With a small menu and large group, we were able try almost everything on the menu. Dishes were unique, wonderfully displayed, and extremely tasty yet simple. I will be coming back very soon. 

My reco: Try the whole fish, gnocchi pasta, and the cannoli for dessert.
author: Josephine L.

description: Giuseppi always amazes me with new twists on the menu.  Right now there a seafood ravioli that is just delicious! Start with a martini from Alex and the zucchini blossoms.  Go from there to the ravioli and a nice bichieri di vino bianco.  So good.
author: Rob C.

description:
Real Italian, real gays, really good.

The importance of knowing what you're getting into when you want authentic food, is like getting authentic clothes; it's all about the quality.

Authentic Italian food from Poesia is not going to come as aesthetically perfect as say, Ducca or the "infused" Italian eateries, but the labor and quality of the individual pieces of the meal are above and beyond what they charge per dish.

The menu in the glass case outside is misleading; the menu changes weekly, with the master chef pulling family recipes from various regions of Italy. I'm waiting to go back for Northern Italian recipes, since my family used to summer in Laggo Maggiore and Locarno every year (helps if you're European).

The wait staff is amazing; probably the best no-frills servers/hosts I've seen in a while. It was moderately empty when I went with a date (of the many; I'm amazed people still date as it is) on a Thursday evening without a reservation.

On the back wall leading to the kitchen, they project black/white films, so if mastication grosses you out, you can zone out to a silent film.

The dessert menu is by the best thing here. It's Europa at it's best; especially the canoli.

I'd recommend this place if you're able to walk up a flight of stairs; the location leaves something to be desired, especially if you're handicapped or wasted from Moby Dick's/Midnight Sun across the street.

I couldn't think of two more contrasting places...a Castro bar staple and a genuinely great gem of a restaurant, facing off.

UPDATE: I originally gave P. a 4-Stars rating...however, went there again last night (5/12) and the eggplant parmigianna was the best f-ing thing I've had in my mouth in months. IN-SAN-I-TY.
author: C. P.

description: Used a living social deal here and had a great time! The owner was really sweet to us as well. The food was excellent, but we actually ended up spending $50 on top of our deal because we ordered extra wine and coffee. I ordered the crab ravioli which was amazing, the bf ordered the sea bass, which was just ok. Overall the owner definitely made the dinning experience more enjoyable
author: Jessica C.

description:
I drooled whilst writing my first review of this Castro gem so I'm not really sure how to go about waxing gastronomic over my second.

Robertino! Sono pazza per te!

Just when I thought it couldn't get any better they bring in house-made infused liquors.  Ask for the Chamomile or licorice...and then ask for the chamomile again.  

The new tiramisu is awesome!...infused with oranges and un-typically round and on a pedestal which somehow seems that much more Italian... or maybe that's just a wishful self reference.

I love this place even when I'm going through some of my more dietary restrictive moments..(raw vegan for example) and I will tromp my ultra lazy a$$ all the way over to the Castro to indulge in a sinful zucchini carpaccio with truffle oil....mmmmm
author: Genevra P.

description:
On the pricey side but we had no complaints about anything, from the quaint warm atmosphere, to the charming attentive service, to the flavorful fulfilling food it was all molto bene.

I have no reservations about making reservations again sometime.
author: GIR ..

description: This place is yumsters. Still get hard over the Beet Ravioli. The ambience is super Kawaii too!
author: Sancho P.

description:
Excellent food, kind of a small/noisy atmosphere on a Friday night, staff was awkward and a little forgetful, which never made me feel totally comfortable. Constantly having my water glass refilled after taking two sips. The food was worth it, though.

I had the cauliflower orichette and tasted the eggplant parm; both perfect. Waiter recommended a wine, and it was excellent. The bread was fresh and olive oil had subtle flavor. I tried the choc mousse with salt, oil, etc. and it came with two pea size scoops. If you're going to order this, do it at Bi-Rite and not here; the other desserts are all much better (I tried most of them from friends).

A silent movie was projected on the wall and I felt like I was eating in someone's dining room (which I may have been).

I might go back, for the food, not the ambiance or service.
author: Karl N.

description:
Recently had a great time at Poesia!

...steep staircase to the entrance...dining room is warm and inviting...complete with a sophia loren flick projected onto one of the walls...careful and competent service...clean in all respects...cocktails mixed to perfection...ok wine selection...the food is for foodies!

...enthusiastic owner/manager Francesco d'Ippolito stopped by our table and shared fun stories about italy...this is a place that cares passionately about its food!
author: Matthew L.

description:
I simply loved this cute place.  Fun location, but hard parking.  You can take the muni and it'sonly a block away.  Luigi, the ponytail, Italian waiter was just adorable!  

Appetizers:
Sardines - good and tasty
Carpaccio - very yummy

Main Dishes:
Pork ribs pasta with tomato sauce - superb
Rack of Lamb - I don't eat lamb, but my friend said it was delish

The service was excellent.  The lighting was warm and cozy.  I would go back again.
author: Annie S.

description:
Everything about our meal was disappointing except the bread which was great. Although friendly, the waiter made several mistakes on the wine choices and brought the wrong wine-and forgot to put some of our order in. The portions were small and the food was not very good. 
The decor is great and staff friendly...but I went there primarily for good food which we did not get. All 5 in my party were disappointed.
author: mark m.

description: saw this place on Check Please.  Very disappointed.  Pasta was bland and nothing special.  Others have talked about how friendly the owner was.  What a joke.  He was so occupied with selected customers, but completely ignored others.  Don't need this place.  There are much better places than this one
author: Van C.

description:
Hm, this one is tough for me to review.  The staff here was super and the setting and location was very comfortable and relaxing.  Not too crowded, and warm and cozy inside.  The food was pretty good, but it's probably me more than anything else, but I just wasn't blown away really.  It wasn't bad at all, but for the price, I expected something more memorable.  I don't eat Italian that much but was there with excellent company and enjoyed three bottles of wine throughout our meal.

The dessert was quite tasty though and may have been my favorite part of the meal.
author: Gene X.

description:
Went last night with two friends. Another friend who has worked in the Castro for years and knows Italian food said something like, "finally there's a really good restaurant in the neighborhood," so I'd been very curious to try it.

It was around 9 on a Friday night, so the place was full, but we sat at the (empty) bar, drank Prosecco, and had a table within 15 minutes. We lucked out and got the three-top in the front window, definitely the nicest table in the place.

The arancini were really good: crunchy exterior, gamy lamb ragù filling, and a nice tomato sauce on the side. I expected more fish in the baccalà dish but it was more like scalloped potatoes flavored with salt cod--tasty though we wouldn't have ordered it if the description had been clearer.

Pastas were all good. I had strozzapretti with nduja and sardines, really flavorful and spicy. Big fat tortelloni were also great.

I'm forgetting one appetizer and one pasta but everything was good. We drank a nice bottle of Prosecco and a new-to-me Lamezia Riserva. We were too full to order dessert. Came to $75 a head with tax and tip.

I wouldn't necessarily go out of my way to eat there, but I'd definitely go back if I were in the Castro.
author: Robert L.

description:
Amazing. Absolutely amazing.  Yelp does it again.

We loved this place for many reasons.

* The location was great.  The gay neighborhoods are always the nicest and classiest in whatever city it's in.  
* The atmosphere of the restaurant itself was more of an intimate large dinner party of sorts.  Very welcoming.
* The service was second-to-none. Very friendly and attentive.  They sat us at the bar as we waited for our table.  They gave us a generous sample of a couple different wines because we couldn't decide on what we wanted.
* The food was amazing, but almost positioned itself as a second seat to the ambiance, atmosphere, and service.  Honestly, the food could've been mediocre and we still would've had a great time.
* The price was reasonable given the vibe.  Two people with wine and an entre was about $65 after tip.

Seriously. Awesome place. I mean the owner of the restaurant handed us our bill personally.  That's awesome.
author: Danny P.

description:
This is my second review and I am sure there will be many more to follow as this place is just terrific.  This time I went with a friend. I called a few days earlier and was able to get a reservation for two at 7:45 on a Friday night. When we got there, Franceso greeted us warmly and escorted us to la prima tavola right in front at the windows overlooking 18th. St. It was great since it was so warm that night and the windows were open. We started with a bottle of prosecco and split a fennel salad. I had the special Venetian-inspired scallops' dish in a sepia risotto.  My friend had the orrechiate which she really enjoyed. She also remarked that the bread was really good which I think is an indicator of a restaurant. If there's great bread, great food usually follows. She also liked the dipping olive oil.

It's interesting that they-along with just about every Italian restaurant I've been to in America-serve olive oil with the bread because I have never seen that in Italy. The service was incredible. My friend said afterward she couldn't figure out who our waiter was because there were four people taking care of us. My friend didn't care for the zabaglione so after dinner we went to Swenson's for sundaes.

The place was packed and very lively. I was able to practice my Italian with everyone - which I really enjoyed. The clientele was very mixed with straights and Castro St. area locals whom I have now dubbed i Castrotti.

Prosecco, one salad, two entrees, dessert and  tax : $85.00.

********************
First visit: This was my first time. I totally loved it here. When I walked in, the owner recognized me from playing accordion in North Beach.  I sat at the bar so I could do my italian homework and I was able to talk to everyone in Italian which was fun. There were a couple also at the bar and they were talking in Italian.

The waiter screwed up my order and brought me the wrong thing, but what I had was great and I am so brain dead I didn't even realize it was the wrong dish. The owner bought me a glass of wine for them screwing up the order once I realized it was the wrong thing.

The entree was not a lot of food so I ended up getting the fennel salad afterward. Both the entree and sald were fabulous. The food is more upscale and gourmet-like than what I usually see at italian restaurants. But, the place is not stuffy and the prices were moderate. My fish was $22.00, the salad was $7.00 and a glass of wine was $7.00.
author: tom t.

description:
the food was hands down the best Italian I have ever had. The wait staff are all the cutest boys, all italian, and incredibly caring. A small space, with a small menu, but something for every one. 

Great date place, or a good night out with the friends. 

Oh and fabulous wine menu!
author: Delilah S.

description: A long wait, of 30 minutes, even with a booking but the food was awesome and the place is to be seen. You MUST go.
author: Rod M.

description:
I'm really surprised to see the negatives here, I've been there lots of times, even with the Living Social coupon and have always enjoyed the food and service. 
It's got a good ambiance and sound level too. I'm looking forward to going back.
author: Johnny M.

description:
The only way I can justify dinner is having used my groupon. But even then I feel bitterly disappointed.
Called a week ahead and told them I have celiac disease and was reassured they understood what gluten was and would make sure I was taken care of. Well...they didn't.
We were 15 minutes late for our reservation, but even then we waited for almost half an hour in the bar for our table to be ready.
Drinks were okay, but nothing special. At $9 and $10 for the cosmo specials, I wasn't impressed.
I can't comment on the bread, but my dining partners fell in love with the fried dough bits (3stars) that were in the basket. The others they used to sop up the juices from their (and my) plates.
Dinner - I had the beet salad to start and the salted cod for my main. The beet salad (3star) was nice, and plated very well. The salted cod I'm pretty sure had gluten and even if it didn't, it was barely palatable. It was so overcooked! (1star, obviously)
Dining partner #1 and #2 ordered the eggplant souffle to start and enjoyed it. Given what else they ordered, it was enough to share (4 stars). They split two pasta dishes (the gnocci and the braised ribs) and the gnocci (1star) came barely lukewarm even though it was supposed to be "oven baked" and the rib dish (3star) was nice enough, and they might order it again, but ask for extra meat.
The dessert was a mess. They were out of one, which of course would have been the gluten free option (other than the obvious gelato, but what celiac is going to order that when a restaurant actually has *real* options?) So the dessert came, and it wasn't presented as advertised and dining partner #2 had to call the manager over to ask what the heck it was. Lucky for us, DP #2 speaks fluent Italian so he was able to communicate but we would have been SOL if he wasn't there to help us.

Bottom line: I wouldn't go back. Dining partner #1 wouldn't either. DP #2 might. It was a lot to pay even with the groupon, but without it I would have been pissed.

*Not recommended
author: Carla S.

description:
I loved this restaurant.  The interior is really cute (and I liked the black and white movie projected on the wall). Service was flawless. Food was great. Prices were really reasonable. It gets a bit loud since it's a small place and packed, but I can't blame them for that.
The only bummer was that my husband's chicken was very undercooked... so overall review went down to 4 stars. After sending it back, the chef came out to our table to personally apologize and they took it off the bill. Back to 5 stars.
author: nicole c.

description:
I live in the neighborhood, and finally stopped here for dinner on a whim, having read other Yelpers' reviews.  I loved every bit of it.

The service was spectacular--attentive without being overbearing.  When I had questions about two Italian wines, my server not only offered to let me taste each, but poured me two half-glasses--the lighter-bodied red (a sangiovese) to go with my appetizer and the heartier (primitivo) to accompany the tagliatelli with lamb ragu that was my entree.  Both were perfect pairings.  Dessert was a tiramisu flavored with Grand Marnier, which I paired with a lovely, light moscato.  

True, it wasn't cheap, but I think that the prices are completely in line with the ambience, the quality of the food, and the service.  I am delighted to have this gem in my neighborhood, and I can't wait to introduce my friends to it.
author: Earline A.

description:
This is my favorite place to eat in the Castro district in San Francisco. The food here is amazing and always incredibly consistent. The menu is seasonal and changes from week to week depending on what the owner can find. The specials are amazing and the bar tender makes excellent cocktails.

My Fiancé absolutely loves the lemon gnocchi which is fantastic and we both enjoy their squid Ink pasta. The service is very attentive and the owner is always at the restaurant and you can tell he really cares about the food and his customers. 

The ingredients always taste fresh and the restaurant is decorated to give the feeling like it's someone fancy Italian home. It has a very romantic feel to it and they play old black and white Italian movies on a projector which gives the place a very authentic vibe.

I can't think of a restaurant that I miss more since moving away from my beloved San Francisco. I often times catch myself day dreaming about the dinners I had with my wife at this magical establishment.
author: Tom M.

description:
Loved it!
Loved it!
Loved it!

Very happy to have made it in the first week of operation, it felt like home and I didn't want to leave.

Lovely Baccalau, Ragu and fusilli, and wonderful treatment of fish - with scallion's prepared is such an unusual and yummy fashion it made eating them tons of fun.

The owner and staff made the experience and leaves me craving to go back. If I wasn't so exhausted from the weekend I would have stayed for more drinks at the bar.

I've told at least 10 people about it today, the day after. I wish them well and hope to be there again soon.

Ciao, dh
author: David H.

description:
Went here for a group dinner last night, and I thought the restaurant was quite charming.  I loved the Victorian architecture and romantic low-lighting.  It would be a perfect date place or perfect for any special occasion-- actually the couple sitting to the right of us were celebrating their anniversary the night we went.  However, I wouldn't come here if you're in any kind of a rush...this is true European style dining, where the waiter requests that you ask for the check, when you're ready to leave.

I was a bit indifferent about the fried artichoke cake appetizer (I've decided that I prefer my artichokes whole, instead of pureed), but I thought the pork ribs and tomato pasta dish was orgasmically good.  The filleted pork, was tender and juicy, the tomato sauce was bubbling with flavor, and the pasta was freshly made.  Even though I was full at the end of my meal, I really could have ordered another pork entree, just to be a glutton.  

The dishes were beautifully presented,  the cocktails were quite inventive, and I think almost everyone enjoyed their main dishes, but there seemed to be an issue with portion equity.  My friend's roasted chicken dish with potatoes and vegetables was huge!  My pasta dish was medium sized yet  filling, but my friend's chestnut ravioli came with about 7-8 pieces and no side garnishment or vegetables.  I was hungry for her, at the end of the meal.  :~(
author: LaSha G.

description: We often hear of the great cuisine in San Francisco neighborhoods, and we found it at Poesia.  Poesia brings Italian regional cooking to the Castro, with dishes from the Calabria region of southern Italy. We tried several dishes, and all were outstanding.  It is clear that this restaurant pays close attention to fresh ingredients, including vegetables and seafood. Two of the dishes that really stood out for us were the pyramid-shaped cheese ravioli with a dynamite pesto sauce (with hints of dill and perhaps mint, in addition to the usual basil), and the fresh Mediterranean sea bass (Branzino). The Italian varietal wines were solid (we had help with the pairing), the servers very attentive, and the prices reasonable. An exceptional dining experience.
author: James B.

description: This is Italian service at its best.  After ascending the steep and narrow stairs of this Castro Restaurant, you enter a space that reminds you of what your Italian grandmother's house might have been,  Living room, dining room, and a full bar.  It also is a bit Cinema Paradiso with Italian movies playing on the wall.  The service is superb, from Francesco welcoming handshake at the door, to his frequent visits to the table to see how "we like".  I was enticed to this restaurant because of it gluten free options, which is unique of a pasta house.  The gluten free pasta was delicious with a roast pork gravy.  (Gravy is what Italians call sauce).  Although I could not eat the Tomato soup because it is made with Dairy, it is highly recommended for those who can eat dairy.  The branzino was good, just slightly under-seasoned.  This is a neighborhood gem, and a rarity for the Castro to have a good restaurant.  Go here when you want some Italian love that your grandmother can only give.
author: Michael G.

description:
If you can get past the pricey menu just once, you'll see what everyone is talking about. Each dish is impressive all by itself (don't call it "Italian Food" unless you've been there; this isn't the Sausage Factory), but is even more of a standout in the Castro. It's about on par with Range in my opinion if you substitute the dutiful service for a homey, warm living room-type atmosphere where they expect you to hang out (this isn't a place that rushes to bring you the bill so they can turn over your table, but they do breeze by to ensure you're making yummy noises).

Still, Poesia scores higher in my book because everything is so full of care. It's not one of those snooty Michelin machines that churns out technical excellence. You can totally taste the love.

My only criticism of Poesia is probably something it prides itself on: everything about the place is completely understated. Beige signage and stairs leading up make it tough to find, so even Castro residents are all "What's Poesia?" (About half the diners are clearly not of Castro origin.) I also know that the restaurant has had some stellar write-ups, but none of them are hanging on the wall. That's not an accident either. My aunt had honey with her tea and freaked out. "Taste this honey!" she said. "It tastes like fresh flowers; I've never had honey like this in my life." Sure enough, we found out they get it direct from Italy. How special is that?!

In short, go to Poesia, but don't tell your friends. Oh, and make sure to get the spicy chocolate "shots" ("Cioccopic") if you don't get dessert. You won't regret it.
author: Gabe E.

description:
The ONLY reason I am willing to write this review is that we live in San Jose, and our trips to San Francisco tend to be planned rather than impromptu, so we should be able to get a reservation even if Poesia gets popular. If I lived in the city, I'd keep this gem to myself.  ;-)

We went early-ish (6pm) on Friday night before going around the corner to see the restored "Metropolis". Others have mentioned the decor, the 1950s/1960s Italian movies sans sound (that night it was "Nights of Cabiria (1957)").

We each had a glass of wine while looking at the thankfully-limited menu; we had enough trouble deciding what to have as it was. And there were 3 off-menu specials as well.

We began with grilled sardines (well executed, yummy) and gnocchi in a citrus sauce (deliciously unusual; I almost canceled my entree and got 2 more orders).

For entrees I had the fileji di renato that has been mentioned in other reviews, and if anything it was better than even my high expectations. But the star was the nightly special branzino that my wife ordered. One of the best fish I have ever tasted, and I grew up near New Orleans with my friends' French grandmothers cooking for me. My wife at everything but the bones and the eyes -- smart girl.

We washed all this down with a bottle of '04 Antano Sagrantino di Montefalco. Again, yum.

We finished with double espressos and gelato, including a chocolate one with olive oil and other goodies. The latter nearly got my hand cut off by my wife when I dared to try for a second taste of it from her plate.

Throughout our server, whose name I unfortunately never got, was friendly, courteous, efficient, and all those other good things. He made us feel at home the moment we sat down, and took great care of us.

If you're coming into the city on BART, exit at 16th Street Mission station, grab the 33 bus right there on Mission, and it'll take you right to Poesia. I hope you enjoy it as much as we did.
author: Curtis J.

description:
It all started when Luigi sucked his breath in through his teeth when we told him we didn't have a reservation, and then, with a wink, graciously gave us our choice of lovely tables in the dining room.  This joke became a warm welcome to a wonderful meal at Poesia.

We weren't rushed at all.  Service was completely unobtrusive, and recommendations were great.  The menu is smallish - 4 antipasti, 4 salads, 4 pastas, 4 entrees, but there are daily specials as well.  The wine list is wonderful with a lovely pinot grigio, and the best part - not a chardonnay in sight!

The filet is TOO DIE FOR, the eggplant parmagiana is divine, and the zucchini carpaccio and insalata verde (with the gorgonzola dressing) are very nice.

While I miss Ararat (Poesia's predecessor), I'm glad Poesia is here.  Because it's here to stay!
author: Evan G.

description:
Quite possibly the best Italian Restaurant in the city and trust me I know! I have been dining in SF for over 14 years now. I am Italian, a foodie, and a recreational chef in my own right. 

Francesco; the owner and Roberto; the Executive chef take pride in all the ingredients that go into every distinct dish. In my last experience; even though the place was quite busy, the waiter was there at the right time, suggesting his favorite dishes and pouring wine when we were ready. My girlfriend is still raving about these Sicilian tomatoes called "Pacchino" I think, that were in the special calamari dish. The Lamb Chops are tender and huge! 

Although the desserts are all unique and good you need to try the Chocolate Mousse.. Mamma Mia! and I say that with encouragement. Try two scoops of dark rich Chocolate Mousse over a bed of Mascarpone and  Peperoncino, drizzled with olive oil and topped off with Rock salt. Incredible combination of flavors!

Bravissimi Ragazzi!
author: Tiziano S.

description:
From the food to the service to the drinks, this was one of the best overall dining experiences we've had in San Francisco comparatively speaking.

North Beach does not have a place like this.  We have had the pleasure to dine at many Italian restaurants in San Francisco and this ranks as one of the top.

The bar is great, awesome cocktails :)  Menu prices are very reasonable given the quality of the food.  We will definitely be back!
author: Jennifer N.

description:
Wow, who woulda thought fine dining would actually have made it to the Castro? 

Sure there are fancy places here, but most suffer in one major area: service. Poesia is a welcome addition to the neighborhood because it combines those rare attributes of both excellent food and equally excellent service. We had ALL sorts of weird substitutions and adjustments to our order due to my husband having some pretty specific food allergies. Almost anywhere we go, it seems to be the litmus test when we order to see if the server will either begrudgingly accommodate us or their head explodes.

We had no attitude and delicious food substitutions, all my husband's food was perfect. Luigi, our server was kind and extremely helpful. As we were there for our 10 year anniversary, it really felt quite special. 

Ambiance points for the Italian movie playing on a whole wall and the Baccarat-like crystal chandeliers - so, so very classy considering you can look out your window as you dine and watch drunk queens throwing up on the sidewalk as they stagger out of The Mix and Moby Dick.

Definitely a good addition to the Castro. They set the bar high (as it should be) for dining in the neighborhood. I'll be back!
author: Nick R.

description: Saw this restaurant on KQED's show 'Check Please' and was really excited to go. We were greeted immediately and were seated. Though our waiter was very nice the service was very slow. We ordered a medium priced wine and could not even finish the bottle.  The kale salad we ordered was awful. Our meals were decent. This place was disappointing. There are so many great Italian restaurants in San Francisco, I would not say this was one of them.
author: Cole K.

description: This place is amazing. Very small, so expect a bit of a wait on the weekends(even with a reservation) but 100% worth the wait! I used to get the filet there, and they changed what kind of sauce they use a few months back, but was informed that in the future I can always request it to be done the old way. Thats quality service. I've had Jesus as a waiter there a few times and he is the nicest, most competent waiter I've had in the city. Love this restaurant!
author: Michaelyn S.

description: Delicious squid ink ravioli but that's the best part.  The burrata and gnocci appetizer  were above average, and the lamb fettucine was a ok.  Cute little restaurant with the charm of Italian movie playing in the background.  Unfortunately, not enough to have me back another time.
author: Tiffany H.

description:
Ok, so we came  on a Saturday night, without a reservation.  We are provincial Bernal dwellers who dont know any better.  Despite our audacity, we were promptly seated at the bar where (dammit, its better anyway) we got more than adequate service (read: super attentive and "on it") along with some stellar food.
MY GF got the Bass which (not being seafood afficionadas) won us over and I got the gnocchi which was better than average, though not stellar.
The beet salad was a must.
The Canollo(i) was formidable and intimidating to be sure.  It almost lived up to its reputation ("better than Delfina's) though only a fraction of a fraction apart.
The place was packed, the bar service stellar and the limoncello an after-dinner must.
At last, a respite of dining in the slums of the Castro.
author: Jen L.

description:
Good old Yelp pulling through again with another great recommendation. We had a bunch of family friends coming into the city to see a friends' film  that was screening at the Castro Theatre, and they looked to me to find us a place to eat. Turned out it was a hit!

This is easily some of the best Italian food I've had. With a large group, we pretty much got to order most of their menu, and nothing disappointed. The wine list is impressive and the prices are pretty reasonable for the quality of the food and ambiance.

Bottom line, it pleased a group of 20 somethings and our parents without a doubt, and we were just around the corner from the theater.  Everyone was so impressed with my choice of restaurant, I almost didn't want to tell them how easily I found it on Yelp, but when the owner came by to talk to us, I had to be honest.
author: Chris P.

description: Yummy food and a really cute place. The staff were nice but when it came to surprising the birthday couple with dessert, three different people came to ask us what we wanted : / otherwise a great experience. It was packed but we never felt rushed. Plus reservations were easy to make!
author: C L.

description:
if you have not been here yet, you should definitely check it out. Poesia is a brand new restaurant,  boasting delicious dishes from Southern Italy. 

I had the pleasure of trying several different dishes.I certainly cannot tell you what not to try because it was all prepared to perfection, presented as art, and even more delicious than it looked. 

For appetizers the spicy lamb chops was my favorite but the fennel salad with blood oranges created sweet flavors I had yet to experience before.
For mains the hand made gnocchi with fresh gorgonzola sauce and mushrooms literally melts in your mouth. I also tried a couple bites of the chicken with celery and parsley sauce laid on top of a bed of sliced fried potatoes. You may have never heard of such as sauce before, but once you try it, you'll be back for more. For desert, both the orange tirramisu and the chocolate mousse are guaranteed winners.

 It's one thing for a restaurant to have great food, but also very important is the service and the staff. Poesia knows how to execute. The owner is very charming and authentic with each and every customer. The wait staff and bartenders all have a pleasant balance of warming and outgoing personalities that make you feel like you're amongst family. This is certainly the type of place I will return time and time again. I highly suggest stopping by. You'll be glad you did!
author: Heather M.

description:
Fresh authentic Italian. Not the gooey over sauced over cheesed american version. This is regional healthy and they use alot of local fresh produce to make their dishes. Pasta is usually very fresh and made by hand. Innovative dishes that change regularly. 
I gotta say it's a pleasure each and every time. Francesco the owner is attentive and remembers your name if you become a regular quickly. It's a small gem in the Castro neighborhood. Once you go it will become one your favorites. Mine is the gnocchi salani appetizer antipasti, the insalata barbabietola, and the pork tenderloins, or pork ragout. they also make an amzing cannoli for dessert...presto!
author: Johnny G.

description: This is our go-to special dinner place.  It can get a little noisy with large and exuberant parties.  Food is fantastic and service attentive.  Particularly like showing up at 9:00 for a late dinner.
author: Thomas A.

description: Excellent restaurant. My wife and I love the beet ravioli. The muscles are ok but star belly has better.
author: Jeff G.

description:
a quaint italian osteria in the heart of the castro district.  what looked like a classic victorian home is really a high class delight.  Staffed with the nicest and most attentive servers, the food complemented the staff and the fanciness of the location.

I had a whole pan-seared and then backed seabass infused with garlic and other fine herbs.  it was cooked to perfection...HONESTLY.  my partner had the scallops and fettucine that came with a cream sauce where you had to ask for more bread to soak up every last drop.  they gave us complimentary champage and dessert since it served as my birthday dinner....the party of 8 next to us actually sang happy birthday to me.

You will not be disappointed with Poesia!
author: lasok o.

description: The Best Dining in the Castro.  When you are feeling like a different type of Italian  or just good dining in the Castro this place is a must.  Not your ordinary quick sit and go place, get your butt comfortable and prepare your chakras for an experience.  Celebrating something special like sundown?  Have the bartender concoct something seasonal served in a martini glass in drag.  For antipasti-get the swimming fresh sardines or squid on local greens, it's usually on special.   The pork rib ragu is a cant be missed, best  when served with the hand rolled fileji pasta.
author: OneOfTwo F.

description:
scrumptious pasta and wine.  riso amaro - giuseppe de antis.  perfect host.  spontaneity.

the freshest tiramisu.  loved this eveninG.  open until  11:00PM!

 impressive late night (fine?) dining in san francisco.
author: Noel J.

description:
I am going to join the chorus of 5 star reviews after having a nice romantic dinner here for 2 last night. The food was amazing, the service was top notch, warm and personal, with a very comfortable atmosphere. The restaurant is small, but is a versatile spot, so it is a great place for both a date or a large party. 

I still can't get the desserts off my mind. So good!
author: Jonathan H.

description:
Poetry indeed! I am so excited to have an excellent Italian restaurant close by my hood. Just a straight shot down the hill and into Poesia I roll.

The space is adorable. I went on the really hot day (you know, the only one we'll have until October) and it was a little stifling, but luckily heat isn't much of a problem here so the lack of a cross breeze shouldn't have much impact on them. The staff is incredibly friendly and stylish and oh-so-Italiano. They let you taste wines at the bar before you order. Big ups. The wine list, as you might expect, has a wide selection of Italian varietals, some at really decent prices given the "we're imported from a country whose currency regularly beats up your currency" factor.

The food was slightly hit or miss, which is the only reason Poesia does not get 5 stars. My dining companion and I split the fennel and orange salad which was really disappointing. The fennel had no flavor at all. It was just texture. Fennel is SO local - their chef could seriously walk up to my hood and pick wild fennel right off the slopes of Twin Peaks if they wanted to. Flavorless fennel is inexcusable, especially as the main ingredient in a salad. 

The pasta dishes, however, were excellent. I ordered the orichette with cauliflower, which was served perfectly al dente, loaded with cheese and straight from the oven. My companion had the gnocchi, which was absolutely divine. I was tempted to knock him on the head and steal his dinner. It was that good. 

I am really looking forward to my next trip to Poesia. It's a welcome addition to a neighborhood where the food is generally pretty dull. Bravo!
author: Angie R.

description:
Eh.  I dunno what all the fuss is about for this place.  Sure, if you're into over-the-top pretentious (authentic italian? or just pretending? couldn't tell) service, ambiance, and overpriced food, this is THE place.

I had the calamari pasta special, but it had a strong fishy taste - i.e., like it was old calamari.  The pasta was also overcooked - at an Italian place!  My husband had something else equally forgettable.  I think it might have been the ravioli.  Anyway, you would be well-advised to forget that you thought about coming here and check out someplace else - you can do a LOT better for the price.
author: A H.

description: This is a gem in the Castro. A solid Italian restaurant set off from the scene because its just off of Castro on 18th and up a flight if stairs.  Don't let the noise from the bars nearby fool you,  you can take your parents or a date here and have a lovely time. Service was good and helpful and the food was very good , although I kind of wanted a little more of the really tasty homemade pasta with pork sugo!  Really toothsome perfect pasta. Clean flavors  where you can taste the ingredients. Our favorite dish was the brodetto ( a soup) with peas, fava beans and grilled squid. So good!  The fresh grilled sardines were the only disappointment. They weren't bad, but there was a strange soft stuffing in them that detracted from the sardines themselves. I enjoyed my wines too. Italian and between 8-10 per glass. Very reasonable. We didn't have room for dessert but I'll try that next time!
author: Priscilla C.

description:
Loved this place. Finally a nice chill restaurant in the Castro, with good food and friendly staff, without having to put up with what you would typically find in any other restaurant in this neighborhood.

From the beginning to the end of the night, the staff was impeccable and always friendly and happy to help. I love how honest and genuine they all were and always with a smile and a laugh.

The food was great. I'm vegetarian but they had enough options to keep me happy the whole time. Starting with the arborio rice and the fennel antipasti, continuing with the tomato soup and the wonderful gnocci and home made pasta my friend had.

Everything was really tasty and with nice portions. For the people complaining about small portions or lack of spice, I'm not sure what they're used to, but it really reminded me of an actual European restaurant.

The desserts were incredible. The Canolli especially was unreal.

I will definitely be coming here again soon and will tell my friends to go try it as well. We need more places like this in the Castro.
author: Afonso S.

description:
I really don't know what is going on with this place.

I came here because of all these rave Yelp reviews. My best friend flew in from New York to stay in the city and I recommended we ate at this place - I mean it is Castro and all! Made reservations, guy was very nice on the phone and also greeted us with a table ready for the time we reserved. The atmosphere was all artsy, ooooohh.... and it was just crowded. Like a typical hyped up NYC restaurant. Perfect!

Until we got to the food. I don't even know what kind of fish of the day it was but I'm always up for trying something even though I've never heard of it. Turned out it was two very tiny fish in creamed sauce with all their tiny little bones in it. I can understand leaving the bones in for Chinese joints, but that's for Chinese people, they expect it. This is Italian. Besides, Chinese restaurants give you bigger portions with bigger bones for that kind of price, or maybe half that price. Nobody serves small little catch with a million little bones, those are considered cheap, unwanted fish. Especially with thick creamy sauce, that's just unheard of. With all of that you can't even find the bones in your bite and you end up swallowing a bunch and having the worst dinner experience ever in a fancy, hyped up, highly rated Italian restaurant in the middle of Castro.

I did tell my waiter about it and he told me that it's expected to have tiny bones in tiny fish... um.... right. But later on he came back and offered to change my order, which made me a little more satisfied. The second order was okay I ordered a simple pasta dish. 

I must say, the flavor of their dishes do come out uniquely and is above average.

My friend though... whatever special she got that day, it was a shrimp pasta. Well, it made her sick. She only ate a little bit of it and stopped. I tried one shrimp and thought something was off with the taste. 20 minutes after we left the restaurant she puked everything up. And she's said she rarely ever throws up food. She felt so weak after we had to call it an early night and take a taxi back to her hotel. That was the end of her visit with me, the first time I'd seen her in four years, thanks to this meal. 

I'm sure others have had good experiences with this restaurant. But this is my first time, and it ruined my night with my friend, so it's going to be my only time.
author: lilcooptown g.

description:
Great Service . . . Disappointing Food

With fond memories of other restaurants in this space, over the years, we really wanted to like Poesia.  The location is great.  The atmosphere is upscale, warm, inviting and cozy.  The staff is friendly, polite, attentive, authentically Italian and easy-on-the-eyes.   Service was very good. 

Then . . . there is the food.  It was, well . . . SAD.   Not a single dish was right and everything suffered from incredibly poor presentation.

First, the Carpaccio was just a few thick slices of low quality beef wrapped around hunks of salad, hidden under even more weeds and then doused with a forgettable dressing.    We had expected the traditional presentation of thinly sliced meat with a few capers . . . not a big pile of salad.   The Tomato Mozzarella Caprese was just as bad . . . huge hunks of mushy, over ripe tomato - served in a BOWL, of all things - with a few lumps of cheese and a tasteless dressing.  We had to ask for salt and pepper, (which was not on the tables), to make it acceptable.

Main courses were equally disappointing.  The roast chicken had great flavor, but was horribly dry and over cooked, as were the accompanying roast potatoes.  The pricey Rack of Lamb looked pretty but presented very small, fatty ribs with an overly acidic sauce and an odd taste.  Desert?  It was somewhat better, but the cake was also overcooked and dry.

In short, we're glad we tried Poesia but will not come back.  For Italian food at this price range, we'll go just over the hill to Lupa or Ristorante Bacco, in Noe Valley.
author: Sebastian T.

description:
Since were are fans of the Eureka restaurant wanted to try this place across the street. My girl and I made reservations for Saturday at 6. The restaurant was empty couple of people at the bar and 1 or 2 couples dining. We started out with the Antipasti, Antipasto Misto, that was out standing. I ordered the rack of lamb and my girl ordered the corkscrew pasta with braised shredded pork ribs. Let me just say and quote, from the food section in Sundays Chronicle. 

"Lamb--especially rack of lamb--is best when medium rare. A half rack of lamb can weigh from a little less than 1 pound up to 1 3/4 pounds. It almost always has eight bones unless one has accidentally broken off". 

I had the rack of lamb, 2 pieces of lamb each had 2 bones, where is the other half of my lamb? I told my girl that this is not a rack of lamb, a rack has 8 bones. The cut of meat was also trimmed too much. You need fat on meat to give meat flavor, or else you have meat with no flavor. My girl had the corkscrew braised shredded pork ribs, the pasta was NOT corkscrew it was something else very thick and under cooked not al dente, but crunchy raw. Since my lamb was small due to the lack of the other half, my girls pasta was even smaller. 

The service was very good, the drinks were good, the food needs to improve and step up to the plate, especially since they are across from the GREAT EUREKA. This is an Italian restaurant create great Italian food. At that point of the evening we opt to go across the street to... you guessed it,,,The Eureka for dessert and drinks.
author: joy e.

description:
We started w/the antipasto misto and it was disappointing.  I was excited to taste the arancino and it was so disappointing.  Nothing like Italy.  No flavor.  The salume was ok, nothing special.  We had the Fileji di Renato (corkscrew pasta w/pork ribs in tomato sauce) and Burrata con Carciofini Marinati, Pomodori Secchi e Olive di Cerignola.  The burrata cheese was good and the aspargus was not overcooked.  The corkscrew pasta was perfectly cooked.  

Overall, some dishes were good and others were disappointing.  We would come back but isn't our first choice.
author: Eva Y.

description: Excellent pastas and a great corkage fee of $20 (waived if you buy your own bottle). The service is timely but not intrusive. Check this place out if you want a nice Italian flare.
author: Chris F.

description: Very competent Italian food.  Nothing flashy or exciting but well handled and solid.  It was real Italian food rather than the Italian-American stuff.  Reasonably priced wine list too.
author: Steven R.

description:
Summary: Poesia is an incredible alternative to the newer, colder, noisy Italian places down the street.  The environment is comfortable, the food frighteningly fresh and inventively seasoned. The prices are reasonable for the quality.  Lastly, the staff is warm and charming.

Review: Is the new center for Italian cuisine in San Francisco moving southwest?  While the Mission is quickly becoming a breeding ground for the best inventive food in the city 18th Street is drawing amazing Italian food.  It all began with Delfina, their Pizzeria next door then Farina down the street and now Poesia up the street near Castro.

Poesia inhabits a cursed location one floor above 18th street between Castro and Hartford.  There have been no less than 6 restaurants in the space in as many years that have ranged from a burger joint to middle eastern and Japanese themed eateries.  Each time the space felt feng-shuei-challenged. Not this time!  Poesia - Osteria Italiana rocks.

Smartly-dressed Francesco greeted us and immediately seated us in their quiet (a first for neighborhood Italian places) dining room.  I ordered a tasty Nero d'Avalo Sicilian red wine and settled in.  

When it came time to order I chose the appetizer and pasta specials.  Moreover I enjoyed actually hearing my dining partners voice while we waited for dinner.  My garden fresh salad was a mix of arugula, bright-red cherry tomato and scooped-from-the-sea grilled squid.  It was a perfect way to begin the meal with a fantastic light dressing and the right amount of acid against the tender baby squid.  The pasta was an inspired blend of fettuccini, pan roasted cherry tomatoes, a smooth and silky tart 'n' spicey tomato sauce with coulis of basil and olive oil set against buttery cubes of sautéed swordfish finished with fresh romano cheese.   (Writing about my meal made me hungry again!)

When they found out that we were neighbors and it was our first time in the restaurant they treated me to a home made chocolate liquor that tasted like a melted, ultra rich milkshake with a boozy bite.  My compatriot had a foodgasm for their extraordinary homemade chocolate mousse with sea salt, olive oil and chili powder.

Wow, these guys have really brought a different dining experience to the Mission/Castro.  BRAVO!
author: frederick f.

description:
Went back to Poesia and had another fantastic meal.

The service the wines and the food were outstanding.

Still my favorite Italian restaurant in the Castro!
author: Jorge H.

description: Went here for a second try and have to say it didn't hold up compared to my first review. The food was good, not amazing like the first time. The waiter was good but here is the deal. I love arugula and ordered the arugula salad and the waiter recommended the fillet. What the waiter didn't tell us was that pretty much the same salad we ordered off the menu came with the steak, hummm. Lots and lots of arugula. The chocolate mouse with chili and sea salt is amazing. This place is good, my first impression was it was Great! I think it's good, but with all the other great places around they need to step up the game!
author: Jill T.

description: We have eaten here before and have a had a wonderful dinning experience and time was no exception. Alex our server and the rest of staff let us set our own pace in dining, which was slow and filled with great conversation, which is not found at all of the places we have eaten.
