Now the food was excellent for the three of us my wife had the special stuffed ravioli,  my son ad the vegetarian dish(the only one on the menu) and I had the fettuccine al ragu' di agnello and all was very much to our taste. The desert we shared was a dark chocolate mousse with sea salt and the sea salt could have been ground a little finer and little less, it left with more salt taste than chocolate. Otherwise the whole evening was great success.
author: Ron W.

description:
My girlfriend and I went to Poesia on a random sort of date. It was a fantastic choice.
Although I've been on that block a million times I never noticed this place. I had assumed it was a residence -and indeed it once was- but when you walk up the steps into the second-floor restaurant you find a very warm atmosphere.

We were greeted by a friendly hostess and waited just a few moments for our table to be set. They gave us the one right at the front window with a great view of 18th/Castro which really did help set the tone for the evening.

Our meal was very tasty as was the wine which we asked the server to help us select. Sorry to be vague on both food and drink but I am writing this review a few weeks overdue. I also believe we shared a yummy dessert but damned if I can recall 2 weeks later. (Hopefully my g/f will remember these things and write a review too)

At some point in the evening the owner came by and chatted with us. He was quite friendly and later sent over some delicious sampler liqueurs. 

I think both my girlfriend and I felt like we were getting the royal treatment. You always hope for good service when you go out to dine, but rarely get the type of legendary service we encountered that night. 
I suppose it was due in part to the fact that it was a quieter night of the week, and possibly because we mentioned that we chose the restaurant from Yelp (raising restaurant standards since...?) Not to take anything away from the fine folks who took care of us that night. Not at all. 
We will happily return and hope for a similar experience.
author: Evan A.

description:
This is a difficult review to write, I so wanted love this place and slap a 5 star approval down, but after dinner last night I just can't.   It's a gorgeous little restaurant, but the layout is a little cramped, so between the person behind me slamming their chair into my back when they got up to leave and the close proximity to the loud boor at the next table I was distracted from what was really a pretty good meal.  So distracted in fact we called it quits after the main course and passed on dessert.  The staff were lovely but I had to twice flag down a waiter to order another glass of wine.  The beef carpaccio was beautiful though and for that I'll give it another try sometime soon to see if it can earn those additional stars...

*Update*
2nd visit proved out the first.  Carpaccio fabulous, everything else the same although service improved a little since last time its still cramped, another chair in the back experience (and I'm not that big!).  But it remains 3 stars and a parting of ways.  
Good luck Poesia, plenty of people seem to like you so I'm sure you'll be fine without me, ciao.
author: Nick S.

description:
Poesia = schweet, also the staff is agreeable and if you're the type of person who chats it up with the staff (cough *cough ME cough* cough) then you will be at home. The entire staff & owner are Italian's and treat you like family; however, not you're family at Thanksgiving or when you're left in a shopping mall and you're eight, I mean they never came to my little league games....but I digress

The food! Poesia has excellent food. I really liked the Seabass and the Gnocchi which my friends ordered, I had the Steak: quality meat and perfectly done. As wine lists go, many are in the 30's and are unique selections from Italy. 

The only item I didn't like was the hearts of romaine salad...the dressing was bland and spooky.

I'd go here over Beretta the atmosphere and the small or no wait.
author: Stephen S.

description: I really wanted to like this place. Unfortunately, the food is all a little off -- which is weird, because Italian food is so standard, it's hard to imagine how any kitchen could go wrong. The service is friendly but not great on details: at least 3 people at our table (a group of about 10) got dishes that had unexpected elements/ingredients in them, or were weirdly spicy when there was no indication on the menu that they'd be spicy at all. Generally, if the menu fails to mention something important like that, the server should. It's a cute place and you've gotta love the bizarro old timey films they project on the back wall, so the 2 stars are basically for ambiance and because they're trying. However, I would never eat here again, especially when the food is both disappointing AND expensive.
author: S G.

description: Compared to the price you pay for the food here, they have very mediocre food. I ordered the fillet mignon, medium well and it was almost burnt in some parts and very tasteless. Don't recommend it.
author: Nazanin S.

description:
Just had a fabulous evening. Great food, great service, perfect ambiance. Manager comped us for our deserts and aperitif, which was wonderful as he then sat down to talk with us after our meal.  A wonderful and authentic experience topped off with some interesting conversation with the staff.

The dishes were rich and rewarding to taste, with interesting and experimental flavors mixed among the menu.  Our dessert of chocolate mousse, rock salt, olive oil, marscapone cheese and chili powder was particularly notable.

One of our dishes, a special of the evening, was a noble effort but for the price lacked the value one expects from such a highly regarded restaurant. Certainly it was tasty and well received at the table and the ambiance and color of the restaurant more than made up for any perceived flaws.  A star is taken away only because this place needs room to go up!
author: Curtis J.

description:
i went here 2 years ago because of lack of a better place
i don't remember what i ate, but now, looking at the menu, it's weird to think of all the things i would eat that i would've frowned at when i was 21

food and personal growth is weird like that
lovely like that
expensive like that

they projected an old movie on the wall
late-night
author: jen f.

description: I don't leave Marin often enough to dine, but I ventured out that night with four fabulous girlfriends to the place we all still argue about pronunciation (pe-ee-sha? posha? po-see-a?).  Anyway, it had that great little bistro vibe, excellent wines (of which the great bartender let us try several until we found the one we liked best).  We had a cozy round table in the back by the bar. The appetizers were amazing, my pasta was delightful, but my friend's chicken was a bit dry.  That is what she gets for ordering chicken over pasta, but I have to agree there is nothing worse than drik chicken.  We EACH had a starter, a salad, a main course and a dessert so between the five of us, we tried just about everything.  With the exception of the chicken - the rest was great, including the steak.  The service was fantastic too.  The neighboorhod spot was fun too, although I will admit after three years of living in the bay area, that was my first experience walking out of a restaurant and seeing a completely naked man strolling down the street.  Despite the chicken and the streaker, I'll definately go back.
author: Nora F.

description: After hearing great reviews of the veggie options here, I went with my boyfriend's family a few months back. The staff were very friendly and quick to seat us, without a reservation on a Friday night, in a nice table in the back corner all to ourselves (which was nice, because we could talk and hear each other). I loved the b/w movie playing on the wall, and the decor overall- very unique but not over the top, and still very romantic. The waitress knew her wines fairly well, and offered us still or sparkling water (although, I think the sparkling cost a bit more). The food was really very good, not amazing, but the veggie options (especially gnocchi) were nothing to complain about (although, I've had better, in Italy). If you are in the area, definitely a great deal... there is better Italian in SF, but for the friendliness, value, and atmosphere, this place might top the list.
author: Amanda S.

description:
I came here for a friends birthday. I love this place. The staff are so friendly and funny at the same time. We were a little late and they didn't give our table away like everywhere else would've done. The antipasti were stuff I never had before. The main dish was so intense I couldn't figure out what was the seasoning. The coffee was as rich as the dessert.  

Parking was hell. The bread that they brought to the table was cold. Even the food that they brought to the table was barely warm. And some plates many mines came late.
author: M C.

description:
Great food, great company, and great service.  I can't really complain.  

Let's start with the food - Everyone pretty much liked what the ordered.  I started with the eggplant souffle - so light and wonderful.  Also tried someone else's beet salad, which was nicely presented and well-dressed.  I was pretty full already, but bring on the red beet tortelloni.  Immediately I could smell the smoked cheese on top.  Now this tortelloni was very unique, I've never had red beet filling before and LOVE beets.  The smoked gouda(?) on top was a great complement.  

I would also have to say that we had a few bottles of wine with dinner; despite choosing from the cheaper end of the wine list (~$40-45 per bottle), I was pleasantly surprised.  

On to the service: Usually with a party of 14, you would expect service to suck because they're getting an 18-20% gratuity regardless.  Not only was service excellent (constantly refilling our water glasses despite leaving bottles of water for us is always a good sign), but they also let us bring in our own cupcakes to celebrate the birthday boy.  They seemed to do this without any complaints, amazing a restaurant that's not trying to gouge you for every little cent.
author: Olivia T.

description: One star, not for the food or for the service, but because the owners are not listening.  Rarely are so many Yelp reviews so clear....you are too pricey.  When the check at Blvd. (a top 5 SF restaurant) is less that Poesia, it's time to listen.
author: Gary H.

description: Very quaint and friendly! This place is authentic! I sat at the bar next to a relative of the owner who was behind the bar, and I got to listen to them speak Italian to one and other throughout my meal! It was awesome! Every service member who passed me attempted to help, if they could, and not in a pushy way. The food was delicious as well. There were new twists on classic Italian recipes. Get the Carpaccio!
author: Robert M.

description:
A bit disappointed.

First, we waited for 40 minutes past our reservation time. The restaurant was overly packed with the seats bumping into people on other tables. It was an extremely busy evening so I would've been willing to overlook that but when my lamb chops came---I ordered it to be cooked medium---it actually came well done..big difference. I didn't bother saying anything because by the time the food came, we were absolutely famished. It was basically one reason after another. Overall a disappointing experience especially since we heard so much good things about the restaurant on Yelp. I think that the experience may have been better if they weren't over extended and rushed. The wait staff were very apologetic so I have to give them a little credit. I could tell that they were trying very hard so I felt sorry if I complained about my food.
author: Vincent L.

description:
There is hope yet for Castro dining.  I only wish this place was on the street level and not in this cursed location.  

The atmosphere hasn't changed since the restaurant that was in this place back in 1997.  But the food, service and amazing staff have certainly changed.  

I really hope Poesia stays around.   Ideally if they could change locations that would be even better.  How cool if that idiot who owns the Patio space would allow this place to go in there and set up a cafe style dining.  You would feel like you were back in Italy and become a destination spot
author: Scott P.

description:
I don't think I have ever been as excited to give a 5 star review as I am for this one. I was absolutely stunned with Poesia- I'm not sure if it was from the welcoming we received by the host or by our server and his amazing true Italian blood, but this place certainly knows how to do it. 
Our server, Mattia, was so fun- we watched as he did his magic with a Jeroboam (I think) at the neighboring table. I was amazed that he could even pour the wine from that bottle without dripping it all over. 
When I asked him about the wine he laughed and told us that his father had a winery in Italy and that he's handled larger bottles than that! Ha! 
The food- the food was amazing. We had a table of four and we shared quite a few bites among each other as we all had dazzled taste buds. 
We had the Tortino ai Carciofi (Fried Artichoke cake, Mozzarella) and Antipasto di Salumi to start. Both delicious but I was more impressed with the Antipasto. 
Next we had Insalata Fresca and Insalata di Barbabietole (Golden and Red Beets, Radish, Goat Cheese). I am a beet lover so anything with beets is amazing to me- especially when they are fresh! 
My entree was the Ravioli al Granchio and it literally melted in my mouth. My husband tried the Fettuccine al Ragu and that was also very tasty. He made the comment that when we come back, he wouldn't order anything else, he loved the home made pasta! Our Dad tried the Filet Mignon which was really tender but I wouldn't give up my ravioli for the filet any day. 
Even our wine choice was good and it was a very reasonable bottle ($44). 
I can't wait to come back and experience Poesia again! Well done!
author: Janell D.

description:
Love. This. Place.

Excellent food, friendly service, great location.

Start with a drink at the bar.  Mattia usually has a drink special (often with some wonderful fresh fruit ingredient) or will make you whatever you want.  He's a master.

Appetizers are great--tomato soup is out of this world, and if they have sardines as a special, forget about your experience long ago of oily little bony fish--this ain't them.

There are usually several specials each night and the pasta is fresh.  After at least 12 meals, I've never had a bad dish.  Really, they're wonderful.

And for dessert, don't miss the spicy chocolate liquer--a liquid version of the chocolate mousse with sea salt and chili.  May not sound like a winning combination but it is.

Glad that Francesco and his team have broken the curse that this restaurant location seemed to have for years.
author: David A.

description: RUN to eat here...I don't care that it's in the middle of the Castro and parking may be a nightmare (take MUNI)...you will be missing out on some of the most wonderful food in San Francisco. The atmosphere is wonderful. The food is absolutely lovely. It is the most romantic restaurant in the Castro. While many are dying to get into Frances (I've been there) I like this so (SO) much better. It's friendlier. It's more cozy. And the food...have I mentioned the food?!
author: Mark M.

description:
Mediocre.

We went hear after reading all the Yelp reviews. This place is apparently very hit or miss.  Some people seem to love it, others hate it.  We actually had a middle-of-the road experience.

Plusses:
Service was stellar.  We were very well taken care of and felt like the staff genuinely wanted us to have a good experience.
The "asmuse-bouche" of fava-bean and pecorino cheese crostini was tasty!  The arancini was also good, but warning, it has fennel in it, which may not be to everyone's liking.

Minuses:
I ordered the "controversial" gnocchi.  I was hoping to love it, but afraid, based on other Yelp reviews....apparently I had good reason to be afraid.  It was completely overcooked and tasteless. I tried to pick up a piece of gnocchi after I had already speared a mushroom on my fork, and the gnocchi turned to complete mush.  That is not supposed to happen!
My husband ordered the pork rib pasta, which had more flavor, but was also overcooked.

Such a shame that they don't seem to know how to cook pasta al dente...
author: Kimberly G.

description:
We also had a great time at Poesia.

The service is incredible and it is such a warm welcome to the neighborhood. The food was also good. After sampling the other plates I was glad I ordered the special pork tenderloin. Yum! I also enjoyed the complimentary fennel digestifs at the end of the meal. Whooo!

Please keep specializing in regional cuisine because the Calabrese style is delicious!!
author: G Z.

description:
My husband and I, who usually love Poesia and take friends and visitors here whenever possible, took his brother and his brother's wife here for a double date a few weeks back.  While past experiences have been superb, this visit left us slightly perturbed.  I ordered my usual favorite: Fileji di Renato but noticed a $9/$16 price tag this time.  Perhaps this was something I've somehow missed in past visits, but it definitely didn't look familiar.  My first course came out (it was a special starter of the day) and it was OK, nothing memorable.  And then my main (the Fileji) arrived.  From the looks of the portion I assumed I was being charged the $9 plate, but when the bill arrived, I was shocked to see the small pile of pasta cost $16!  We inquired with the server who claimed it's always been this cost for 4oz of pasta.  I'm sorry, come again?  4oz of pasta equates to $16 dollars?  Food doesn't come much heavier than pasta, in my opinion, and to charge $4/oz (for PASTA - which is comprised of flour, some salt, and eggs.. maybe a potato) seems a bit nickel 'n dime-ish to me.  

In addition, the ambiance wasn't quite as pleasant as it has been.  In fact, it was so loud we could barely hear each other and ended up focusing on just eating so we could go somewhere else more conducive to conversation.

Overall, very disappointed.
author: Arlie A.

description: This place is a gem!  The kale salad was incredible, squid ink pasta was perfect, and the sea salt chocolate mousse was amazing.
author: Lucas J.

description:
Went there with some friends last night and it was just great -- food, atmosphere, service.  Really what made the experience though was our waiter, Devin.  

He was amazingly friendly, knowledgeable, and real.  He made the most amazing apple cucumber martini (smoothest and best martini I've ever had) and the best non-alcoholic shirley temple (yes, I drink those) I've ever tasted!  To top it off, after we finished, he let us try a new mix of his with black cherry infused vodka + blueberry aloe and some other goodness I can't remember -- incredible!

Will definitely go back, esp if it's a Mon or Tue which is when Devin's around. :)
author: Virginia W.

description: We were passing through the Castro and decided to Yelp for an Italian restaurant and Poesia turned up at the top of the list.  We were not disappointed.  Poessia is amazing.  The food here is as good as it gets.  And although I've seen a couple of reviews here that are critical of the service, our experience was a very good one.  We were there on a Friday night and the place was very busy.  Despite this, we had excellent service.  It is a little on the pricey side, although we had no regrets dropping some cash here as both the food and service were outstanding.  We could've gotten out a lot cheaper if it weren't for all the wine.  We will definitely go back.
author: Kevin H.

description:
It's great to have a new spot in the neighborhood that has excellent food, a nice wine list, and most importantly a great staff!  I find myself wandering into Poesia from time to time just to grab a quick bite at the bar.  Inevitably I wind up chatting with the very friendly staff and always leave happy!

Kudos to Poesia for creating a fantastic atmosphere to go along with the food and wine offering!
author: Jason H.

description:
Came here last week and had a good experience. The staff is great, service is awesome. Started with a very good salad. 

Pasta dish I had was decent.
author: Art A.

description:
Yeah, I really loved the owner and the entire staff.  They were all very friendly, and very cute in the - I'd like to mingle with them at a dinner party - kind of way.  Plus, the drinks were delicious, and clearly made with loving care by the bartender.  And the food was wonderful with homemade pasta, etc.  I will definitely be back to try more of the menu.  

I think it's a hard location to make work because even though it is located in central Castro, it was hard to find even when I was looking for it, because it is up a flight of stairs.  I really hope this local restaurant stays around because there are not enough great places in the Castro to eat.
author: Julie B.

description:
Definitely one of the better Italian restaurants to be found in SF. Wait staff was very attentive even though it was so busy in the restaurant.  I would definitely recommend getting reservations if going there on a weekend.  Love the location of the restaurant. which is the living room of a house.

A group of went a while ago so don't quite remember the dishes, but I do remember what the impression was...delicious.  Most of us ordered of the specials that had that night and it all turned out fantastic.  Dessert was chocolate with sea salt and cayenne pepper, if you've never tried these seasonings with chocolate before...you're missing out on something special.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
I came here last night with all of the other folks trying to cash in on their groupons.  There was a delay in the kitchen because of the groupon traffic (but I don't blame them for this).  I think they handled this as well as they could.

However, I was really excited to try this place, but wasn't really impressed with their dishes.  The tomato soup was the best dish we got.  The burrata, asparagus, and prosciutto was good too.  However, our main dishes lamb shank ragu and short rib pasta dish were only ok.  I was excited about home made pasta, but it didn't live up to my expectations.

For Italian I recommend Contadina or North Beach Restaurant.
author: J S.

description: This place is a gem. I was here with a friend and I had the minestrone soup with home made egg pasta.  The soup was hearty and delicious.  My friend had a mozzarella appetizer and the gnocchi, which he liked.  We both split a flaky, pear dessert, which was delicious.  The service was excellent and you felt genuinely welcome by the staff.
author: Carlos C.

description:
Poesia o tragedia?

This is a pretentious dump that serves microwaved, processed food. It is mind boggling that in a city like San Francisco, with so many great Italian restaurants (eg Sodini's), this place can stay in business. It preys on Castro tourists. Stay away.

I speak fluent Italian, yet could not communicate effectively with the staff, despite their "Italian" accents, or my attempts to communicate in English!

The "carpaccio" is, I swear, two rolled up pieces of Trader Joe's roast beef mixed with greens and some shaved "parmesan".

The garbanzo bean soap, which I got after mistakenly being brought gnocchi (I guess those two words sound the same - to an idiot!), was served at a thermonuclear temperature. The waiter confirmed it was microwaved, even though, later, the head waiter told me they "didn't own a microwave". Bulls*#%!

I didn't stay for the pasta. It did finally come out - after telling the waiter I was tired of waiting and to bring my check. It looked like Stouffer's.

Il ristorante è merda!
author: Osiris C.

description: I came back from a 6-week trip to Italy last week and have been to Poesia twice since. I needed a hit of real Italian food. Their Papa al Pomodoro (soup) rivals what you find in Florence. I love this place. They make you feel welcome, even when they are jammed. They stay open late, a plus in a city that shuts down too early for my taste. I love the food. The sardines and the calamari are both excellent.  It is a converted flat and I like being upstairs and able to watch the lively city below. Great place.
author: jessica d.

description: Fantastic restaurant. Nice location. Great food. Friendly staff. Perfect for a date.
author: Michael S.

description:
Poesia is without a doubt the best restaurant in the Castro. In some neighborhoods it would not stand out but the Castro is a culinary wasteland for the most part. No one goes there (the neighborhood) for its food choices. The best restaurants prefer to locate in the more hip Valencia corridor 1/2 mile east. So Poesia being here serves its local community well.
The location is up a stairway above a garage and the dining room is small and intimate. It is very comfortable and well appointed but not hip and ultra chic.
It is a quiet and reserved place that is really great for a date.
I had the Lamb Shank Bolognese pasta. It was so delicious! The wine list is excellent with glasses priced $8-11. Service was refined and attentive. The host is a really nice gentleman (I think he is the owner) and he is there to make sure that you have a good experience at his establishment. My dining partner had the Grass Fed Filet Mignon which I tried a bite...and was also incredible. It melted in my mouth!
I only drink beer and wine so I cannot comment on the cocktails.
Overall, it was a really enjoyable dinner that was worth the price. I highly recommend it.
author: Andreas M.

description:
Full bar, real italian chef and a low key, quiet atmosphere. This is one of my favorite dining spots in the 'stro. The menu is always changing so you never get bored. The quality is so consistent that you can be adventurous, try new things and never have to regret it.
I love going to a restaurant where you can actually hear the conversation of your dinner companions. What a concept!
author: J D.

description: It is a really cute place, it was full on a Saturday night which is always fun. The bread is really good and it's nice coz they keep refilling it! I really wanted to like this place but the pasta I had was tasteless and the pork in it was hard to chew. My friend's lamp chops were nice tho, with really good flavors. The portions, however, are really small, which was another minus. We had the Canolli for dessert, which was good but not great. If I ever go again, it will be only for the nice setting!
author: Ishita S.

description: The food was good, but I thought it was a bit expensive when I got the check.  It's a cute place.
author: Elena L.

description:
Four of us went for a dinner here on a week night, and though the owner is very kind, and the space is cute, that's about the best thing I can say.  

A two course dinner took us more than two and a half hours.  We waited an hour before even getting bread.  Our appetizers were bland and tasteless, and unforunately, the main course, which we waited another hour for, was the same.  I ordered an airline chicken breast that looked like it came off of a cornish hen (TINY), and it was charred.

Our waitress was completely unattentive, and the chef spent most of the time out in the dinning room chatting when he should have been in the kitchen doing some serious quality control.  Out of four people at our table, only one was satisfied with his meal, but that was only after he sent it back to the kitchen because it wasn't what he had ordered (or at least, it wasn't how it was described on the menu).

We really wanted this place to survive because we really like the owner, but we won't go back, and I can't recommend any one else should either.
author: Joshua M.

description:
At first I was afraid, I was petrified...

...and for good reason.

A friend and I met up at 9p here on a Thursday and were seated promptly.  Not much has changed from when this place use to be Ararat.  Of course the paint is new, the corks are gone from above the bar, and the style is more French Country...I thought this was suppose to be an Italian restaurant?

After ordering our entrees (both specials for the night), the boyfriend called and said the he and a friend would be joining.  Changing our table from a two top to a four was no problem at all.  The waiter was more than happy to fulfill our request and wouldn't even let me carry my own gym bag to the other table. 

I ordered the veal which was very tender but small in portion.  It came with zucchini and potatoes which were quite delicious.  We're still not quite sure what my friend ordered other than we think it was Salt Cod raviolis with a red pepper and shrimp sauce.  He said that it has no taste and that he wasn't sure if the lack of flavor that it did have were mixed well together.

The BF ordered the gnocchi which was extremely bland and mushy.  He had asked for ground pepper and salt and not even that was able to help save his dish.  Our other friend had ordered the Airline Chicken Breast like Joshua M. did and it was the same as he had reviewed, "...looked like it came off of a Cornish Hen (TINY), and it was charred."  We think this was topped with a lime and cilantro sauce which had a very grit-like texture.  Needless to say, the BF returned his dish and did not order another entree as we were all finished with our meals.

The dessert was okay.  One friend had ordered the hazelnut ice cream sandwich, but he said the bread it came on was hard.  I believe it was made to come that way, however he would have like it to be a little softer.  I myself ordered the cannoli which I thought was wonderful.  The BF on the other hand spit it out and thought it was disgusting.  His loss!  I ate the whole thing.  Strangely enough, when I asked for the dessert wine list, they looked at me like I had a huge pimple on my forehead.  Finally the waiter came over with a ruby and tawny port.  The tawny port was fantastic!

The waitstaff is extremely friendly and attentive.

I don't think I'll be heading back to Poesia anytime soon.  Like Joshua M. I would like to see this place thrive, however, I think they need kick up there spices a bit.
author: Shane P.

description:
Cute Italian bar and restaurant tucked away on what feels like a refitted second-floor apartment. The staff are friendly; our waitress was so cool I want to believe she'd had a bit to drink.

Pasta's always a good comfort food, and as with most mid-range Italian places the portions were satisfactory. I only wish they had more than five red wines by the glass (I got a cocktail instead).

Five entrees, two appetizers, two coffees and two drinks total came to $130.
author: Nick D.

description:
Finally, a good restaurant in this space!  

I had no idea that Poesia even opened, but I'm glad my dining companion suggested we eat dinner here.  I loved the carpaccio zucchini.  It was such a light and refreshing dish!

My dining companion's half-chicken was very moist, flavorful and lemony while my tagliatelle with squid and scallops was quite well done.  

Plus, our waiter was a hoot!  I loved his two-toned glasses and he was super attentive and helpful.
author: Marcus C.

description:
This place is so cool and very-very classy. 
Its pricey, you get a normal sized meal (way too small for my American standards). I love the cocktails, nice bar, really! 

On the other hand I find it annoying when the nerdy waiters stress the Italian accent (Not impressed).
Wish they had more things on the menu! 
8-meals-list is not a choice :)
author: P.H. D.

description: We had a really nice dinner here Saturday night.  Probably my favorite thing about the evening was they didn't rush us - we stayed probably about 2 1/2 hours, celebrating my husband's birthday, just the 2 of us. The waiter and maitre d' were sweet and attentive, but not overly so.  I almost always go with the waiter's recommendations, and this was no exception. For an appetizer, I had the sardines - delicious. For the entree I had the risotto - lovely and creamy. Only criticism is that both were a bit salty for my taste.  Had a very yummy fig manhattan.
author: Carolyn B.

description:
The service was better than the food.  That's pretty much all I can say.  

The eggplant parmigiana was bland and boring.  Just a square piece of parmigiana slapped onto a plate.  There wasn't even any effort made for presentation.

Our salumi platter had mortadella on it.  Isn't that a lunch meat?  Oscar Meyer comes to mind.

Dessert was two melon ball sized chocolate mousse scoops.  The flavors were interesting, but a little stingy on the serving, I thought.

Came here based on the reviews on Yelp!, but this is the first time I really felt like the reviews were way off.  Not worth revisiting just to see if they were having a bad night, so I'm sticking with my review.
author: Anna V.

description: very good italian food, great service, a hidden neighborhood gem.
author: John F.

description:
This is a great little Italian restaurant in the 2nd story of an old victorian.  The location reminds you of dining in the parlor of a good friend, who cooked for you true Italian dishes with fine ingredients.  

For a primi, I had a daily special of farfalle, asparagus and crispy, thick cut prosciutto.   

As the secondi, I had the pollo al mattone (chicken under a brick), which had a phenomenally crispy skin redolent of lemon and herbs.   

I would do the primi/secondi route if you have a healthy appetite, as the pasta courses are sized appropriately for that combination.

Service was good, considering how busy the overall restaurant was.
author: Greg K.

description:
We were at Poesia to celebrate our anniversary - and we definitely chose the right place. Found this through Opentable and not Yelp, but that is another story.
Reading the reviews here I realized that this is a great place, and also found out what the best dishes are - like the lamb ragu - so I will not go into details about the food - which was really great.
What we had was extraordinary good service with great wine (and aperitifs) suggestions (like the 2003 Allegrini La Poja, not found on the wine menu), several complimentary tastings of grappa and dessert wines. The muscat with the great tiramisu and the 20 yr old port with the chocolate mousse (rock salt, chili, olive oil) where perfect pairings. The last one we had was a combination of chili, cocoa (liqueur), which was really good, too.
The person who served us was exceptionally nice and good (I am so sorry but I forgot your name!) and our evening was unforgettable.
The only reason I do not give 5 stars is that I have that reserved for some of the mind-blowing places on the globe that I have not (yet) experienced.
author: Kaj HeGe H.

description:
Went there last night.  

Negatives:
- Wait time for food to leave the kitchen. I think 40+ mins for entrees to arrive after the appetizers. 
- I ordered the free range chicken entree and got way way way over cooked chicken.  Probably put the chicken in the oven and forgot about it.

Positives: 
-  We arrived early before our reservation time and got seated early.
- Atmosphere was ok. Seat spacing wasn't too tight so that was a plus
- Gnocchi appettizer was ok
- Corkscrew Pasta entree was ok. 
- wait staff + host service was ok.  

I would have probably given 3 stars if not for the over cooked chicken.  I can forgive wait time if the food was worth the wait
author: Peter C.

description: Great homemade, al dente pastas.  The appetizers/ salads are not really big enough to share between two people so get an individual one for each.  I absolutely love the beet stuffed ravioli.  Yummy.  Good wine selection served by a group of Italian waitstaff.  Brought me back to Italy.  If you want spaghetti and meatballs, go to Olive Garden. If you want authentic Italian food, this is your place.
author: John F.

description: This is the real thing. Best Italian in the neighborhood - they get it. Cozy space, not too noisy. I'm going back!
author: Mark C.

description:
Living in South Bay we're always easily impressed by any restaurants in SF. Poesia is definitely different from anything we have in Sunnyvale ;) Almost easy to miss this place among all the restaurants and bar on 18th St. Relaxing and very chill atmosphere. Enjoyed my pasta with artichokes, shiitake, walnuts. Had a taste of ravioli which was interesting and really good, not the usual gloopy cheesy pasta fare i"m used to. Service was gracious, not all in your face. We lingered without being rushed over our dessert which we shared amongst our group of 5, tiramisu that almost made me orgasm and berries over a flaky pastry which was so-so. A tad bit pricey but on the whole quite worth it.
Only downside to dining in the city is parking is a bitch.
author: M G.

description: I went here for dinner and really enjoyed the food.  The service was reasonably good, and I was very happy with the food.  It fits in this nice niche of good Italian that isn't overly expensive and has a nice ambiance to it.  Perhaps the only knock I have against the place was that it was a little cramped- we were seated inches away from another table on one side, and the other I had to keep making room for peopling walking through.  Otherwise, I was happy with the experience and would recommend it.
author: Peter B.

description: Sweet little Italian find, this restaurant! Love the intimacy, the great food & the black and white Italian movies playing on the wall. We had driven for a couple of hours to get to the city for an event in the Castro - took our chances with this restaurant from Yelp reviews. Perfect little restaurant!
author: Lorraine G.

description: Food was good but the owner needs a lesson in customer service. I would've never guessed he was appreciative of our business. So many other great restaurants in Castro that would gladly take and appreciate my business.
author: R W.

description: The best bartender!  Wonderful food.  The entire evening takes you back to Italy.  Relaxed, some items were fabulous, some were okay, but I give five stars because the entire experience is very nice.
author: mi m.

description: Among the best Italian food I'll ever have is but 4 blocks from my front door. Great staff. Grilled sardines apetizer is to die for.   Fun space. Reserve back table if you are a small group. Cozy as hell.  Am I permitted to say once again, "great staff" who are wonderfully attentive in making sure you have a great evening?
author: John C.

description:
My wife and I went here recently on a date - a merciful getaway from our little two year old.  The menu was refreshingly brief: selections for antipasti, zuppa/salade, primis and secondis all squeezed onto one page and which included some delicious-sounding plates.  

As we arrived, the place was abuzz and there was barely room for us to wait on the small chaise by the front door.  Other patrons entered, stepping on our feet, and getting swiped by the busy wait-staff.  Finally, 30 minutes after our reservation, we were seated by the placating host.  We didn't mind the wait, the atmosphere seemed fun and the b&w film showing on the dining wall kept us entertained. 

Nearly everything was downhill from that point onward:  We had to ask for our bread and oil, our drinking water, a decent wine glass as opposed to the neanderthal-goblet our Montepulciano was initially served in, and the food was...not as good as it sounded.  

For starters, we ordered an artichoke puff pastry which was completely mediocre, surrounded by a too-tangy citrus sauce, and an over-the-top rich gnocchi which never melted in the mouth and was too grainy inside.  The kitchen did hit it just right with a lentil-fava zuppa flavored with pancetta and topped with grilled calamari.  It was subtle but deeply flavored and the crispy squid were delicious.  Unfortunately, our risotto nero came to the table looking like someone had assembled it in a dark room.  A massive heap of black rice with green-tinted scallops and shrimp around it - very poor presentation.  It tasted passable but we were ready to cruise at that point.  To top it off, our diminuitive waiter "accidentally" slipped a decaf coffee onto the bill!

Too bad - this place's polish and pizazz misled us into thinking it would be a fully-fledged dining experience.  Not worth the bill!
author: David S.

description: I love this place.  I have Yelp to thank for finding it.  I had seen the reviews and thought I'd give it a try.  I didn't even know the place was there.  You have to walk up a flight of stairs to get to it.  This is the real deal.  Owned and operated by a real Italian.  The waiters are from Italy (some are from Spain) and I think that there is an Italian in the kitchen doing the cooking.   The food is outstanding.  They are doing a good business.  By 8 o'clock they place is buzzing and crowded - The word is out.  Give this place a try.  I especially like the Eggplant Parmigiana.  I've tried several different dishes and they were all very good.
author: Arthur W.

description: Very nice Italian selection. Love the sardines. Good service, though they did have a few tables set up for large parties. Nice wine selection as well. Have been a few times before, and will return again.
author: Joey D.

description: The best and most authentic Italian food in the city. And good price for the quality of product.  Not a fan of tomato soup but this one is a don't miss; I order it every time. From the street the spot doesn't look that busy but walk up the stairs and it's like entering the door straight into your grandmother's kitchen. Cozy up to the bar with the handsome and talented mixologists or sit at a table and ask Francesco to help you choose the perfect bottle of Italian vino to go with your handmade pasta. Yummy!. Perfect balance of ambiance, food, and service. Just don't take my spot at the end of the bar!
author: Madison P.

description:
I was hoping for a relaxed, quite dinner with simple food; instead, I spent an evening increasingly perplexed by the frazzled service that seemed to alternate between desperately soliciting our approval and ignoring us.

A dish that we were told early had only one left later turned out  to be in plentiful supply; an appetizer arrived that we didn't order, was rejected, reappeared, was rejected again, reappeared after the server consulted with our waitress, was eaten; when the waitress checked on our table later, she seemed upset that we had actually eaten the appetizer the server had forced on us.  The appetizer then made it on our bill, but in exchange the dessert was free - what's going on here?  We all make mistakes, but why not fix them and move on?

The food itself was alright - I wouldn't bring people here for the food, but I wouldn't avoid it, either.  I liked the very dense chocolate mousse (but good thing we split it) although the mascarpone near it had to be scraped off the plate camouflaged under chocolate powder dust, and was easy to ignore; the grilled lamb chop appetizer was great.  The breaded, fried fennel worked surprisingly well with pepper, but would have benefited from something to cut the grease.  The dreaded reappearing beet salad appetizer didn't impress me - it had been dressed up in one of those stack-inside-a-metal-ring formats, but the flavor stayed kind of blah - they could have used a little dressing.  The New York Strip steak I had was fine, but I eventually grew tired of the large heap of leafy broccoli it came with.
author: Jutta D.

description:
Utterly amazing!!! 

Celebrated my birthday there with my family of friends.  The staff were gorgeous, friendly, attentive and generous!!! It felt as if we were at home with more friends.  The atmosphere, warm and cozy, cocooned us with soft light and delicious smells.  

Francesco communicated with me via email which eliminated all of the communication barriers I usually encounter in the 'hearing' world. And even in person, Francesco and the staff of Poesia made sure communication was fluid.  

Definitely will go back. . .for a romantic night, a festival, a feast or just to be!

Thank you Poesia!!! for making it all assolutamente bello! 

xoxo
author: susan g.

description:
We had a huge party recently. They were so easy to work with (they said the night we chose shouldn't be super busy) as we increased our guest count a few times.  They gave as a fixed price menu with plenty of options for everyone.

The food was great and the wait staff was very attentive.  The two of us will be going back to check it out under more normal circumstances.
author: Michael M.

description:
I love this place, and i've only been there once.

The service is excellent.  Every waiter came by our table at some point, including the owner to see how we were doing.  Oh, and the waiters are soo cute.  Handsome young Italian boys.  

For an appetizer, my friend and I ordered the tuna tartar and the carpaccio.  Yum.  I had  the swordfish for my main course, and we had the chocolate mousse and orange tiramisu for dessert.  Oh.  My.  God.  Flavors were just bursting in my mouth.  The chocolate mousse is sprinkled with sea salt and drizzeled with olive oil.  It was delicious.  Everything was fabulous.

And this place has ambiance.  It's so romantic and cute.  They had an old black and white italian movie playing, that was projected onto the wall.  Way cute.

I'm so coming back here!
author: Jennifer S.

description: I loved this restaurant for what it is:  Quiet and cozy ambiance with a superb menu of authentic Italian foods.  Our waiter was Italian and very knowledgeable about the food and the wine and region of the wine, climate etc.  I value that instead of someone totally unfamiliar serving me.  I had the sea food risotto and I found it delicious. I highly recommend Poesia and will definitely go back there again if I am in the area.
author: The W.

description: Great food, friendly service. The owner supervises the operation, so things run pretty smoothly.
author: Hayward M.

description: went with my mom... she lived in italy for years, and thought it was very authentic. true italian. calamari salad was terrific, and the risotto with squid ink was oh so delicious. exceptional meal!
author: Kai C.

description: Best Italian I've had since Siciliana on College.  Thoughtful, authentic, classic service and a full bar.  For the true Italian cuisine lover.
author: yaron f.

description: This has got to be some of the best Italian food in town. The stuffed ravioli were moist with a delicate outer wrapper that was unlike anything I had had before. The sardine appetizer was amazing- super fresh and tasty, better than the sardine tapas I had in Barcelona.  Reasonable prices- although Groupon helped out quite a bit in this regards.  Will definitely return.
author: Yew-Hoe T.

description: The service is AMAZING - super friendly and helpful staff.  We had the bartender mix some cocktails for a few of us, and he ended up whipping up a scrumptious concoction for our entire table to try!  The food is standard, but made well and very tasty.  We went early so the staff was able to focus their attention on us - and who doesn't like that!
author: Vicente G.

description:
If cooking is Poetry - then Poesia is a perfectly executed sonnet.

Our meal at Poesia was simply exquisite.  We were not sure what to expect when we first walked into the restaurant.  We were early diners, and although the restaurant had reservations for 91 clients that night, we were quickly seated.  The restaurant is very tastefully decorated, with a flair of sophistication reminiscent of an elegant Italian villa.  The seating is very tight, so privacy is limited but intimacy is shared.

We began our meal with the gnocchi silani.  The gnocchi are house made with a remarkable cream sauce accentuated with a hint of citrus.  The sauce was very well balance without being overwhelming.  The undertone of the lemon married so well with the gnocchi, tomatoes, and basil.  Our taste buds were pleasantly awakened.

For our entree, we ordered the Filejo do Renato (pork rib, garlic, smoked ricotta.  I had the tagliatelle with beef ragout.  All we can say about them is "oh my god!"  The pastas were again fresh home made, and the seasoning of the sauces were perfectly balanced with no overtones of herbs that can ruin a meal. Poesia's chefs are superb!  The pork rib were so tender that the meat fell off the bone.

For desert, we ordered the tiramitsu with grand marnier - wow!  airy and delicious.  We also ordered the poached pears in a red wine reduction served with a cube of puff pastry with hazelnut gellato.  This was one of the best deserts that we have ever tasted.

Overall, Poesia was quite a surprise, and a definite do again.  The food presentation was perfect, and the owner/GM was in attendance ensuring that everything with our meal was perfect.  Although service was a bit slow at times (busy night) we were quite pleased with our dining experience.

The menu changes every night, so if our experience was consistent to the dining quality, we are due for wonderful experiences in the near future.  Give Poesia a chance, you won't be disappointed.
author: T N.

description:
"The food was great; I especially like the handmade pasta, it is thick and chewy. I had a pasta with scallops, the scallops tasted fresh and buttery.  My girlfriend had pasta with vegetables and a cheese sauce which was delicious, but it did contain mushrooms which were not listed on the menu and she had to pick them out. There are lots of good options for vegetarians, but they also serve alot of seafood and the dining area has the aroma you might expect. Dessert was a chocolate mousse - quite rich and interestingly very salty. The waiter made excellent wine pairing suggestions. 

In the second story of a remodeled house, Peosia pulls off a nice bohemian cafe atmosphere. This vibe is further reinforced by the doe-eyed and blase waiters who somehow make the place classy but not pretentious. The seating is "intimate" and it is effortless to snoop on your neighbor's conversation or choice of dish (if that's something you like to
author: Ren D.

description:
I dragged my other half back here for the second time, under the pretext of celebrating our anniversary, but I really just wanted to get some more of that chocolate fluff of heaven! 

The food flavors do not disappoint and the presentation of EVERYTHING is lovely, but some people might appreciate larger portions. The host was very warm and hospitable but the wait staff seemed stressed and rushed... service was fine, just not too friendly.   We skipped on the bottle of wine and just had two glasses to save a little, because dinner for two can easily edge toward $200 after tax+tip otherwise. 

I guess large parties are the norm here, but to me that seems to go completely against the intended ambiance of this small and intimate space. The noise level was enough to ruin the entire evening, mostly due to poor acoustics, and a few people who needed reminding to use their "indoor" voice. I don't' think we'll be going back on a weekend night ever again.  But I would gladly return for any splurge or special occasion that falls on a weekday!
author: astrofisica m.

description: Excellent. We showed up around 9 and sat right down. The service was very attentive and didn't mind letting us "graze" our dining experience (we closed the place). Ambiance is great, and the food was fantastic. We started with a Sauvignon Blanc & shared an Insalata Caprese, which is quite possibly the best Caprese I have ever tasted. We ordered the Squid Ink Risotto and the Filet Mignon, both of which were cooked perfectly and simply delicious. Finished with a Tiramisu and espresso.  Overall, the experience was quite lovely & I highly recommend!
author: the d.

description: Love Poesia!  The service and the food were great.  It was a little loud at times due to the table next to us but they were just having a good time.  The service was awesome and super friendly.  The owner even stopped by our table to check in.  Loved it!  The food was outstanding.  It reminded me of my last trip to Rome.  Delicious!  I would definitely go back and recommend it to my friends.
author: Tom S.

description: I went here tonight with a group of 10. The owner greeted us and couldn't have been nicer. The space is very nice - warm decor and not too loud. I had a beet salad to start. It was warm and mixed with a fresh goat cheese that melted into basically a dressing for the beets. Goat cheese and beets is pretty expected, but I love it anyway. I had the special tagliatelle pasta with porcini, truffle oil and a creamy sauce. The pasta was perfectly al dente and definitely tasted house made, which it is. Hubby had a fennel and pear salad with a citrus vinaigrette followed by a fileji pasta with slow cooked pork ribs. Yum! I asked the owner for a wine recommendation and he chose one right in our price range and let me taste it before committing. Service was good. They kept our wine and water glasses full and brought us more than enough bread. I'll definitely be back. Highly recommended.
author: Natalie T.

description:
I've walked down 18th a million times and never noticed this little gem. I wish I'd known about it sooner!
The ambiance and service were lovely. The food was delicious! Everything was super fresh and seasoned perfectly. Just thinking about the beef carpaccio and tomato sauce which coated my papparadelle makes my mouth water.  I will be back soon!
author: Kirsten S.

description:
This restaurant was a delightful surprise, and what I think a good restaurant should be. The staff made us feel immediately welcome, the service was superb, and they didn't blink when we decided to move to another table after sitting for a while. The wine suggestions complimented our dishes perfectly - our waiter was clearly very knowledgeable on food and wine pairings, which I highly value. On the Sunday night we were there, a  silent Italian film was being projected onto a nearby wall. It was all so good.

It wasn't  just a meal, it was an experience I can't wait to repeat.
author: Diane J.

description:
I'm confused as to why this place has such great reviews.

A limited and overpriced menu for mediocre food was my impression.
author: Dana R.

description:
we came here for a group dinner before going to the sing-a-long sound of music and got a table right as they opened at 5:30 (definitely no problem scoring a table then).

service and decor were excellent. they had a movie projected onto the far wall, but it was kind of unnecessary since most of the seats in the place didn't face that direction anyways and it's off to the side so it's not easy to see from the corner of your eye. foreign cinema it ain't. but alas, i digress.

apps: gnocchi and the fried artichoke. the gnocchi was not dense at all--an enjoyable dish, although a bit too citrusy for my taste (and others at the table). i'm normally not a fan of artichoke, but this app had me at first bite (i even semi-stole the last one). flaky crust and yummy artichoke filling.

i had the pork rib pasta on the recommendation of all the other reviews. everything was excellent about it except the food was too hot (burn your mouth hot) towards the middle and too cool (the kind of cool that makes food bland) on the edges. 

i tried a bite of the orecchiette off of a friend's plate and it was totally yummy--this is what i'm getting the next time i come.

i will definitely keep this place in mind for dining around the castro!
author: Jonathan K.

description: Consistently fresh, though I admit the grilled sardines as an appetizer makes me return. Attentive and smiling staff is a relief from haughty and holier than though servants at other lesser establishment. Best bar eating scene. I will return again and again.
author: One P.

description:
As soon we walked into Poesia, they made us feel at home. The maitre d' was warm, welcoming & friendly. The charming & cute owner, Francesco, offered us the wine list, brought us a bottle as we waited for our table, and chatted with us about his restaurant. Dimmed amber lights & silent Fellini films playing on one wall set a romantic low-key hip mood. 

As for the food -- spectacular & out-of-this-world! Best Italian food I've had outside of Italy, and I've had Italian here in SF, in Boston's North End and NYC's Little Italy! Food is Calabrian & everything rocked. Best calamari I've ever had - nice sear on the outside, tender and juicy inside; pork ribs melted in the mouth, and homemade pasta to die for. I can't wait to come back to this place!

This was a surprise belated birthday dinner date planned entirely by my man, who once again proved that somewhere deep inside him, there lurks the heart of a hipster.
author: Lisa M.

description: Not "as good as it gets," as the Yelp categories suggest for 5 stars, but for me pretty close.  Server was knowledgeable about the menu items and her recommendations deserve listening to, especially (1) the deep sea bass and (2) the chocolate mousse dessert.  The latter was a taste treat - a delicious mix of chocolate, salt, red pepper (very lightly done).  The latter moved me to write this review!  (Missed the fifth star because a baked chicken was a little uneven, partly moist, partly dry.)
author: Fred T.

description:
This place is amazing!  

We went for DH's bday.  Every staff member was friendly and warm. we were seated by the window bc of the special occasion. The resto is very casual and unpretentious with the fabulous food.

The cocktail list has some really yummy concoctions. The wine list offers a good variety, with reasonably-priced wines by the glass.  We started with the fried artichoke (it is a fried cake, not fried whole hearts) and the fennel, pear and arugula salad. both were yum. the fennel was fresh and crunchy. the olive oil is fragrant and delish! it comes from a very special region in sicily (i can't remember how to pronounce it but it was rated one of the top 10 in the world, per the waiter).  for the entrees, we had the rack of lamb and the brazino special (most expensive items on the menu but worth it). both were amazing as well.  i was absolutely stuffed but decided to share the tiramisu. WOW!! it was fresh and uber creamy. i would love to know the secret ingredient(s) in the cream.  they brought th dessert with a candle and also two glasses of their chocolate with chili and olive oil blend. 

we left the restaurant completely satisfied with warm happy tummies.  it is a winner and i will be bringing back the fam and girls
author: joyce l.

description: One of the nicest wait staff I've ever encountered.  We had made a reservation here for our anniversary and upon arrival realized there was a private party going on. The waiter was so apologetic and told us that the gentleman who took our reservation forgot there was a private party this evening. He also didn't take down our number to call and reschedule.  But he was insistent we come back a short 45 mins. later and enjoy a meal on the house. How many restaurants would do that?  We really didn't need an entire meal on the house as they were willing to accommodate us 45 mins. later.  But, it was such a nice gesture.  The food? DELICIOUS! The ricotta frito misto was heavenly. I crave it! The housemade pastas are fantastic as well.  I really love the staff and their demeanor; so nice.  Will definitely go back.
author: Susan Y.

description: Beautiful ambiance, great service, delicious, amazing food. I had the orecchiette pasta, my mother had the pork tenderloin special, our friends had the eggplant parmesan and the sea bass special. Everything was so yummy and thoughtfully prepared. Can't wait to go back to San Francisco and eat at Poesia again.  Definitely a must try.
author: Janinius B.

description:
I have been to italy several times to visit my italian relatives and we always go out to unique restaurants that feel like you're eating in someones living room. Poesia does exactly the same. Hands down the most authentic italian food I have had in the city, I felt like i was in the italian countryside again.

The owner was happy that me and the people i was with new something about what we were eating and hooked us up with a few free appetizers on the house

Ordered the asparagus and prosciutto pasta that (like many italian pastas) didn't actually have a "sauce" and was simply a bit of olive oil and chili flakes over farfalle.

Excellent dish, the desserts were great as well and there was a good wine selection

i'm coming back anytime i feel like being back in italy again

HIGHLY RECOMMENDED to anyone who feels that they cant' find real italian food in this city that hasnt been americanized or californianized
author: Jimmy K.

description: We had several decent dishes at Poesia: garden salad, the lamb shank ragu and the filet mignon were all fairly good. The service was really excellent. But several details bothered me and might stop me from returning. 1) the coffee was terrible, which is unusual for an Italian restaurant. Watery & unpleasant. The waiter changed it out for me, but by the second cup I realized it was just bad tasting coffee. 2) The olive oil served with the bread was so bitter it was inedible. 3) It was early in the evening and the restaurant had already run out of the fish course. The menu has a lot of shellfish and pork in the dishes, which we don't eat, so that was pretty disappointing. However, the location is great!
author: Eileen A.

description: Excellent Italian restaurant offering in the Castro with a menu that changes regularly, a wonderful atmosphere and excellent service. The night I ate at Poesia, there was an unreal sardines starter on the menu that was absolutely melt in your mouth delicious - not your conventional starter, and one I was glad I dared to indulge in. Then, my boyfriend and I shared a delicious salad and second course entree, which wound up being more than enough food for two people to enjoy. In summary, Poesia is a gem for its friendly vibe and upbeat staff. We chatted with the host & owner, who made us feel very welcome. All the while, a birthday dinner for 16 or so was unfolding right next to us, showing that even when it is very crowded, Poesia feels like a warm and cozy neighborhood place to eat dinner with friends and loved ones. Strongly recommended!
author: Marc S.

description: Poesia used to be my default Italian restaurant in SF, but it seems stale.  The food took forever to get out of the kitchen, service was OK and friendly, but it took us 45 minutes to sit even with a reservation.  They need to do something to freshen up the place or they will start bleeding customers.  I have no interest in going back again.
author: Casey W.

description: This was my first time at Poesia of San Francisco and I was very impressed from the moment I entered the restaurant.  At the door I was welcomed warmly by the owner.  It is a cozy place yet has an ambiance that made me feel I was going to have a very unique dinner experience.  The back wall was playing a classic film without sound as a backdrop to a very delicious dinner.  The service was outstanding!  I accidentally dropped my napkin and it was immediately replaced with a new one.  Now that's class.  I ordered the tomato soup and for dinner I had the rack of lamb.  The soup was thick and hearty and was delicious.  I also loved the unique bowl it was served in.  The rack of lamb was perfection.  I ordered it medium rare and that turned out to be the right choice.  It was seasoned and prepared better than I excepted.  I also enjoyed the potato and vegetables which came with my dinner. Our waiter was extremely helpful and attentive.  I would strongly recommend this restaurant to anyone that wants to sample the tastes of Italy with a San Francisco flair.
author: Mike I.

description:
What a nice surprise!   This is upstairs in an old Victorian row house, but when you walk in, you are treated to a chic, European decor.  The waitstaff was very friendly, if a little slow, but we enjoyed our meal so much it didn't matter.   The ricotta gnocchi with citrus sauce was excellent.  I ordered the Pollo al Mattone and was delightfully surprised with the flavors. I hadn't known what to expect, but it was delicious.  My dining partner orderd the orrichette with artichokes, walnuts, and provolone. Excellent choice as well.  The dessert is what we talked about all night.  The chocolate mousse!  Small scoops of dense, rich mousse on a smear of marscapone cheese, sprinkled with rock salt, and drizzled with olive oil.  There's a whole chili on the plate and everything is dusted with chili powder.  You take a small scoop of mousse with the cheese, and then just touch your spoon on the chili to break it.  When the combination goes into your mouth, it bounces around on your palette unbelieveably.  What a combination of flavors all at once!  Our only complaint was that we wished the scoops of mousse were a bit larger.  We each got a golf-ball sized portion.  But it was delicious!
     For those who are interested, they have poetry reading nights there as well, hence the name.
author: Ann G.

description: The service and attention from the staff was indeed great, but the food was a major disappointment.  The Fried artichoke cakes was veggie glop and had no taste of artichoke.  The boratta (sp) with asparagus and prosciutto was bland and didn't seen to go together.  The gnocchi was gummy and tasteless and the rack of lamb for 30 bucks was overcooked, dry and tasteless.  The desserts, however were quite good.
author: mark p.

description: People who rave about this place do not know Italian food. The more I think about the $80 I spent for a total crap meal, the more I feel I need to post this review. While the wait staff was pleasant, the kitchen really doesn't know or care what they are doing. Our appetizer was bland gnocchi with a texture somewhere between wet sand and chewing gum, and drowning in an almost inedible sauce of out-of-season mussels. My friend's fava bean and calamari soup tasted vaguely burnt and was unpleasantly viscous, rather than light and fresh as it should be. My branzino -- a whole fish but really not much of a fish for the $26 it cost -- was chewy and flavorless. It came with "sauteed vegetables" that turned out to be oily cherry tomatoes and red peppers that may as well have come from a can. The wine was unremarkable and overpriced. Even the bread was stale. We loved the basil-infused vodka martini, not the least because it cleared our palates of the horrible meal. We seriously wished we had simply gotten slices of pizza at Marcello's instead. Seriously, avoid this place and spend the equivalent amount of money for outstanding and nearly authentic food at Delfina or Farina.
author: James C.

description: I don't often go back to restaurants that I was not thrilled about, but it was my friends birthday and getting to go further than 2 miles from his house is a challenge, so we decided to go to Poesia.  I am so glad we did.  As the last time the service was awesome, but I really enjoyed the food as well!  There were six of us and we got a nice table at the back.  I had the Salt Cod for an appetizer and thought it was exceptional.  I had the pasta with short ribs for an entree.  Very good.  My partner had the eggplant parmigiana and I think it was the best I ever had.  For desserts I was bold and tried chocolate mousse with olive oil and chile.  It was a weird combo for me, but the mousse was good.  I completely recommend this place and am sure I will go again.
author: Sean O.

description: Excellent!  The eggplant parmigiana was just exquisite.  The service was attentive and deeply Italian, which was quite entertaining.  Some dishes were only good - the beet salad a bit bland, the tomato soup quite good could have benefited greatly from a bit of cream, but then others, like the capaccio di bue and the aforementioned eggplant, were amazing.  Great ambiance, excellent date place.  Well lit, not overloud, the prices are commensurate with the food, the wine list is extensive, and they project black and white Italian movies on the far wall for your delectation.
author: Jordan J.

description: On a cold San Francisco night, there is nothing like the thick, hot, amazingly flavorful tomato soup and homemade bread with obviously best-quality olive oil at Poesia.  I point this out because, the fine dining speaks for itself--the fish filet, the salads, and avant garde desserts paired with beautiful Italian Brunellos and Spumantis--for a romantic evening out, this is quite clearly the perfect place.  And yet, for the tired, the cold, the lonely...this place still does the trick.  The atmosphere, like the soup, is warm and flavorful.  Enjoy.
author: Alma D.

description: Used to eat at La Moone at this location, so pleasantly surprised by the fun ambiance, in a smallish space, fun waitstaff, and yummy food. Not as cheap as I'd like, but worth another visit. Cod spread was fresh and tasty, Tasty desserts, too!
author: David G.

description: I should have known better than to think there's such thing as fine dining in the Castro.  The food was good.  That's it... nothing about my dining experience was unique or anything to write home about.  The Pollo al Mattone was overcooked and the thyme/lemon butter sauce over the veggy and mashed potato tasted like it's been cooked a long time ago and it was simply reheated.  The highlight of my meal was the orecchiette.  The cauliflower in the pasta added interesting texture to the dish.  Overall I would recommend Poesia if you're in the Castro and looking for a decent meal with good friends in a cozy setting.
author: Peter S.

description: Pretty darn good. Would be 5 stars but our server forgot our entrees and brought us the desert menu after we finished our 1st pasta (things happen, I know). Regardless, I'm going back and bringing friends.
author: Alberto A.

description: The best  Southern Italian food in the city hands down!!!!!!!!!! Some of the noodles they make (fresh) my grandmother made when i was little, everything is soooooooo good. I have been twice and i cant waite to go back!! also the owner........um eye candy!! The staff is so nice and friendly and their service is excellent. This place is a must to check out!
author: T C.

description: I went to Poesia last Friday with a group of 6.  I decided to give this place a chance since hearing so many good things about it.  I have passed this  location numerous times but  I never made it up those stairs before Poesia.  The Castro finally has a restaurant they can be proud of. The food was fantastic, service impeccable (good looking to) and the atmosphere charming.
author: Robert P.

description: Treated my dad to a birthday dinner at this hole in the wall type place in the Castro. I felt like I was back in Europe. The service was beyond excellent. The food was slightly overpriced for the quality, but worth it for a special occasion. The menu seemed limited at first, but there was definetely something for each of us. They need to update the menu and wine list on their website because now I can't find the precious wine that our waiter recommended!
author: Sara W.

description: The most authentic Italian food I have had outside of Italy.  Succulent mozzarella. Tender calamari (not fried!).  Home made pastas that are to die for.  Waiters with Italian accents.  I would eat here every night if I could.
author: Jill D.

description:
there's something I really like about the space. maybe it is because it feels like you step off the castro streets into a different world. maybe it's the steep stairs with the very Italian host there to greet you at the top. maybe it's the bar that looks like it got built into the cove of the old Victorian that it is located in because it would not have fit otherwise. 

the duck was outstanding. love the alcove ceilings and the old couples that act as if they have been coming here for years (are senior citizens yelping too? where have I been??). service was friendly and warm in that classic Italian way. whatever that means. 

well priced, cozy, great for a date.
author: Jeremi M.

description: We had a late dinner here after a movie at the Castro and it's now my favorite spot in the neighborhood.  Excellent home made pasta;  we had the Fileji with the pork ribs, which was the perfect late fall savory dish.  Also a very nice local Italian wine list.  The canolo, though, was not very satisfying for these fans of New York canoli.
author: Paul H.

description: The food here is wonderful, and the service is outstanding. The first time we went, our waiter was very attentive and new everything about the food and cocktails.  I had the orechiette al forno and the beet salad...both delicious.  The place itself is in a Victorian house in the Castro, and they project old Italian movies on the wall which gives it a very nice ambience.  The drink menu has a lot of unique selections, and ask about their special after dinner aperitifs, which they make themselves (according to the attentive waiter).
author: Emily K.

description:
A pleasant surprise. After debating with friends for 30 minutes on where to go, we settled on Poesia for a few crucial reasons
1. I wanted "down home" Italian food while one of my friends has more eclectic tastes, and the menu seemed to satisfy both
2. It was a halfway point for our group, walkable by both parties, thereby preventing both the need to drive AND a sense of equity.

The food was superb. We shared the heirloom tomato salad (served with some of the tastiest olives I've come across) and I got the gnocchi as my main. The tomato sauce was perfect, the gnocchi itself was both chewy and creamy, and the mushrooms a lovely accent.

Have to rave about the chocolate mousse as well. We actually settled on the grand marnier tiramisu to share. The waiter had heard us debating beforehand and so he brought us out a complimentary serving of the mousse also. The consistency is almost like non-frozen gelato, and the sea salt, olive oil, and chili powder work perfectly. The grand marnier tiramisu was also a delight. Light, not overpowering, the orange tasted fresh and was served with candied orange peel accompaniments.

Staff was friendly and welcoming. They seem to be trying to build up their client base - and let me tell you it's working.
author: C M.

description:
Great little italian spot hidden in the Castro.  
Our waiter was Italian and he was very charming and sincere about the food.  We started out with a Sardine Appetizer and a Beet Salad.  Considering Sardines would never end up in my grocery cart I was very impressed.  The salad was just ok but the presentation was pretty.  
My main course was fantastic... The pasta was homemade and the sauce was definitely something I could never copy.  :)
For dessert I wrapped it all up with a Poached Pear and a scoop of Ice Cream.  Mmmm  Not much to complain about this place other than the decor.
author: Stevie G.

description: Wonderful!  Particularly out waiter.  When I had a hard time picking between two wines, he let me gave me healthy tastes of both.  In addition to the great service, the food was original and fantastic!
author: kathryn t.

description:
My wife and I entertained another couple at this restaurant tonight and were basically disappointed.  The service was 5 star but the food was unspectacular.  I would have to say that my squid appetizer was excellent, but the pork ribs left something to be desired.  First of all, it was actually the ends of pork ribs with plenty of inedible cartiledge.  My wife said her meal was just ok.  The food was expensive for what you got and quite disappointing.  The dessert we got was supposed to be like a Tiramisu but resembled more of a mouse like dessert.  It was $10.  Instead of having ice water, they served water out of some bottles but left a high ball glass with ice on the table.  Why not have ice in the glasses in the first place?  Anyway, four people, four entrees, one salad, one appetizer, two desserts and one coffee amounted to $150 exclusive of tip.  There was no wine, beer or soda consumed.  My personal recommendation is to skip this one.  I'm going to have to re-evaluate my opinion of Yelped restaurants with 4 star ratings from now on.  I've always been under the impression that 4 stars would be a pretty solid place.  I now know that isn't necessarily so.

Add to this the fact that two men wearing only g-strings were displaying their bodies just a few doors away.  It sort of ruined my wife's appetite.  I mean, even if it got her in the mood for linguisa, the Poesia doesn't have it on their menu!

I wish restaurants would print their specials on a sheet with the prices.  They always love to tell you about their specials but never tell you the prices which are usually more than the average prices on the menu.
author: geoff k.

description:
Finally!  A great restaurant comes to the Castro... I was with a large group of friends recently at Poesia and we ordered every appetizer on the menu plus a majority of the entrees.  We all shared our dishes and everyone left the restaurant completely sated.  My personal favorites:  appetizers: the lamb; the fresh mozzarella, and the seafood plate.  Entrees: the fish and the gnocchi were excellent.  The bartender knows what he's doing -- the drinks are fantastic.

The staff are all young, very personable, friendly, and warm. Overall a fantastic experience.
author: Tony Y.

description: One of our favorites. Always excellent authentic Italian. Love the fresh pastas, esp the gnocchi. Fun and romantic atmosphere right in the heart of the Castro.
author: Peter H.

description:
Quite simply, the food was HORRIBLE!!! Well at least what I ordered! A friend and I met my BF & a friend of his there. They had just finished their meals, and then we ordered; I went for the Gnocchi. Imagine, Polenta cheese, mushroom creamy sauce & the Gnocchi, sounds great huh??? WRONG!!! I sent it back! I attempted to add salt & pepper, SO did not help! Still bland, mushy and extremely flavorless!! My buddy ordered the Airline Chicken Breast aka Cornish Hen sauced with some Cilantro, Lime stuff that KILLED the naturally tender and flavorful chicken. Dessert was where I was hoping they'd redeem themselves & sadly they did not. The Ice Cream Sandwiches were ok, forgettable though. The Cannoli was AWFUL!! Again, NO flavor; can someone show the cook staff that there are spices out there! I spit it out; the BF thought it was good, I could not stand to even think of having another bite! 
The staff was ok, however it took them FOREVER to drop the check and when they finally did it took them another forever to process 2 cards! Yet they were all VERY nice!!

Definitely NOT returning!
author: Rob L.

description:
I'm very surprised by people who were underwhelmed by the food at Poesia. All the pasta we had was definitely homemade. From our first glass of sparkling rose prosseco through our rich chocolate dessert, the evening was wonderful. It is a very cute space. A little loud, but not too bad. We didn't make a reservation, and still got in on a Friday night at 7. I always thinks it's a good sign when your waiter at an Italian restaurant is Italian. 

My new favorite local spot for a fancier dinner.
author: Silent A.

description: fantastic , cute romantic with fantastic service . the food was amazing . A gem .
author: eric d.
